story:
Book Project "HDB: Homes of Singapore"

Singapore's Housing Development Board (HDB) has built one of the world's best and fascinating public housing solutions. "HDB: Homes of Singapore" is a pictorial journey of photographs taken over a period of three years that portray the diversity, culture, individuality, colours and creativity within HDB homes. This project is the brainchild of the artist duo Eitaro Ogawa and Tamae Iwasaki of KEYAKISMOS, with architect Tomohisa Miyauchi.


The photographs of this book are currently exhibited at the 15th International Architecture Exhibition, titled REPORTING FROM THE FRONT, curated by Alejandro Aravena and organised by La Biennale di Venezia (Venice Biennale). They are on view until 27 November 2016.

Join our journey 

Our journey began in 2008 when we considered purchasing a HDB flat. To tell the truth, we were a little concerned about living in what seemed like rigid and uniformed units at the time, but that changed completely after visiting friends' homes, namely flats that were renovated so uniquely. Since then we toyed with the idea of making a book about HDBs. This materialised when we met and shared the idea with Tomo in 2013. We immediately got to work, taking photos that very weekend! We got in touch with as many people in our address books as we possible in a bid to search and capture interesting flats. We even knocked on the doors of strangers who, to our surprise and delight, welcomed and even fed us well on many occasions! Throughout this project, what touched us the most was the kindness of people's hearts, the lives they live and the generosity that enabled such rich story-sharing. Singaporeans often speak of the lack of culture in Singapore yet we found this to be quite the contradiction because we discovered much culture residing in the topic of the HDB flat alone! Culture was evident in each home. Culture was lived. At the end of the project, we gathered plenty of photos. But more importantly, we got to know Singapore a lot more through uncovering the multifarious and personal way of living beyond the exteriors of the HDB flat-- and this was something we wanted the photographs to capture.

At the end of project, we gathered many photos  but moreover we got to know Singapore a lot more through HDB flats.


You are the Impact

The photographs trace our three-year journey of visiting various HDB flats chronologically. We hope to publish them as a book that would be accessible to many. You can join in this amazing discovery of Singaporean culture by supporting the project and getting a copy.

- We need to raise a total of US$38,000 in funds to print 2,000 copies of this book. Funding received will also be channelled towards the videography, as well as the book's translation, design and layout which we have begun.

- Please support us by ordering a copy of this book which will be published and start shipping out in Dec 2016.

    Our Challenges

    The hardcover book of 588 pages (30 x 30 cm) will contain images of over a hundred homes in Singapore in full colour images. We wish to make this book as affordable as possible by printing more copies and reaching the community in Singapore, as well as the wider community worldwide. Your support will bring us closer to our goal in sharing the Singapore story.

    Share the Good News

    Any support from you, big or small, means a lot to us. Please share this project with your friends and families. Good news always gets around.


    100 Limited Edition book cover.

story:
Landscapes & Light 2017

We are aiming to produce a 2017 Calendar showcasing some of the finest landscapes from around the UK. By combining the talents of photographers Francis Taylor and Adam Sherratt our calendar will deliver a selection of some of their best work, bound together in a high quality A3 wall calendar. The aim of this project is to raise funds for the 'Fix Our Father' campaign.  

Fix our Father is urgently trying to raise money for Karl Bullimore, a Grantham man, who in October 2015 was diagnosed with stage 4 bladder cancer.  This particular form of cancer is so rare that the NHS weren't able to offer treatment. However, the family has been able to find hope through a private oncology clinic in London. Karl started a course of chemotherapy while a targeted immunology drug therapy was developed specifically for him. Unfortunately this particular type of treatment is vastly expensive. The Bullimore family has exhausted their life savings and have only been able to carry on treatment through the generosity of family and friends.

This is where you come in. We need your assistance in funding this calendar so that we can use it as a platform to raise money for Karl and his family, in order to help them carry on with treatment. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to cover the initial printing costs for the calendar in order to turn this project from a concept into a reality. Ring bound and printed on high quality paper, the calendar will be packed full of stunning landscape photography ensuring you have something beautiful to keep track of those all important dates throughout 2017. 

With images provided by Adam and Francis, the calendar will be A3 (297w x 420h mm) sized, packed full of beautiful landscape photography and presented in a stylish month by month spiral bound form.

The projected photos can be seen in the gallery section (please note that we may change them as we develop the product).  

The Impact

Please don't underestimate the impact of your pledge/donation. You are enabling us to produce this calendar to raise money for the Bullimore family.  Imagine if it were a member of your family, what you would give for a chance of hope. 

The more we raise, the more we can produce. The more we produce, the more cost efficient it becomes and the more we can donate to the family.  We hope to raise over £1000 for Karl and his family, it would be fantastic to raise even more!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that everyone's circumstances are different and not everyone can afford to donate.  That's OK, you can still make a difference. Simply share this campaign with everyone you know using the share tools available. Could you sell some at a market?  Can you ask colleagues at work?  Parents at the local play group?  Spread the word where you can.  

If you wish to make a direct donation to Fix Our Father, please visit https://gogetfunding.com/fix-our-father/

The photographers

Adam Sherratt
www.adamsherratt.co.uk
Adam Sherratt is a sports, landscape and nature
photographer, travelling the UK to capture light
as it falls on some of the worlds finest scenes.
Adam loves to show the passage of time in his
photographs, capturing movement to allow the
viewer to experience the scene, or to add a sense
of mysticism and the unreal.

Francis Taylor
www.francisjtaylor.co.uk
Francis Taylor is a well renowned and respected
landscape and wildlife photographer.  Based in
Sheffield, Francis spends much of his time in
and around the Peak District National Park.
With an eye for composition and a flare for
capturing the moment Francis is
rapidly gaining a reputation as a talent to be watched.

story:
Hi! We are Melis Agabigum (San Francisco, CA) and Rachel Andrea Davis (Iowa City, IA), two emerging makers who have proposed & curated a two person art jewelry show What Lies Beneath, which features our individual and collaborative works.

Our proposal has been accepted as part of the 3 juried group curated shows during Athens Jewelry Week 2018 in Athens, Greece. AJW is a week-long International art jewelry show held in May hosted by the non-profit organization [anti]clastics. Our participation in this event would mean that we will be renting a local gallery space, curating work, and traveling to Greece to  install it in conjunction with the main event show curated by [anti]clastics.

ATHENS JEWELRY WEEK “aims through collective action, to promote Contemporary Greek Jewelry both in Greece and abroad.” Our aim in participating in AJW2018 is to present our contemporary jewelry to the wider public, while showing the international diversity and artistic dimension of works being produced by emerging artists from the United States.

We (Melis and Rachel) met at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee in 2013 while Melis was pursuing her MFA and Rachel, her BFA. Since then, we have supported each other in our artistic endeavors. We are both active participants in creating individual bodies of work that examine various forms of love, loss, mourning, and burden. Separately, we have shown our individual works in several national and international venues, and have now reached a milestone in our emerging careers with being accepted to curate and exhibit a joint show of our work internationally. 

With your donations, the funding of this project would allow us to bring our work to a broader international audience and represent emerging American makers. It would be both individual promotion of our works, but also a promotion of emerging artists that will hopefully foster future opportunities to connect with galleries and makers around the world.

We are committing to showing What Lies Beneath during Athens Jewelry Week 2018. As emerging artists with limited financial resources, funding of this project would allow us to both to transport our work and displays, travel to Athens, install our work, host our opening, and pay for our participation and registration fees-- in total about $8,500 USD. All proceeds raised would go towards making this event a reality.

In return for your donations, we are happy to offer a variety of rewards!

If we do not reach our entire goal, the raised proceeds will go to covering our venue rental, display/installation materials, and transport of our work. Whatever costs are left over will be covered by us individually.

However, should we find ourselves fortunate enough to exceed our goal of $8,500 USD, all further funding will go toward other necessary expenses that we may incur during the process of putting on this show, including travel while in Greece, lodging, and promotional materials (show cards, posters, etc.).

Participating in AJW18 is a huge step in our individual careers as well as our joint effort in putting together a traveling version of this two person show for the future. Experience and relationships fostered through our participation with international gallerists and buyers will also help us on our journey to further grow as artists and connect to the greater art jewelry community. 

We request that you please share this funding campaign with everyone you know:  on your blogs, mailing lists, and social media sites.  Your support is beneficial to our community's growth.

story:
OUR STORY:

We are group of theatre makers based in the Sweden, UK and Southern Africa, who are interested in telling untold stories and presenting performances that question mainstream norms in our society. We believe theatre can both entertain and create social change. We do this by producing thought provoking theatre and run participatory workshops that engage people in dialogue.

In this project, we are working as a collaborative towards our goal – to open-up dialogue about diversity and belonging by presenting a theatrical performance and accompanying workshops to diverse audiences around South Africa. We will be performing as part of the main programme at the National Arts Festival in Grahamstown, and then traveling onto PopArt in Johannesburg and the Alexander Bar and Theatre in Cape Town. Parallel to our performances we are running our participatory workshops in collaboration with Drama For Life, South Africa’s leading centre for theatre and research in applied arts.

We’re excited to bring The Incident to new audiences and engage in new, bold discussions.

 

WHY THE INCIDENT?

The Incident is a poignant theatrical performance about whether you are ready to stand up for your values when the stakes are raised. Are we prepared to and can we change our behaviors in order to understand others? The play and the workshop make the audience and participants reflect over how we are shaped by our experiences, including our cultural and ethnic backgrounds, and how it influences the ways we see the world and how we treat other people.

 

IMPACT

We believe that theatre can be a vehicle for dialogue and social change. Through the play, we want to open up a dialogue about race and gender relations - an important topic that people often find difficult to talk about. We will have post-show discussions and ask for feedback from the audience on the topics raised. We will also run workshops that use scenes from the play and Theatre of the Oppressed techniques to create a safe space for audience and community members alike to discuss the themes of the show in relation to their own experiences. The National Arts Festival is the highlight of the South African arts scene and both a South African and international audience. we are looking forward to bringing this highly relevant performance to South African and international audiences. Through our partnership with Drama for Life we are aiming to create a long-term collaboration where we can continue to run our workshops for different communities in South Africa and possibly create new work. The National Arts Festival is also an opportunity for us to create new partnerships in South Africa and beyond.

 

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

We have created a number of partnerships for our South African run but we need an additional £1000 to cover our local travel accommodation cost for our team of performers, workshop facilitators and director.

Your contribution will help pay for travel and accommodation costs.

 

If you contribute:

 

£10 – You will receive free weekly updates to your e-mail from the production (voluntary)

 

£20 – Your name will appear in the ‘thank you’ section on our website and social media (voluntary)

 

£50 – All of the above + You will get thank you message from the Artistic Team and your name will appear in the production program

 

£100 -  All of the above + You will get personal message from the Artistic Team and your name will appear in the production program and on our website and social media.

 

£500 – All of the above + A free copy of a recording of the performance

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We understand that not everyone is able to donate. However, you can still contribute by:

•           Sharing our campaign on Social Media, Facebook and Instagram and by word of mouth to your friends, family and anyone you think might be interested in supporting us

•           Being an audience member at one of our shows

•           Following us on social media @TheIncidentPlay

•           Using the hashtag #TheIncident #NAF2018

story:
Short Summary 

            My name is Adam DeDecker and this time last year The Giving Tree started to sprout into more than a dream. Little did I know it was going to receive two awards of excellence at burning man 2017 and was the largest an most stunning piece that the Arise music and art festival has seen in its five years. I purchased the base vehicle of The Giving Tree in 2015, a 1989 blue bird short bus that I converted into my off the grid green mobile home to travel the nation with my best friend Spudz McKenzee the coolest golden retriever to lay a paw on this earth! We formed many good memories on the road together unfortunately I lost him March 3, 2017. We loved sharing the outdoors together. My best friend shared many great understandings of life but this last year I learned that not everything was meant to be understood. So with great loss I created uplifting art and it continued to fill my spirit with all kinds of unconditional love and happiness from all walks of life. The Giving Tree has allowed me to continue to share my best friends great spirit. It's very sacred to keep the giving tree alive for its journey is not complete. We are campaigning to raise funds for a new engine. We have already been invited back to Burning man 2018. It's a real bummer but the old engine has retired permanently so we are getting it in the shop to get ready for the new engine transplant. Please help us bring The Giving Tree back to life. We would love to make it to a few events before arriving to the playa this year.

            We are raising funds for a new engine, the old engine has retired and we are looking to purchase a remanufactured 7.3 liter IDI diesel engine to replace the old one. A new engine on the low end will cost around  $3,000  before the install. Anything we raise over our goal will be invested into any extra install fees and beyond that upgrades to The Giving Tree such as a new 6000 watt generator and 6500 watt power inverter that the playa claimed last year, we could also upgrade our sound system and lighting. If we don't reach our goal all the funds we do raise will still be invested toward the new engine. However if we do reach our goal  before the campaign ends, then we will be able to keep the fundraiser rolling to help with all the fun upgrades that we want to improve on this year! Besides just replacing the engine which is our main objective at the moment. Anything helps and we are very determined to make it back to playa and hopefully a few events before we return home this year. We have a great track record for a first year art car, in fact it's better than great. Burning Man awarded it excellence to the second power and Arise music and art festival loved every minute of it and more. We are currently based in Gardnerville, NV just south of Reno. So if you would like to contribute hands on, we always love learning and building together with our local community. We have new perks this time around. Giving Tree stickers, koozies, T-shirts, Hats and more. We are very excited about our return to the playa 2018 please contribute by spreading the word about our campaign. Thank you all for taking the time to read about our journey! Let the giving never stop as we will continue to give unconditional inspiration. For we are so grateful, may all your wonderful dreams come true.

 

MUCH LOVE )'(

The Giving Tree

Giving Tree stickers, koozies, T-shirts, Hats and more. We are very excited about our return to the playa 2018 please contribute by spreading the word about our campaign. Thank you all for taking the time to read about our journey! Let the giving never stop as we will continue to give unconditional inspiration. For we are so grateful, may all your wonderful dreams come true.
 
MUCH LOVE )'(
The Giving Tree

story:
BACKGROUND

Ilana Peña and Madeline Hendricks founded See What Sticks in 2015.  As they hustled in the television writing industry, they realized they both craved their own artistic community - somewhere people could feel safe to take risks, be vulnerable, and celebrate each other's work. And so See What Sticks was born! 

CAMPAIGN

As we enter our third year, we need your help to raise $1500 so we can continue renting the Lyric Hyperion Theater & Cafe, while expanding the community and keeping our workshops free to the public. Additionally, this year we are launching a new creative lab initiative where we will produce original, full-length projects. By donating, you will help us shepherd thought-provoking pieces from new voices, and support a rare artistic haven in LA that encourages people to collaborate, connect, and take creative risks!

story:
The story so far

The alchemy of glassblowing is a remarkably unchanged heritage craft currently on the brink of extinction… I am an artist and a glassblower. Trained and practised in the chemical industry.

Here is a video produced during my training to give an idea. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AGvf-3tZKoY

Since 2015 I have been building up my glass workshop MERSEY GLASS WORKS http://www.merseyglassworks.co.uk/ in South Liverpool, UK.

I managed to survive and build it up for five years. Since 2017 I have been teaching specialised beginners glassblowing workshops to public audiences.

Here are a couple of reviews:

Here is a link to my workshops https://www.airbnb.co.uk/experiences/884697 and I also produce memorial glass art with cremation ashes made into personal memorial glass art. http://www.memorialglassart.co.uk/

What I am hoping to get

In light of the recent pandemic and it’s economic impact on many small creative businesses I am looking for support to ensure the survival of my glass art and education centre.

My biggest motivation for my work with glass is that I want to share the fascination for glass as for the incredible material it really is.

I promised my scientific glassblowing teacher Paul LePinnet MBE https://europe.worldscientific.com/news-events/2016-07-14-01.html that I will continue showing people the magic of glassblowing and promote the importance of preserving this heritage craft from disappearing completely over the next generations.

I want to raise money by offering artworks in return for a small contribution to my campaign.

It would help enormously to be able pay off rent arrears, overheads and insurance as well as progress my practice by developing ways for teaching workshops in outdoor settings on markets, street events and for schools and community centers.

I would use about two-thirds of the raised funds towards my ongoing costs and one-third towards creating new ways of teaching.

 

'Who when he first saw the sand and ashes by a casual intenseness of heat melted into metalline form, rugged with excrescences and clouded with impurities, would have imagined that in this shapeless lump lay concealed so many conveniences of life as would, in time, constitute a great part of happiness in the world.

Yet by some such fortuitous liquefaction was mankind taught to procure a body at once in a high degree solid and transparent; which might admit the light of the sun, and exclude the violence of the wind; which might extend the sight of the philosopher to new ranges of existence, and charm him at one time with the unbounded extend of material creation, and at another with endless subordination of animal life, and, what is of yet more importance, might supply the decays of nature, and succour old age with subsidiary sight. Thus was the artificer in glass employed though without his knowledge or expectation.

He was facilitating and prolonging the enjoyment of light, enlarging the avenue of science, and conferring the highest and most lasting pleasures; he was enabling the student to contemplate nature, and the beauty to behold herself.'

Samuel Johnson, 1750

 

Since 2013 I have been a proud member of the B.S.S.G the British Society of Scientific Glassblowers and can only hope that they will be able to continue to do such a fantastic job of promoting scientific glassblowing in the UK. http://www.bssg.co.uk/

 

If you appreciate glass art please support my journey - if you can - with a perk based donation or a small amount to keep me afloat through these difficult time or if money is as much of problem for you, as it is for me at the moment then maybe you could pass on this link to people who might be interested to support glass art. There are very few places around the UK, where a complete novice can learn about this fascinating material hands on. I also give talks about glass art and offer fused glass workshops to local community groups. I love all glass art and technique and, am determined to continue to offer insights into to the mysterious world of glass.

Are you are fan of light reflecting glass art?

story:
Summary 

Hi! My name is Wisdom, and I am a Chicago based artist, mother and curator. With over a decade of experience in making art, community organizing and event planning, I am most passionate about curating space for black mothers and children. The fullness of my creative practice explores negotiating space, autonomy and historical accuracy in support of black families through a lens of intersectionality and motherhood. 

Wild Yams: Black Mothers Artist Residency (B.M.A.R), is an art residency experience designed to support, uplift and encourage artist sustainability for black mothers on the South Side of Chicago. Inspired by traditional artist residencies, Wild Yams B.M.A.R provides studio space, studio visits, artist stipends and exhibition opportunities. In additional to the standard artist residency model, Wild Yams B.M.A.R provides a holistic equity approach, catering to the specific needs of black mothers, caretakers and children. These needs being; a child care stipend, workshops on entrepreneurship, finances, grant writing and workshops on healing the health and wellness of black women. 

Wild Yams B.M.A.R has partnered with the South Shore co-working space Colab7100, to provide studio and coworking space. 

Minar Kalyango, Wild Yams: Black Mothers Artist Residency 2020 inaugural artist, is an artist, teacher, mother and entrepreneur. She currently uses COLAB7100 to conduct photoshoots and exhibit her work. Wild Yams: Black Mother Artist Residency was supported by a 2019 Threewalls Propellor Grant. 

Your support in growing this Artist in Residency, will generate an increase in creativity within the lives of black mothers on the South Side of Chicago. Join me!

 

What We Need & What You Get 

Wild Yams: Black Mother Artist Residency seeks to raise $5,500 to continue developing our equity model. Funding will provide a variety of key resources for our current artist Minar Kalyango, the next artist in resident, and the growing community of black creatives that participate in Wild Yams B.M.A.R programming. Below is a budget breakdown: 

1. Dedicated Office Space: $525/ per month (for the total of 5+ months) 

Leasing a dedicated office space for 5 months, within COLAB7100 for the artist to conduct private business, studio visits, general meetings, self reflection/ and quiet time. Currently the resident artist has use of the conference room, lounge and common area, along with other amenities provided by the coworking space.  

2. Artist Stipend $500 (for the second round)

3. Child Care Stipend ($200)

4. Partnership with a wellness instructor: $800

5. Skill building Workshops: $300

6. Community Engagement: $200

7. Exhibition costs: $75

8. Social media promoter: $200

10. Establish organizations legal status: $200

11: Assessment workshop with Wild Yams team: $300 

 

If our entire funding goals are not meet, funding will be allotted to the following components in order of importance:

1. Partnership with Wellness Instructor/ Consultant 

2.  Dedicated Office Space 

3. Skill building workshops 

    4. Artist Stipend (second iteration) 

    5. Child Care Stipend (second iteration) 

    6. Skill building workshops 

    7-11. The remainder items 

     

    The Impact

    You can read more about the ongoing impact Wild Yams: Black Mother Artist Residency has generated below in a Block Club Chicago feature by South Shore contributor Maxwell Evans: 

    https://blockclubchicago.org/2020/11/11/art-res... 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute financially, but feel a deep connection to this mission you can help by: 

    1.  Sharing this campaign. with your network.

    2. Use the Indiegogo share tools!

2. Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Summary of this Project 

Greetings, fellow human BE-ing. Thank you for showing up to this space for a look around. My name is Reena Marie Spansail {she//her}l, and for now, I will be your guide for your journey through the labyrinth. This interactive experience of walking a labyrinth while looking at art inspired by the story of Aradne, one of the characters in the most famous myth of the labyrinth of King Minos, where Thesus slew the Minotaur, is both an art show and a remembering, a chance to engage with an ancient symbol of transformation, and noticing how interacting with this pattern has transformed me as an artist. 

This artistic experience is important to me because it is a metaphor and a portal for our collective healing and grief journey. I believe we all need to have space to unpack and untangle the knots of the past year and half (at least!) and this is the space I have envisioned for us to do that. This show will be up for about 3 weeks, and it will live on as a digital artefact on my website, reenart.space, after the show leaves the gallery. 

Finally, especially if it is the case we haven’t met, I’d like you to know some things I call myself, and some things I practice. I alternately call myself a multimedia artist, your friendly neighborhood art teacher, wyrdo, moon-gazer, shaper of culture, and a member of the Wander Society. I practice in writing poems, sculpting ceramics, dance, breathing mindfully, getting still, devotion, ink painting, water and color. My ongoing intentions are to quicken and nourish artful, creative experience in my personal, professional, and performative living. I invite you to join me this August (Leo-Virgo season) in an exercise in artful living by funding an interactive labyrinth gallery experience at the Potentialist Workshop Gallery in Reno, Nevada, on the unceded lands of the Numu Paiute people.

I am honored to work with this sacred symbol, and act as a conduit of our collective abundance of visual, performative, and ritual knowledge for transforming ourselves as we walk through the Labyrinth of our lives. Thank you for your consideration, time, and space. 

Godxspeed! 

 

What I Need & What You Recieve 

Here’s a breakdown of our funding request:

Our goal is $1350 to launch, hang, perform, and share the experience of embodied labyrinth with the Northern Nevada arts and culture making community.

This funding will go to:

  • Gallery booking fees (this is the portion that directly keeps the Potentialist workshop’s doors open for art happening) ($350)
  • Performance materials costs  (this is the portion that directly helps create mood, ambiance, and performance actions that lay the groundwork for this gallery experience ($200)
  • Supply costs for hanging artwork (nails, wood, frames, patch paint, etc.) ($200)
  • Opening and closing reception//art party for viewers and artists ($400)
  • Studio stocking costs (paint, ink, paper, cloth, brushes, etc. Most of the materials in this show are recycled, but not all) ($200)

These funds will be collectively pushed into making this show an experienced, collective meaning-making opportunity and reality for August 16-31 at the Potentialist Workshop. If we don’t reach our entire goal, all funds raised here will go directly into exhibition and costs of art making and shipping.   

What you will receive in return, specifically: 

  • At 6$, you will receive a digital photo of a hand-drawn labyrinth.
  • At $11, you receive a digitally printed postcard with a finger labyrinth on it in the mail and instructions on how to draw your own 4-circuit labyrinth.
  • At 22$, you will receive a small original labyrinth painting with watercolor on recycled paper.
  • At $33 you will receive a linoleum block print of the labyrinth's path on recycled paper.
  • At $44, you will receive a medium original painting of one of the spirits of the labyrinth. 
  • At $88 you will receive an original watercolor on wood painting of the labyrinth myth. 
  • At $144 you will receive a large original ink and watercolor painting on recycled paper.

Important Logistical  Notes: All art except the digital labyrinths will be posted by mail to your mailing address by the end of the third week in September. Artworks will go out first pledged, first served. You may select the specific artwork you want according to your price level at the opening reception or closing reception of the show, August 20th 6-8pm or August 28th, 5-7pm at the Potentialist Workshop, 836 E 2nd St, Reno, NV 89502. If you are interested in funding the show but do not want a physical artwork, or you would like to discuss commission work, or if you'd like to see more images, please contact me directly at spansailr@gmail.com. 

The Impact

By supporting this project and, by extension, my artistic practice, you are actively making the choice to engage with these possible benefits:

  • A mythic journey of profound mystery and wonder into an ancient and universal pattern. 
  • A budding relationship with a lovingly made piece of the labyrinth, and a clue for how to make it through on your own. 
  • Supporting the building of a public space for pausing and for processing our collective WOW and grief of the last year and a half, with a tool that has been in use by humans for transformation since at least 4,000 years ago.
  • Nodding and feeling YES to  low-waste  art making processes and recycled use art objects and materials; one small step towards more sustainable living.
  • Supporting public arts education through patronage of myself as a high school art teacher. I consider all my solo work to be part of a research and development process of projects for my students to engage with and build upon. By supporting me, you support my students. .
  • Beaming with the knowledge that you support a local arts and culture birth and nurturing space, The Potentialist Workshop, a Reno-based artist collective devoted to developing the potentiality for creative living for all. By supporting this space, you help create and shape culture in our community.
  • Contributing to environmental justice and land-back efforts. A portion of the overall proceeds from this gallery show will go to support land and water protectors. Please read the FAQ to learn the specifics of the Stop Line 3 and Protect Thacker Pass organizations that will receive funds from this project. 

Risks & Challenges

We are still in a global pandemic. Making and hanging art is difficult in the best of times, coming out to public events is often uncomfortable. This show will be be a distanced, masked public gathering, but by attending it in person, you do accept the responsibilities and risks of engaging in an interactive art show while there is an ongoing public health emergency. The interactive elements of this gallery experience are all voluntary, and you will not be asked to engage in anything you do not agree to whole-heartedly. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you can't contribute to this campaign, but that doesn't mean you can't make this happen! Here's some other ways to get involved:

  • Send me sustenance//snack cash for the working nights and mornings to my venmo @reenam account directly (you can also donate directly via venmo or paypal if that’s easier for  you-please just contact me)
  • Share this invitation with your guardians, elders, your email list, your therapist, your D&D party-share wherever and within whomever labyrinth, water, color and art-making medicine is needed and wanted in your life. Look! Indigogo has share tools! 
  • Send me prayerful, or wishful thoughts for good art-making and good myth weaving while I complete this work. 
  • Contact me via email with your uplifting words of good news and wandering notes at spansailr@gmail.com. This is the personal energetic form of sustenance, thank you! 

And that's all there is to it. Are you ready to join us in the labyrinth?

story:
Short Summary

  • A little about me,  I have spent the last 20 years engineering and machining all sorts of contracts from NASA to DOD ect:  But my true passion even from a boy has been to become and master blacksmithing,  moving back to Colorado to take over my families property gave me the opportunity to finally pursue my dream.  I have worked with all  manners of machinery  and equipment but want to leave that behind and become a true craftsman, to create pieces of art all buy hand.  To bring back to life a lost art that very few know.
  • I  am trying to raise enough to build the equipment and tools I need to further expand my shop, to have the ability to create even larger pieces 
  • I feel with your help I will be able to have a greater chance to begin learning even more and crafting full time.  To pursue a life dream and be able to share it with the world.

What We Need & What You Get

  • I am trying to raise $2,000 to build a larger forge and to build my first foundry.  Which I am very excited to be able to cast infinite possibilities.  which will further expand my ideas to reality.
  • All the funds I receive will be dedicated to this dream even if my goal is not met.  I feel it will put my a foot step closer to achieving my goals. 

The Impact

  • I believe that this form of art is a dying craft and needs to have more passionate people to revive and show the world the beauty that  comes from it.

story:
English version here

IL NOSTRO PROGETTO

L’Accademia Musicale Mediterranea di Carini (Palermo) è un centro multifunzionale che si autofinanzia poiché non gode ancora di nessun contributo pubblico. Il nostro sogno è quello di realizzare il progetto Carini Piazza d’Arte, ideato nel 2014 e che punta alla riscoperta di alcuni tra i più importanti e suggestivi luoghi della città di Carini, molti dei quali troppo spesso trascurati e non adeguatamente valorizzati. Attraverso la programmazione di mostre, concerti, concorsi musicali, saggi e seminari di volta in volta abbiamo dato risalto ad un luogo diverso della città, che per l’occasione è diventato palcoscenico dei nostri spettacoli: dal rinomato Castello di Carini alla meno conosciuta ma altrettanto incantevole Chiesa degli Agonizzanti, dal Chiostro dei Carmelitani a Piazza delle Vittorie, dal Teatro Totuccio Aiello al Baglio al Mare e tanti altri che, ospitando le manifestazioni organizzate dall’Accademia, vengono messi in luce, riqualificati e vissuti con più partecipazione da ogni cittadino. L’obiettivo di Carini Piazza D’Arte è quello di proseguire su questa strada da poco intrapresa, dando vita ad un calendario di eventi musicali e culturali per il 2016 che abbia come protagonisti i monumenti della nostra città, anche quelli meno conosciuti e a volte dimenticati, ma non per questo meno affascinanti. All’interno di questo contesto, uno degli obiettivi è quello di organizzare delle Masterclass con artisti di chiara fama internazionale che hanno già dato la loro disponibilità, al fine di impreziosire il nostro calendario eventi. Grazie alla nostra iniziativa infatti, gli stessi carinesi hanno riscoperto chiese, piazze e scorci che fino a poco tempo fa erano caduti nell’oblio. Il riscontro che abbiamo ottenuto in questi mesi da parte dei nostri concittadini, ci spinge a non mollare e a continuare a credere nella possibilità di mettere in pratica le nostre intenzioni a lungo termine.

PERCH SOSTENERCI 

A causa dei grossi limiti economici, quest’anno siamo riusciti a realizzare alcune delle iniziative previste dal progetto Carini Piazza D’Arte, soprattutto grazie alla forza di volontà e all’impegno di giovani musicisti autoctoni e non, dei maestri, degli allievi, e di tutti coloro i quali hanno sposato con entusiasmo la nostra causa. Ad oggi però, trovandoci senza fondi, rischiamo di doverci fermare e di non poter portare avanti il progetto. Per questo motivo, anche un piccolo contributo può aiutarci a proseguire la realizzazione di questo sogno in musica. 

Ringranziadovi in anticipo, vi invitiamo a continuare la lettura e a conoscerci meglio.

L'ACCADEMIA MUSICALE MEDITERRANEA

La musica come veicolo di integrazione e di solidarietà, la cultura in senso lato come occasione di crescita individuale, anche professionale. Sono questi i princìpi che guidano l'azione dell'Accademia Musicale Mediterranea di Carini (Palermo).

Corsi di studio tenuti da docenti di rilievo nazionale e internazionale e rivolti ai bambini e ai ragazzi costituiscono il cuore delle attività dell'Accademia, che comprendono anche stage formativi, masterclass e workshop.

Il lavoro svolto dal gruppo che anima l'AMM mira all'alta formazione musicale, sia classica che moderna, dei propri allievi, che siano consapevoli della massima rilevanza del concetto di progettualità nella realizzazione dei loro percorsi di crescita creativa e professionale.

Una formazione che sia davvero per tutti, diretta a chi ha talento da far emergere, al di là delle proprie possibilità economiche.

Inoltre, l'Accademia punta da sempre al coinvolgimento di tutta la comunità locale attraverso l'ideazione e la realizzazione di eventi quali concerti, concorsi e mostre, con lo scopo ulteriore e l'ambizione di diventare un polo di eccellenza musicale per tutto il bacino del Mediterraneo.

Infine, vi presentiamo due delle nostre formazioni: la Mediterranea Jazz Orchestra e il Coro di voci bianche.

Mediterranea Jazz Orchestra

Formatasi durante l'anno accademico 2014/2015, è il principale organico strumentale della Accademia Musicale Mediterranea. È un'orchestra di diciotto elementi, spesso integrata da altre sezioni strumentali, e vede la collaborazione di docenti e allievi con artisti del panorama jazzistico nazionale. Il suo debutto è avvenuto il 5 luglio 2015 presso il Chiostro di San Vincenzo a Carini (Palermo), sotto la direzione di Roberto Basile, attuale direttore e responsabile musicale della MJO, nonché membro fondatore dell’AMM.

La formazione è impegnata nella diffusione di progetti speciali e nella realizzazione di proprie produzioni originali.

Coro di Voci Bianche dell’Accademia Musicale Mediterranea

Nato nel marzo del 2011, il Coro di voci bianche dell’Accademia Musicale Mediterranea è costituito da circa quaranta bambini selezionati tra gli alunni di tutte le scuole del comune di Carini. Il lavoro del coro, diretto dal Maestro Maura Aresu, si basa su incontri settimanali dedicati allo studio della musica, della vocalità e del repertorio. Per gli allievi si tratta di una preziosa opportunità  formativa culturale e musicale.

Il coro ha partecipato a numerosi eventi, distinguendosi anche  fuori dalla realtà cittadina, in produzioni svoltesi in luoghi quali il Teatro Politeama "Giuseppe Garibaldi" di Palermo, il Duomo di Caccamo e in centri esterni al Palermitano come Noto e Lipari.

---------------------------------------------------

English

VETRINA

Make Carini a stage: help us organize cultural events in the most suggestive locations of our city.

The Accademia Musicale Mediterranea in Carini (Palermo, Italy) is a self-financing multifunctional center that doesn’t benefit from public funding. We want to make our dream of Carini Piazza D’Arte come true. This project was conceived in 2014 and its goal is the rebirth of some of the most important and beautiful places in Carini, that have been neglected and not promoted.

Our exhibits, concerts, music contests, shows, recitals and workshops have highlighted a different location each time making it the stage of our events: the well known Castello di Carini or the less known but very fascinating Chiesa degli Agonizzanti, the Chiostro dei Carmelitani and the Piazza delle Vittorie, the Totuccio Aiello Theatre rather than the Baglio al Mare and many other locations have hosted the events organized by the Accademia and thus they have been enjoyed by the community with great emotional participation.

The purpose of Carini Piazza D’Arte is to continue on this path to initiate an agenda of cultural and musical events 2016 that turns the spotlight on the monuments of our city, especially on the less known and sometimes forgotten. One of our goals is to organize a Masterclass featuring international artists who are fully available to cooperate with us so as to enhance our agenda. Thanks to our initiative, the “Carinesi” discovered again churches, plazas and landscapes that had faded into obscurity until not long ago. The great response to our project encourages us to never give up and to keep believing in the opportunity to reach our long term goals.


WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

Despite the financial straits, this year we succeeded in hitting some targets of Carini Piazza D’Arte, especially thanks to the willpower and to the dedication of the young local musicians, of the teachers, of the students and of all of those who embraced our cause with passion. The current lack of assets might force us to suspend the project. This is why even a little donation can help us make our dream in music come true.

Thanking you in advance, we suggest you to read more about us.


THE ACCADEMIA MUSICALE MEDITERRANEA

Music as integration and solidarity, as culture , as individual and professional enrichment: these are the foundations of our mission.

The core of our academy lies in the courses held by international and national teachers for children and teenagers, in the masterclasses and workshops.

The work of the group that leads the Academy aims for a qualified classical and modern musical education in order to increase the student’s creative, artistic and professional growth.

We support the concept of education for everyone, for who is talented in despite of one’s economic possibility.

Our events, concerts, contests and exhibitions have always taken place in the local community with the ambition to be a center of musical excellence in all the Mediterranean.

In addition, we want to present our institutions: The Mediterranean Jazz Orchestra and The White Voices Choir.


The Mediterrean Jazz Orchestra

The Mediterranean Jazz Orchestra born in 2014 is the main instrumental band of the A. M. M. It is composed of 18 musicians, with the collaboration of other music sections including the presence of important popular jazz musicians. The debut on July, 5 2015 at the Chiostro of San Vincenzo in Carini was conducted by Roberto Basile, the present director and music responsible of the MJO and member of the A.M.M. The Orchestra’s aim is to spread special projects and perform its own original works.


The White Voices Choir

The White Voices Choir born in March 2011 is composed of 40 children selected in all the schools in Carini. Its program directed by the M° Maura Aresu is based on meetings centered in the history of music, singing and repertoire. It’s considered as an excellent opportunity in the process of cultural and musical development. In these years the choir participated to many events non only in Carini, but in Palermo at the Teatro Politeama “Giuseppe Garibaldi”, in Caccamo at the Duomo, in Noto and in Lipari.

story:
About Studio Liz

Studio Liz is a traveling art studio. Each class and party is unique, every place brings different inspiration and the people a different vision to each project or painting. The main goal of Studio Liz is to offer art classes at a lower cost without losing the richness of the experience. When resources allow we like to give free classes, so people who would normally not be able to participate have the opportunity to express themselves artistically. 

About the Owner and Artist

My name is Liz and I'm an artist and a teacher among other things. :)  I want to spread the chance for others to express themselves through art. I find that it is both inspiring, fulfilling, and therapeutic to create art. Sharing that experience with others makes me so happy. Everyone deserves the opportunity to create and express.

By supporting me and this campaign, you are giving others a chance to explore art, to create, and to spread a little joy. You are allowing others to expand their horizons and try new things.

What Studio Liz Needs Help with..

Studio Liz is still relatively new and getting started, it is also geared towards lower cost classes and free classes, so there aren't a lot of resources all the time to support this work.

  • Studio Liz is looking to raise $3000
The $3000 is going toward getting a folding tables and stools. It will also buy supplies for classes ranging from crafty to painting (think paint, new brushes, beads, string, scissors, etc.)  And a drying rack for wet paintings. Studio Liz is a strictly traveling business so there are space rental fees in order to use certain spaces. Other things we need are better storage containers and water coolers for transporting supplies and of course the water. 
 

Some of the perks that come with the support of Studio Liz are: 

  • $1-10 - A Shout Out &
                - A Personal Thank You Card
  • $11-25 - A Shout Out &
                   - A Personal Thank You Card &
                  - 3"x5" Print of your choice

                       - 18"x24" Watercolor Painting or
                       - 18"x24" Charcoal or Pastel Drawing or
                       - 16"x20" Pencil or Color Pencil Drawing or
                       - 12"x18" Marker Drawing or
                       - 24"x36" Acrylic Painting or
                       - 20"x24" Oil Painting

First tell me which reward you want for your prize bracket. Then for all of the rewards make sure you specify what subject you want. Photographs or pictures of the style, etc you want are incredibly helpful. Also be sure to tell me which one you want, for example: Black and White Pencil or Color Pencil.

Prints can be full color or black and white.

The Impact

With your help Studio Liz will be able to offer low cost or free classes to those who would otherwise not have the opportunity. Studio Liz is a traveling art class, we come to the people in the community and help them create some awesomeness. Your contributions and help will go directly towards the supplies needed to provide these classes. They will also help enrich the classes as well with better materials, supplies, and so on. Everyone deserves to be creative and to express themselves.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of the other ways you guys can help Studio Liz if you can't contribute is to spread the word! Word of mouth and social media are great (and easy) ways to help us reach our goal! Anything you can do to help is GREATLY appreciated. :)

We appreciate your time and support! Studio Liz wants to give more people a chance to be creative and to express themselves! We hope that you can help us with our dream: to spread the love of creating! Thank you!
story_txt:
About Studio LizStudio Liz is a traveling art studio. Each class and party is unique, every place brings different inspiration and the people a different vision to each project or painting. The main goal of Studio Liz is to offer art classes at a lower cost without losing the richness of the experience. When resources allow we like to give free classes, so people who would normally not be able to participate have the opportunity to express themselves artistically. About the Owner and ArtistMy name is Liz and I'm an artist and a teacher among other things. :)  I want to spread the chance for others to express themselves through art. I find that it is both inspiring, fulfilling, and therapeutic to create art. Sharing that experience with others makes me so happy. Everyone deserves the opportunity to create and express.By supporting me and this campaign, you are giving others a chance to explore art, to create, and to spread a little joy. You are allowing others to expand their horizons and try new things.What Studio Liz Needs Help with..Studio Liz is still relatively new and getting started, it is also geared towards lower cost classes and free classes, so there aren't a lot of resources all the time to support this work.Studio Liz is looking to raise $3000The $3000 is going toward getting a folding tables and stools. It will also buy supplies for classes ranging from crafty to painting (think paint, new brushes, beads, string, scissors, etc.)  And a drying rack for wet paintings. Studio Liz is a strictly traveling business so there are space rental fees in order to use certain spaces. Other things we need are better storage containers and water coolers for transporting supplies and of course the water.  Some of the perks that come with the support of Studio Liz are: 
$1-10 - A Shout Out &            - A Personal Thank You Card

$11-25 - A Shout Out &               - A Personal Thank You Card &              - 3"x5" Print of your choice

$76-100 - A Shout Out &                  - A Personal Thank You Card &                  - 8"x10" Print or                  - 8"x10" Watercolor or                  - 5"x7" Charcoal or Pastel Drawing or                  - 3"x5" Pencil or Color Pencil Drawing

$201-300 - A Shout Out &                     - A Personal Thank You Card &                     - 16"x20" Print or                     - 11"x14" Watercolor Painting or                     - 11"x14" Charcoal or Pastel Drawing or                     - 8"x10" Pencil or Color Pencil Drawing or                     - 5"x7" Marker Drawing or                     - 11"x14" Acrylic Painting or                     - 8"x10" Oil Painting
$301-400 - A Shout Out &                     - A Personal Thank You Card &                     - 2 8"x10" Prints or                     - 12"x18" Watercolor Painting or                     - 12"x18" Charcoal or Pastel Drawing or                     - 11"x14" Pencil or Color Pencil Drawing or                     - 8"x10" Marker Drawing or                     - 16"x20" Acrylic Painting or                     - 12"x16" Oil Painting

story:
La Ligue Nationale d’Improvisation, la seule et unique au monde, se retrouve aujourd’hui dans une situation financière précaire qui menace directement sa capacité d’accomplir sa mission….

La LNI a besoin de VOTRE appui dès maintenant…

En lui témoignant VOTRE amour et en contribuant à cette campagne, vous aiderez directement à stabiliser la situation de la LNI et pourrez même vous procurer des billets pour notre prochaine saison!

La Ligue Nationale d’Improvisation c’est :
-   un spectacle unique du monde…
-   près de 40 ans de créativité, de passion, d’émotions et d’innovation théâtrale qui ont touché des millions de spectateurs en salle et à la télé…
-   une icône de l’inventivité artistique et culturelle québécoise…
-   une inspiration éducative puissante pour la jeunesse...
-   une source de grande fierté pour les Québécois et Québécoises de toutes les générations…
-   un morceau important de NOTRE patrimoine…
-   un véritable trésor culturel, un espace de création unique au monde que chacun d’entre nous a le devoir de préserver!

Toute contribution est essentielle et bienvenue.

Merci de contribuer à préserver la LNI!

D'autres façons d'aider

Vous voulez aider d’une autre manière? Nous vous suggérons de parler de la campagne avec le plus de gens possible sur les réseaux sociaux et, pourquoi pas, de vous-même faire de l’impro. Il y a certainement une ligue riche de talents près de chez vous!


Gardons cet art en vie.

Calendrier des matchs LNI saison 2016

story:
The Deck

Tarot in Space! is an exhilarating and unique deck creator by animator Laura "LED" Douglass to tickle fancies and play with one of the most beautiful and enduring sets of archetype in human history. Tarot will never go out of style, so she's brought it into the Space Age with a truly unusual and deeply thought-out take on the characters and stories. 


The Artist

It's taken me over a year of juggling classes, two wonderful jobs, and this personal project but finally Tarot in Space! is ready to be released to the public. I'm passionate about bringing my love of story-telling and character creation to you, the Diviner. I want to help you explore new worlds and ideas, to entertain and perhaps even enlighten. With your help, dear Tarot lovers, this deck can be a true success. 


Where Does the Dough Go?

Everyone who donates $30 will receive a deck at the end of the campaign! Regardless of whether or not the goal is reached, you're going to get that deck, by golly. That's the whole point, to get the first run of these decks ordered and in your pretty Earthling hands. 

What about the extra money? Well, my friends, that will be going towards shipping and making sure I can eat and pay rent whilst I lovingly package your decks and send them off to you. But the goodies don't stop there, I love sending people fun stuff in the mail, it's truly a delightful feeling to receive something by post, no matter how small. So not only will ya'll be getting a deck, in a few months you'll get a follow up happy postcard from historic Savannah, GA! We have some truly campy gems in the postcard department here, folks, you won't want to miss this. 


Other Ways You Can Help

I understand, because I've been there. That $1 in your bank account? Please go buy yourself some Ramen with it. If you can't contribute coin please do share this with your friends, family, and kindly strangers. Also, 78 original illustrations take a toll on a gal, a little pep talk is always more than welcome <3

story:
Cascadia Serapeum is a fully collaborative large scale Art Experience being built across Vancouver, Seattle and Portland for Burning Man 2016. Inspired by the Library of Alexandria, the structure is classically Ancient Greek in style; however, a closer look reveals things are not what they seem. Inside will be walls of books, sculptures, things to play and interact with, a secret room, and more, all centered around a flaming chandelier. 


                                               

  

Once inside the secret room, one will encounter a podium atop which sits a giant glowing community book for all to inscribe.

                                                  

 

Just like the Library of Alexandria, part way through the week, the Serapeum will burn to the ground, leaving ruins behind.


                                             


In the center of these ruins, the podium and Community Book will sit, appearing unscathed by the fire. Beauty and community will continue on, altered but unmoving.


Our Team: 

              


Cascadia Serapeum pulls together the talents of many incredible and experienced artists. Members of the team have worked successfully on several on-playa projects in the past, including Fungully, Mount Infinity, Pier 2012, and Embrace. We fully believe that the best thing about these projects is the community that is created as they are built as well as experienced by others through play and exploration.  There is nothing greater than seeing someone interact with something you have helped to create and watching them be delighted, surprised, or moved by a vision.  


                                         We invite YOU to be a part of this experience!

There are many costs involved in the creation of a structure of this size. Building materials, hardware, paint, tool and space rentals, propane, transport (books are heavy), and so much more! The entire structure is estimated to cost $30,000, and we are hoping to raise half through this campaign. Please have a look at the perks we are offering and help if you're able.

We appreciate ALL the help we are offered! Whether you are able to offer a financial donation, donate books, come out to  help build, or just spread the word,

                                    



A special note to Canadians about the Perks offered! Please message us and we will try to send you the perk based on dollar at par.


                                           Oh, and we will not be burning any books.. 


Pics of some Perks:

story:
What is it?

FAR HORIZONS is a FREE monthly eMagazine, brought about from a simple idea to let unpublished, thinly published and  self-published writers and artists showcase their work to the World.

The first issue (no. 1 April 2014) was released on the 17th of April, 2014.

Far Horizons is only possible due to the hard work of a small group of volunteers. 

  • Far Horizons staff include self-published and trad published writers, as well as professionally qualified editors and proofreaders.
  • Our vision is to help new voices break out.
  • Imagine if we could pay our contributors too! 
  • If we can generate money from our anthologies then we can continue to keep the magazine as free and also reward people for contributing.
We have created three new anthologies with published and unpublished authors, from an open submissions period, and now we want to introduce them to the world:
Former Heroes

Former Heroes includes stories by David Gullen, Gaie Sebold, Andrew Goodman, Jim King, Kate Charles, Peter Sutton and Sara Jayne Townsend.
Have you ever wondered what happens to heroes once they stop being heroes? Then you need to read this book to see how real life heroes, heroic buildings, starfarers and super heroes cope with no longer being heroes.
Forever Hungry


Do like brains? Do you like munching into their gooey goodness, do you salivate at the thought of getting your hands deep inside the cranium and stuffing that grey matter into your ever-chomping jaw? Do you, in fact, like Braaaains!? If so then this book is for you. Over 20 stories of the shambling undead for your pleasure.
Fantastically Horny

Do you want your erotica to explore new worlds and new species? Do you want to read sexy sci-fi  or fantasy with added, er fantasy? Then this book is for you, a collection of tales to titillate and tease. Find out what those aliens, robots, dragons and centaurs get up to in the bedroom.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Consider this campaign a pre-order for the books we will be launching with. 
  • We want to make these books the best we can make them but our top priority is to publish them. 
We are looking for money to:

  • Publish anthologies, which we will then sell to raise money to pay contributors.
  • To pay the staff who have worked hard for only the reward of helping new writers.
  • To pay our artists, typesetter, editors and most of all the writers - there is nothing quite like the feeling of being paid for a piece of writing, and we'd like to make that dream come true for new writers.
  • Do you like Zombies? Then pledge for Forever Hungry.
  • Do you sexy tales? Then pledge for Fantastically Horny.
  • Ever wonder what happens to heroes when they stop being heroes? Then pledge for Former Heroes.
  • We'll be using IngramSpark and need a minimum amount to pay for overheads like ISBNs and fees.
  • Our next priority is paying our contributors equally.
  • Our next priority after those two is paying the staff - artists, editors etc.
  • If we make more money than we expect then we will invest in future books and use in paying for contributors to the magazine.

The Impact

Whilst it may now be easier to get your work out into the world with self-publishing, it can be hard to get it discovered. And even harder to make that next step and sell your work to a paying market, or even get a publishing deal.

Several of the authors that have had their work in the pages of Far Horizons have done just that. We can't promise success but we can help a writer improve their craft and give them vital editorial feedback.

  • You'll be helping us support new writers.
  • You'll be getting great stories and art.
  • You'll help us build a sustainable product and brand.
  • We are two years old as of April 2016 and feel ready to expand, please help us to do so!

Risks & Challenges

We have done our homework and hope to not run into problems, but we're fairly new in making books. We have a lot of experience on hitting deadlines though - you have to be to do a monthly magazine! But going via a publishing platform like IngramSpark will be a learning experience. However we have the art, we have the edited stories, we have the enthusiasm and creativity. We can make it happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute then please help us spread the word. Tell any writers you know, even if they are absolute beginners and aspirants, tell your friends, family, work colleagues or random passers-by in the streets. Let's help create something valuable, a place that writers can bring their dreams and find the help they need to make them come true!

story:
WHAT
Formations of my Shadow  is an art show at LP Gallery located in Long Island City, NY. The show will consist of works ranging from paintings and drawings to small metal works. Our work is a personal extension that can often feel like a shadow. Whether it be through a visual commentary on urban neighborhoods, memories, emotions or a work process, our work dares to challenge its relationship with one another to produce a new conversation.

WHY
Since we are recent college graduates, we are looking for as many ways as possible to show our work. We need as much help as we can get! We appreciate any donations and we are very grateful for your support! The funding will be used for renting the gallery space and installation. 

WHEN
The exhibition will take place from April 26th to May 7th. We hope to see you there!

THE ARTISTS

- David Bransfield: http://www.davidbransfield.com

Give&Take  100 x 67'' Oil on Canvas


- Jeanne Jalandoni: www.cargocollective.com/jeannefjalandoni

The Pink Horse  42 x 46'' Oil on Canvas


- Alyssa Steiger: www.alyssasteiger.com 

Untitled(Gold)  10 x 10'' Gold Leaf and Pen on Penal


- Chuang Yu: www.yuchuangjewelry.com 

Family  3 x 3'' (individual) Metal sculptures and Audio Installation
story_txt: WHATFormations of my Shadow  is an art show at LP Gallery located in Long Island City, NY. The show will consist of works ranging from paintings and drawings to small metal works. Our work is a personal extension that can often feel like a shadow. Whether it be through a visual commentary on urban neighborhoods, memories, emotions or a work process, our work dares to challenge its relationship with one another to produce a new conversation.WHYSince we are recent college graduates, we are looking for as many ways as possible to show our work. We need as much help as we can get! We appreciate any donations and we are very grateful for your support! The funding will be used for renting the gallery space and installation. WHENThe exhibition will take place from April 26th to May 7th. We hope to see you there!THE ARTISTS- David Bransfield: http://www.davidbransfield.comGive&Take  100 x 67'' Oil on Canvas- Jeanne Jalandoni: www.cargocollective.com/jeannefjalandoniThe Pink Horse  42 x 46'' Oil on Canvas- Alyssa Steiger: www.alyssasteiger.com Untitled(Gold)  10 x 10'' Gold Leaf and Pen on Penal- Chuang Yu: www.yuchuangjewelry.com Family  3 x 3'' (individual) Metal sculptures and Audio Installation

story:
Gabriel Baeza is an 19 year old violin virtuoso. He was born in New York City and moved to Puerto Rico when he was two years old. A violin prodigy, he began to play the violin when he was three years old.

 His mother, Loida Fernandez Rivera, helped him practice all through his childhood and taught him music theory and solfege, which she is currently a professor of. 

At thirteen years old, he made his debut with the Puerto Rico Symphony Orchestra; under the tutelage of Dr. Francisco Cabán. The concert was conducted by Roselin Pabon. 

Gabriel now studies at Bard College where he he has perfomed under Leon Botstein of the American Symphony Orchestra, cellist Luis Garcia-Renart and violinist Daniel Phillips. 

Gabriel has been lent a violin that he feels is the violin he can use most effectively. An instrument is a deeply personal thing and a connection between the performer and the instrument is critical.

Gabriel would like to purchase this violin but does not have the resources to do so. The violin is owned by a Bard professor of Music willing to sell it at the bargain price of $40,000. It is a 1750 Landolfi violin. The Landolfi family made violins around the same time as the Stadivari and the Guarneri families. To give some perspective, a Guarneri violin was recently sold for sixteen million dollars and was anonymously donated to Anne Akiko Meyers on loan to her for the rest of her life.

This story inspired Gabriel to try to buy the violin. Understanding that time is short he understands the long odds - but does not want to part with this violin without doing all that he can to keep it.

story:
Update 3/22/16:

I extended my campaign 10 days from the original end date so that it would not end the same day I was leaving for my workshop. Thank you everyone for your support - first workshop down! I have raised two bowls and started forging a couple of spoons. Exciting things on the way!

Update 3/2/16:

Only 15 days left in the campaign, and until I fly out to my first workshop! I will be learning how to raise vessels, solder large pieces of metal, and other object-making techniques. Thank you for all of your help in making this happen!

Update 2/11/16:

I have secured my spot in workshop #1!

Thank you to everyone who has contributed! I am excited to start working on your jewelry this weekend.


My name is Jessi and I make jewelry!

Metalsmithing and jewelry started as a way to keep my hands busy and make shiny things in the process. It has since evolved into something more: a business, a passion, and a way to connect with others. I began teaching my first beginner metalsmithing classes in November and I am hooked.

My own metalsmithing education is fairly limited and many things I have taught myself. I have reached a point where I need to focus and expand my tool box of skills. I have determined that the most efficient way to learn these skills is to learn from other metalsmiths and artists that have mastered their crafts. My goal for 2016 is to take 3 short, intensive workshops at jewelry specific and craft schools around the United States. Because I work a full time job that is separate from jewelry, I am limited to workshops and classes I can take time off of work to attend.

The Details

My goal is to gain skills in metalsmithing: forging, forming, raising, and sinking. I also want to learn the basics of creating hollowware out of metals, and lastly enameling both by torch and by kiln. I have chosen three specific workshops to meet these goals, but total costs will be upwards of $3500 with travel, lodging, and tuition.

The Impact

This is an important step in my ultimate goal to become an educator myself and spread the love of metal around!

If you would like to help, each donation will bring me closer to achieving my goal! Every donation of $25 and up will receive a piece of handmade jewelry as my thanks.

If I surpass my goal, all excess money will go towards future educational pursuits. If I don't reach my goal, any and all donations will help relieve the financial burden I am taking on.

Thank you for any and all help as I strike off on these new adventures!


Some examples of the various perks (note: due to the handmade nature of my jewelry, every piece is a little different!):

Please make sure to check out the gallery for more images of past work!

story:
WHO ARE WE?

  We're artists. We're passionate about supporting & promoting local art and handcrafted products. Our backgrounds are in art/jewelry, education, retail and online marketing. 

WHAT ARE WE?

  We are THE COLLECTIVE Art Market - a retail space selling local art and handmade products, with classroom/communal studio/demonstration space.

WHAT DO WE NEED

$10,000 CAD.

WHY DO WE NEED IT?

We need help with start up costs. Specifically, we need:

Classroom set up:

- 3 6' tables - $180.00

-  15 folding chairs - $480.00

- 40" or larger tv with USB - $500.00

- full motion tv wall stand - $200.00

- 6 easels and stools - $800.00

- art supplies - $1000.00

-materials for our mobile booth (for our initial Synergy Credit Union pop-up and for display in our store)- $250.00

-front desk - $100.00

-Moneris debit machine, iPad, iPad holder, cash drawer, thermal receipt printer, and point of sale app to accept credit card, debit and cash payments - $1600.00

-display units and shelving - $1800.00

-advertising - $1000.00

- signage - $500.00

-rent, utilities and insurance for two months to get us started - $2,000


WHAT ARE THE PERKS?

Swag - art, jewelry, t-shirts, art classes, exclusive silver collector keychains.

Fun - an invitation to our VIP sneak peek party.

You will be supporting the arts, helping to revitalize our downtown, creating an arts community and a tourist destination. 


WE DID OUR RESEARCH.

We surveyed our community about a local art retail space. The results were more than encouraging. 

We decided to start small - as a pop-up kiosk store at the new Synergy Credit Union building from March 14th - 31st.

We chose downtown for our location for 6 weeks in April and May. It's the heart of our city and the perfect place for an arts community. We are working with a building owner to fill an empty downtown space.

With your help, we can become a permanent downtown arts community.

The Big Picture includes both communal and private artist studio space to rent. It includes well stocked classroom spaces for different mediums.

If we surpass our campaign goal, awesome!! More funds mean that we are closer to the artist/maker community we envision.

If you can support our campaign by pledging funds, we THANK YOU from the bottoms of our hearts.

If you would like to support our campaign but cannot pledge funds at this time, you can still help! Please spread the word about us, share our campaign and make comments on our campaign so that more people see it.

 We truly believe that this venture will be an amazing success and we want you to be a part of it!
