story:
Soy Rafael Vargas Bernard, artista digital de Puerto Rico

Mi proyecto formará parte de una selección de artistas puertorriqueños que presentan su punto de vista sobre el panorama socio-político contemporáneo del territorio de Puerto Rico con relación a Estados Unidos y sobre asuntos que afectan a la región del Caribe.

Documentaré a tres generaciones de puertorriqueños en Wynwood

A través de Trío Little San Juan quiero colaborar con personas de tres generaciones, miembros de la comunidad puertorriqueña de Little San Juan en Wynwood, Miami. Quiero conocer las ideas y sentimientos de los Baby Boomers, la Generación X y los Millennials acerca del pasado, presente y futuro de la cultura boricua en Wynwood.  Emplearé fotografías, vídeos, sonidos y cualquier objeto o memorabilia que surja del proceso de residencia.

"Wynwood is not just the walls, it's also the people"

Más allá de las famosas paredes que han hecho reconocible a esta comunidad de Miami, quiero propiciar la interacción social a través de medios visuales y sonoros con los que cualquier persona pueda explorar y manipular la experiencia puertorriqueña de tres generaciones.

La evidencia de mi labor artística para tu colección de arte

Tu contribución para el financiamiento de mi estadía en Miami te permitirá adquirir piezas de arte contemporáneo que evidencian la conceptualización, desarrollo y materialización final del trabajo de Rafael Vargas Bernard que la residencia artística hará posible.

Escoge una o varias de las piezas que ofrezco a través de esta página y obtendrás las primicias de mi obra inédita. 

Ayúdame a brincar el charco

Para cumplir con los costos de vida de una estadía saludable y productiva en Miami necesitaré unos $6,000 que cubrirán gastos desde septiembre hasta diciembre de 2017. 

Aporta a esta iniciativa de trabajo creativo y documentación histórica y será tuya una parte del fruto este esfuerzo conjunto. 

Copia y riega este enlace entre colegas, clientes y amigos del arte en general:
https://igg.me/at/rafapamiami

_____________________________________________________________________________

I’m Rafael Vargas Bernard, digital artist from Puerto Rico

Clocktower Productions and Mana Contemporary selected my project proposal Trío Little San Juan to participate in their three-month residency program in Miami, Florida. The program is dedicated to the Puerto Rican arts community, both on the island and across the diaspora. My project will be part of a selection of Puerto Rican artists who present their view on Puerto Rico’s "contemporary social-political landscape—issues facing both the territory in relation to the U.S. and those of the Caribbean at large."

Support from Clocktower-Mana includes round-trip plane tickets, workshop and housing facilities, but to be able to pay for food and other personal expenses I’m counting on the presale of my artwork pieces, designed and produced for contributors to this campaign and for art collectors who have previously supported my art production.

I will be documenting three generations of Puerto Ricans in Wynwood

I want to collaborate with three generations of people from Little San Juan, the Puerto Rican community in Wynwood, Miami.

I want to learn about the ideas and sentiments of Puerto Rican Baby Boomers, GenXers and Millennials associated to the past, present and future of Puerto Rican culture in Wynwood. I will use photographs, videos, sounds and any object or memorabilia that could emerge during the residency.

"Wynwood is not just the walls, it's also the people"

Beyond the famous Wynwood Walls that now make recognizable this community in Miami, I want to provide social interactions through visual and sound media for anyone to explore and manipulate the Puerto Rican experiences of three generations.

Add the evidence of my artistic labor to your art collection

Your contribution to financing my livelyhood during my stay in Miami can put in your hands objects of contemporary art that embody the design, production and final execution of Rafael Vargas Bernard’s creative endeavors that will be nurtured by his upcoming artist residency.

Select one or more pieces of art available from this page and you will get the novelties of my unpublished work.

Help me jump across the sea

To meet the living costs of a healthy and productive journey in Miami I will need around $6000 that will cover expenses from September to December 2017.

You can now support this creative and historical documentation enterprise and get the fruits of our joint effort.

Copy and share this link among colleagues, clients and friends of the arts in general:
https://igg.me/at/rafapamiami

PERKS

$10
Atlantic Pond

I will show you my gratitude on social media.

Item included:

  • Shout-out share on social media
     

$25
Boricua (Puerto Rican) in Wynwood

One (1) of three collectible prints (8” x 10” size)—handcrafted original artwork created as a result of my artist residence in Miami.

Item included:

  • Handcrafted Original Print
     

$50
Miami Bass

Digital download (1) of sound production result of the project in Miami and one (1) of three collectible prints (8” x 10” size)

Items included:

  • Handcrafted Original Print
  • Digital Download
     

$75
Trio Little San Juan

Three (3) collectible prints (8” x 10” size) and digital download (1) of a sound production result of the project in Miami.

Items included:

  • Handcrafted Original Prints (3)
  • Digital download


$100
Visible Spectrum

One (1) electroacoustic art object that reads colors and convert them to audio frequencies, designed and programmed by Rafael Vargas Bernard.

Item included:

  • Electroacoustic Art Object
     

$200
Give it All You Got

One digital download (1) of the sound production and three (3) collectible prints (8” x 10” size) resulted from residency project in Miami. One (1) electroacoustic art object, designed and programmed by Rafael Vargas Bernard. And a little surprise.

Items included:

  • Handcrafted Original Print
  • Digital Download
  • Electroacoustic Art Object
  • Surprise Item
     

$500
Miami Bitch

I’ll register your name inside the silhouette of the fusioned geographies of Puerto Rico and U.S.A. tattooed on a part of my body.

Item included:

  • Your Name Tattooed On My Body.


$800
Here Is The Evidence I

One (1) acoustic & interactive painting (12” x 12” x 3” size) designed by Rafael Vargas Bernard, product of the artist residence project in Miami.

Item included:

  • Acoustic & Interactive Painting
     

$1000
Here Is The Evidence II

One (1) acoustic & interactive sculpture (12” x 12” x 12” size) designed by Rafael Vargas Bernard, product of the artist residence in Miami.

Item included:

  • Acoustic & Interactive Sculpture


$1800
Here Is The Evidence III

One (1) acoustic & interactive painting (24” x 24” x 3” size) designed by Rafael Vargas Bernard, product of the artist residence in Miami.

Item included:

  • Acoustic & Interactive Painting


$2000
Here Is The Evidence IV

One (1) acoustic & interactive sculpture (24” x 24” x 24” size) designed by Rafael Vargas Bernard, product of the artist residence in Miami.

Item included:

  • Acoustic & Interactive Sculpture

story:
Beginning in 2011, South Bay Burners have brought honoraria art installations to Black Rock City: 
2011’s Laptop Man
2012’s Valley of Heart’s Delight
2013’s Mission Umbrae
2014’s Occidental Oasis
2015’s Hare Today, Gone Tomorrow

In 2017, we’re bringing another community art installation to Black Rock City, and we invite everyone to participate and

ENJOY THE BURN!

What We Need & What You Get

This year, we didn't get an honorarium art grant.  So we need your help more than ever!  We have already bought some of the lumber we need, and are on Build Day #12 already.  But we could really use your help to fund this project.  pARTicipate, and come watch it burn with us!

If we don't reach our goal, this will be an out-of-pocket project.  We could really use your help!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, you can still join us with your sweat equity.  Come help us build during the summer, or help us on-playa with Burn Day and clean-up!  Write to southbay@burningman.org and let us know how you'd like to be involved.

story:
I am Natsuko Matsumura. I am a multimedia artist focusing especially on photography and printmaking in New York City. I have been working on this street photography project for 3 years and I have given a chance to showcase this project from April 14th to April 19th at Tenri Gallery in New York. In order to do a successful exhibition, I need to print the photos, frame them, pay for the promotion and gallery fees. If you can contribute even a little amount to make this happen, I would appreciate it. 

こんにちは。ニューヨクをベースに活動をしているマルチメディアアーティストの松村ナツコです。今回３年間のストリートフォトプロジェクトをニューヨークの天理ギャラリーで発表することとなりました。皆様のご支援とともにこの個展を成功させるよう、こちらのサイトで寄付を募っています。できるだけ多くの方に私が感じたニューヨークを感じ、経験していただけたら幸いと思っております。ぜひ個展開催のプロジェクトにご支援いただけますようどうぞよろしくお願いいたします。

Reflection - Things to Feel from the Distance

天理ギャラリー：43A West 13th Street, New York, NY 10011

展示：　　　　　２０１８年４月１４日〜４月１９日

レセプション：　２０１８年４月１７日（火）７時〜９時

http://www.tenri.org

 

 

Why

Why do I create art and do street photography?

 To create and express the feeling the way I feel it so that people stop and think about their feelings and observe them from the different perspective.

 

There are many ways to express and communicate your feelings. Art is my strongest communication tool. 

 
 

 

I believe that the physicality of using films and processing and printing by my own hands brings my emotions into the fine prints the most. My images call for the self-awareness as well as the social awareness of human existence in a lonely way. I have become interested in taking pictures of people on the street from the distance to capture their natural behaviors and the feeling of separation and observation.

Coming from Japan where it has traditions and rules, I have been struggling to deal with my nationality and tradition versus being free in a different country and culture especially in the mixed cultures of New York City. I reflect this uneasy feeling in my current 3-year project of street photography. I sense that there are many people in this country or elsewhere feel the same way I feel. I would like to bring that awareness to the public.

 

ユダヤ人を被写体としているこのプロジェクトは、ユダヤ人の伝統と規則のある文化と日本の似たような文化を照らし合わせ、ニューヨークのような自由な場所で自分のアイデンティティーを外から見て、模索、葛藤している“フィーリング”を映し出しています。

作品はどこかノスタルジックでさみしい感じがします。人を客観的に遠くから観察して、言葉の違いや人種の違い、考え方の違いでコミュニケーションしづらく中に入っていけないもどかしさを表現しています。何かを欲しているが手に入らないもどかしさや、自由と規律の中での葛藤を現実であって夢の中のシーンのように、距離を置いてみている感じです。移民の多いニューヨーク、デジタル社会で疎外感を感じるなど、同じように感じている人々に、ちょっと立ち止まって自分の感情と照らし合わせていただける機会を届る作品展にしたいと思います。

そのほか、大学で１年間とったエッチングの授業に惹かれ、今は版画の制作もしています。写真も版画（エッチング）も実際に自分の手でプリントをすることにより、作り手の気持ちが作品に現れます。ただ現実にそこにあるものを移すというだけでもなく、アングルが良いとか、被写体が良いとかいうだけでもなく、実際に自分の気持ちを込めて、自分が感じた気持ちがそのプロセスを通して現れるのだと思います。そのため、写真は全てフィルムを使用しています。

 

 

Please visit my website to know me more!

http://www.natsukomatsumura.com

More images on Instagram. Please follow me!

https://www.instagram.com/lunasummerny/

 

 

These are the breakdown 

The part of the cost I need to organize the exhibition

frames                                 $3500  

Return item, shipping       $500 

 

What you get

In return, I have various perks to offer and extend an invitation to my opening reception so you can enjoy what your contribution has gone towards.

If you don't need any perks, you can contribute any amount you want by clicking the pink button "back it" at the very top of this site. Thank you!

Other Ways You Can Help

 The more people that support the campaign the better, so please tell your art-loving and curious friends. And any money raised here, beyond the goal, and once the perks have been fulfilled, I can create more great works and show them to you the next time.
story_txt:
I am Natsuko Matsumura. I am a multimedia artist focusing especially on photography and printmaking in New York City. I have been working on this street photography project for 3 years and I have given a chance to showcase this project from April 14th to April 19th at Tenri Gallery in New York. In order to do a successful exhibition, I need to print the photos, frame them, pay for the promotion and gallery fees. If you can contribute even a little amount to make this happen, I would appreciate it.

The part of the cost I need to organize the exhibition
frames                                 $3500  
Return item, shipping       $500 
 
What you get
In return, I have various perks to offer and extend an invitation to my opening reception so you can enjoy what your contribution has gone towards.
If you don't need any perks, you can contribute any amount you want by clicking the pink button "back it" at the very top of this site. Thank you!


Other Ways You Can Help
 The more people that support the campaign the better, so please tell your art-loving and curious friends. And any money raised here, beyond the goal, and once the perks have been fulfilled, I can create more great works and show them to you the next time.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Jamie Whitlow, I am a visual artist who has been creating art installations and murals for music festivals around the United States for the past four years.

The most recent project that I have been traveling with is named The Platonic Solids. The piece consists of five 5'-7' 3-dimensional geometric structures, created from PVC pipe and painted with light-reactive paint to make them glow in the dark. Building and displaying The Platonic Solids has been an extremely joyful and successful endeavor.

In observing the way that people interact with this installation, I have noticed that the nature of these shapes and the way they are built seem to call people to want to climb them. Because PVC is not a sustainable enough material to support this, I plan to recreate this project with steel, making each of the five shapes sturdy and large enough for people to climb and play on.

Successfully funding and building this project can help facilitate wonderful experiences to those who attend music festivals, by adding both aesthetic with this visual piece, and experience with its interactivity.

What We Need & What You Get

The total funding goal for this campaign is $2,500. This funding will go towards the following:

1. Makerspace Membership.

2. Steel. (Over 400 feet!)

3. Primer and light reactive spray paint.

4. Hardware- nuts, bolts, washers.

5. Transportation costs

Rewards for your donation!

$20 or more:

Your choice of one 11"x17" matte cardstock art print of any of my paintings. (Full collection at www.jamiewhitlowart.com)

$50 or more:

Choice of 18"x24" banner poster of paintings "Stripped Bare" or "A Penny For My Thoughts."

$100 or more:

12"x12" original commissioned canvas painting. Your choice of style/subject matter!

$250 or more:

18"x24" original commissioned canvas painting. Your choice of style/subject matter!

$500 or more:

36"x48" original commissioned canvas painting. Your choice of style/subject matter!

If the full goal of $2,500 is not reached within the 30 day campaign, the money raised will still go towards makerspace membership and materials.

The Impact

I truly feel as if creating art for others is not only my dream, but my purpose in life. Since I began building interactive installations two years ago, I have witnessed first hand the facilitation of joy and togetherness that they bring to festivals. Music festivals have been expanding to include more and more visual and interactive art. This project will help me build an even larger and more interactive piece than ever before, and continue following my passion of creating things that facilitate happiness.

Risks & Challenges

Over the past few years, I have built some wonderful professional relationships with various festivals around the country. I have high hopes that I will return to many of these festivals in the upcoming season, specifically with this new and improved project.

While this is true, the process of displaying installations at festivals still requires an application process. I have spent the past several weeks applying and e-mailing over 50 festivals coming up in 2018. Although there are no specific events that I currently have booked with this project, I am currently waiting to hear back from all of these applications and contacts I have reached out to!

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute to funding? No problem! You can still help! Share this campaign with your friends on social media! My links to tag are as follows:

www.jamiewhitlowart.com

www.facebook.com/theartofjamiewhitlow

www.instagram.com/theartofjamiewhitlow

story:
How we got started

In the world of photography and photographic art projects, there is an established norm - a norm which extends to all areas of photographic art involving people. That norm is, as it often is in our society, a norm based on thinness. Back in 2013, I posted an off-hand Facebook status confronting the fact that there were not enough avenues for fat models, especially when it came to nude photo shoots. The response from my community?

"Then do it."


It was that simple. If the art didn't exist, then make it yourself. 


3 years later and the Fat Naked Art Project has two blogs, a facebook page, and has traveled from our homebase in North Carolina up north to New York and plans to go all over the country with the help and support of our community worldwide!

What We Need & What You Get

We need:

          - Venues (such as local studios to shoot at)

          - Lodging

          - Food

          - Transportation

          - Coverage for incidentals


What You Get

The Fat Naked Art Project prides itself on being a project that shoots fat and diverse bodies, and doing so at no cost to the models that pose for us. What this means for you is that we cannot do this without your help and support! In exchange, we create art that aims to make the invisible visible. Exposure breeds tolerance breeds love. We aim to make the world more body positive, one positive body at a time.


We are working on producing prints that we will give to donors at certain donation intervals and the more success we find with this campaign the more we would be able to and want to have an FNAP shoot in your city! If you donate $10 or more, I'll send you a hand written Thank You note on a post card from the city we're traveling to! 


The Impact

Studies show that exposure to body diversity- surprise!- creates more tolerance for diverse bodies. Our goal is to photograph fat bodies of all kinds, but we can't do it without your help! 

In the US, eating disorders and body image issues have been on the rise steadily for decades. Young children are being hospitalized and fat children and teens are are the greatest risk of developing an eating disorder or disordered eating. Luckily, with the spread of body positivity through online information, communities, and projects like this one, I see so many young people at a place that I didn't find until only a few years ago.

The impact of body positive projects like this one are something you can see in your every day life as people begin to accept and love their bodies and become happier people.

Risks & Challenges

RISKS: there's a greater than 50% chance you will love your body more! 

In all seriousness though, challenges are obviously the cost of taking on a project like this. In addition, we strive for as much diversity as possible, which is why traveling is so important- finding people all over the country who represent different walks of life! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. Tumblr, twitter, facebook.. whatever way in which you can spread the word, help us do so!
  • Remember that Indiegogo has share tools that you can use!

story:
My Story

“The mountain is a fold of shadow in the overexposed Andalusian sky. It rises up out of the sea like an ancient beast, the highest point overlooking the entire Mediterranean rim yet it remains hidden, invisible, a lost kingdom cloaked behind its shadow, inside a veil of magic.“

Excerpt from “The Shoulder of God” by Rafael Anderson

In 2012 I moved to the Alpujarra, a remote, mountainous region which was the last stronghold of the Muslims in southern Spain in 1492. I discovered that the legacy of the Muslims’ 800-year civilisation in al-Andalus (Andalusia) includes not only architectural monuments and scholarly achievements, but the most advanced knowledge of its time in farming land and raising livestock.

Mulhacén, the highest mountain in mainland Spain, named after Moulay Abul-Hasan Ali, a 15th century Muslim king of Granada

 

In reading about the history of the region, I came across an important encyclopaedic book about agriculture written in the 12th century by a Muslim scholar called Ibn al-‘Awwām al-Ishbili of Seville. The book described methods that would be used for centuries to follow, some right up until today.

I began to see a direct link between the knowledge and methods of our ancestors in farming as exists today in the Alpujarra mountains. Not only is farming and livestock raising still done in the traditional ways, but the names of the systems for irrigation and water management, and the names of much of the produce are the same as those used hundreds of years ago.

What could have been a boring subject suddenly became fascinating!

 

An ancient Muslim treatise on agriculture in Arabic

 

A quote from the 12th century book in Andalusi Arabic script by Ian Abdallateef Whiteman

 

As a photographer, I wanted to visually record my explorations and discoveries from an artistic perspective, not a documentary one. I wasn’t interesting in farming as such, but I was interested in things that related to it. I began to weave a thread through my experiences, the legacy of the Muslims in farming and some of the produce of today. I found that my photographs were being influenced by the style of the still-life paintings of the Spanish masters with their use of shadows and light on relatively simple compositions.

Slowly a project began to take shape. It evolved over time and eventually, with the help of a few other people, a coherent body of work was completed. These books and photogravure prints are the result of that project.

 

“[This] photographic series is an extraordinary tribute to the Alpujarra region of southern Spain. The Moors who cultivated these lands in the Middle Ages built irrigation canals, terraced the mountainsides, bred sheep and planted orchards there. Now almost entirely forgotten, only the stone ruins scattered along the landscape and the persistent vegetation remains. Dajani photographs this legacy with a steward’s eye. The animal bones and fallen chestnuts, the centenarian olive trees, even the low-lying clouds become artifacts, each curated, revered, and carefully displayed as in a cabinet of wonders.”

Excerpt from “The Art of Filaha” by Collier Brown, (editor Od Review, 21st Editions)

 

 

The books & the prints

This project has been carefully compiled into two beautiful books of rich B&W photographs, magical stories and scripted Arabic quotes taken from the 12th century book on farming. Each book will be hand-bound with Japanese side-stitching. A limited number of 100 copies only will be made.

The photographic prints that accompany the special editions are unique, hand-crafted photogravure prints. Read below why these prints are so special.

Producing this work has been a labour of love with dedication and attention to detail to produce exquisite, hand-made rare objects where every element has been carefully considered. This makes the work special and quite a collectable thing.

 

Book details

• 38 B&W photographic plates and other images with stories and essays in both English and Spanish languages

• format landscape (horizontal), size 21x30 cm, approx.40 pages each book

(note: we are still in production so there may be minor changes from the pictures shown)

 

Why photogravure prints are so special

Photogravure printing is a rare and highly-skilled method of etching photographic images onto metal plates which originated in the 1870s.

For each of the prints included with these books, I used the bright Andalusian sun to burn a photographic image onto a UV-sensitive metal plate. The plate was processed and carefully inked and wiped by hand. Then, using a traditional etching press, the plate was pressed onto a sheet of art paper which had earlier been dampened with fresh spring water from the Sierra Nevada mountains. The result is a detailed print with a full tonal range from bright highlights to deep blacks, and a textural feel that is quite unlike any other type of photographic print.

As the prints are individually hand-crafted there are slight differences from one to another, due to the inking and wiping of the metal plates, the deckled edges of the paper, or other slight variations, resulting in each print being a unique object - even if ever so slightly.

Photogravure prints are very special. Few people have seen them and very few have actually held one in their own hands. Those who are lucky to have done so are always amazed by the quality and beauty of such an object of art.

 

Help to support this project

... by buying the books and a print, and by sharing this with friends and family who might be interested.

 

Your choices are...

Supporter €25

• support the project purely to help me produce this work. Your gift will be the satisfaction of knowing that you will have contributed to the production of wonderful stories and beautiful artwork

 

Book Edition €60

• the 2 books, personally signed, dated and numbered, presented in a custom-made art box

 

“Quince” Print Edition €195

[ no longer available ]

• the 2 books, personally signed, dated and numbered, presented in an elegant cloth-covered box

• 1 photogravure print, 1 of only 10 editions, signed, dated and numbered (verso/on the back), on archival art rag paper, approx. 21x30cm

• a print certificate of authenticity with your print title, edition number and date

 

“Walnuts” Print Edition €195

• the 2 books, personally signed, dated and numbered, presented in an elegant cloth-covered box

• 1 photogravure print (of only 10 editions), signed, dated and numbered (verso/on the back), on archival art rag paper, approx. 21x30cm

• a print certificate of authenticity with your print title, edition number and date

 

“Clouds” Print Edition €195

• the 2 books, personally signed, dated and numbered, presented in an elegant cloth-covered box

• 1 photogravure print (of only 10 editions), signed, dated and numbered (verso/on the back), on archival art rag paper, approx. 21x30cm

• a print certificate of authenticity with your print title, edition number and date

 

"Horns" Collector Edition €450

• the 2 books, personally signed, dated and numbered, presented in an elegant cloth-covered box

• 1 photogravure exhibition print (of only 5 editions), signed, dated and numbered (recto/on the front), on archival art rag paper, approx. 28x38cm (unframed)

• a print certificate of authenticity with your print title, number and date

 

"Olive Tree" Collector Edition €450

[ no longer available ]

• the 2 books, personally signed, dated and numbered, presented in an elegant cloth-covered box

• 1 photogravure exhibition print (of only 5 editions), signed, dated and numbered (recto/on the front), on archival art rag paper, approx. 28x38cm (unframed)

• a print certificate of authenticity with your print title, number and date

 

"Bread Oven" Collector Edition €450

• the 2 books, personally signed, dated and numbered, presented in an elegant cloth-covered box

• 1 photogravure exhibition print (of only 5 editions), signed, dated and numbered (recto/on the front), on archival art rag paper, approx. 28x38cm (unframed)

• a print certificate of authenticity with your print title, number and date

 

"Oranges" Collector Edition €450

• the 2 books, personally signed, dated and numbered, presented in an elegant cloth-covered box

• 1 photogravure exhibition print (of only 5 editions), signed, dated and numbered (recto/on the front), on archival art rag paper, approx. 28x38cm (unframed)

• a print certificate of authenticity with your print title, number and date

 

Photogravure Workshop €950

• a 2-day personal photogravure workshop in the artist’s farmhouse-studio in the beautiful countryside of Galicia, northern Spain (see photo of farm estate below)

• from digital image to final prints

•  suitable for any level, from a total novice to an experienced printer/photographer

• all art materials for production of up to 2 A4 metal-plates and unlimited prints

• workshop tailored to suit individual needs

• 2 days, 3 nights, full board (includes meals and accommodation in own en-suite room); travel and other expenses not included.

• option to extend visit &/or and bring partner for a proper holiday to enjoy many of the wonders of Galicia

• for further info, please contact via email

story_txt:
My Story“The mountain is a fold of shadow in the overexposed Andalusian sky. It rises up out of the sea like an ancient beast, the highest point overlooking the entire Mediterranean rim yet it remains hidden, invisible, a lost kingdom cloaked behind its shadow, inside a veil of magic.“Excerpt from “The Shoulder of God” by Rafael AndersonIn 2012 I moved to the Alpujarra, a remote, mountainous region which was the last stronghold of the Muslims in southern Spain in 1492. I discovered that the legacy of the Muslims’ 800-year civilisation in al-Andalus (Andalusia) includes not only architectural monuments and scholarly achievements, but the most advanced knowledge of its time in farming land and raising livestock.Mulhacén, the highest mountain in mainland Spain, named after Moulay Abul-Hasan Ali, a 15th century Muslim king of Granada In reading about the history of the region, I came across an important encyclopaedic book about agriculture written in the 12th century by a Muslim scholar called Ibn al-‘Awwām al-Ishbili of Seville. The book described methods that would be used for centuries to follow, some right up until today.I began to see a direct link between the knowledge and methods of our ancestors in farming as exists today in the Alpujarra mountains. Not only is farming and livestock raising still done in the traditional ways, but the names of the systems for irrigation and water management, and the names of much of the produce are the same as those used hundreds of years ago.What could have been a boring subject suddenly became fascinating! An ancient Muslim treatise on agriculture in Arabic A quote from the 12th century book in Andalusi Arabic script by Ian Abdallateef Whiteman As a photographer, I wanted to visually record my explorations and discoveries from an artistic perspective, not a documentary one. I wasn’t interesting in farming as such, but I was interested in things that related to it. I began to weave a thread through my experiences, the legacy of the Muslims in farming and some of the produce of today. I found that my photographs were being influenced by the style of the still-life paintings of the Spanish masters with their use of shadows and light on relatively simple compositions.Slowly a project began to take shape. It evolved over time and eventually, with the help of a few other people, a coherent body of work was completed. These books and photogravure prints are the result of that project. “[This] photographic series is an extraordinary tribute to the Alpujarra region of southern Spain. The Moors who cultivated these lands in the Middle Ages built irrigation canals, terraced the mountainsides, bred sheep and planted orchards there. Now almost entirely forgotten, only the stone ruins scattered along the landscape and the persistent vegetation remains. Dajani photographs this legacy with a steward’s eye. The animal bones and fallen chestnuts, the centenarian olive trees, even the low-lying clouds become artifacts, each curated, revered, and carefully displayed as in a cabinet of wonders.”Excerpt from “The Art of Filaha” by Collier Brown, (editor Od Review, 21st Editions)  The books & the printsThis project has been carefully compiled into two beautiful books of rich B&W photographs, magical stories and scripted Arabic quotes taken from the 12th century book on farming. Each book will be hand-bound with Japanese side-stitching. A limited number of 100 copies only will be made.The photographic prints that accompany the special editions are unique, hand-crafted photogravure prints. Read below why these prints are so special.Producing this work has been a labour of love with dedication and attention to detail to produce exquisite, hand-made rare objects where every element has been carefully considered. This makes the work special and quite a collectable thing. Book details• 38 B&W photographic plates and other images with stories and essays in both English and Spanish languages• format landscape (horizontal), size 21x30 cm, approx.40 pages each book(note: we are still in production so there may be minor changes from the pictures shown) Why photogravure prints are so specialPhotogravure printing is a rare and highly-skilled method of etching photographic images onto metal plates which originated in the 1870s.For each of the prints included with these books, I used the bright Andalusian sun to burn a photographic image onto a UV-sensitive metal plate. The plate was processed and carefully inked and wiped by hand. Then, using a traditional etching press, the plate was pressed onto a sheet of art paper which had earlier been dampened with fresh spring water from the Sierra Nevada mountains. The result is a detailed print with a full tonal range from bright highlights to deep blacks, and a textural feel that is quite unlike any other type of photographic print.As the prints are individually hand-crafted there are slight differences from one to another, due to the inking and wiping of the metal plates, the deckled edges of the paper, or other slight variations, resulting in each print being a unique object - even if ever so slightly.Photogravure prints are very special. Few people have seen them and very few have actually held one in their own hands. Those who are lucky to have done so are always amazed by the quality and beauty of such an object of art. Help to support this project ... by buying the books and a print, and by sharing this with friends and family who might be interested.  Your choices are...Supporter €25• support the project purely to help me produce this work. Your gift will be the satisfaction of knowing that you will have contributed to the production of wonderful stories and beautiful artwork Book Edition €60• the 2 books, personally signed, dated and numbered, presented in a custom-made art box
 
“Quince”  Print Edition €195

[ no longer available ]
• the 2 books, personally signed, dated and numbered, presented in an elegant cloth-covered box
• 1 photogravure print, 1 of only 10 editions, signed, dated and numbered (verso/on the back), on archival art rag paper, approx. 21x30cm
• a print certificate of authenticity with your print title, edition number and date
 
“Walnuts” Print Edition €195

story:
NC Dance Collective is a collaboration of unparalleled modern dance leaders who have merged organically as a platform to celebrate our talents. The show directors are Hilary Jordan and Sarah Molaro, both who hold extensive backgrounds in dance, performance and show creation. The larger collective consists of many long time dance teachers, choreographers and strong, experienced dancers who are excited to develop a deep and memorable event.

Our talents demand that we show ourselves to the community, that we let ourselves be seen as the artists that we are, and that we deliver our hearts through our passion to dance.

Healing through art begins and continues as we embrace our abilities and create new pathways for relaying our art. The choice to perform also supports the essential venues where art can safely unravel. To collaborate cohesively also models healing for delivering our best selves in a proud and honorable offering that gives us all an opportunity to embody our moving art more deeply and in a supported way.

Our needs for this show are very simple, yet still require your help. Tickets will cover many expenses, so this fund is for our Dream Come True budget:

Your donations will support:

  • ACTUAL COSTS
  • professional venue for two shows,
  • lights,
  • sound,
  • marketing,
  • videographer,
  • photographer,
  • DREAM COME TRUE FUNDS:
  • choreographer stipends,
  • dancer stipends,
  • producer and director stipends,
  • musician stipends,
  • rehearsal space rental,
  • costumes,
  • flowers,
  • ancillary costs of productions,

Thank you for your generosity and support as we take another leap. With the bigger vision of evoking inspiration in our audiences we align with our truest expressions of our dance art. Your support allows our community to realize movement as both visual art and powerful therapy for artists and audience members. Your help ripples out to immeasurable pools of love, inspiration, and artistic prosperity, right here in Nevada County. Thank you for supporting your local movement artists.

Blessings and Reverence-

Sarah and Hilary and the Nevada County Dance Collective

story:
Bref résumé

  • Je dessine ma première voiture alors que je n’ai que 2 ans 1/2. Très vite cependant, mon regard de petite fille est captivé par l’être humain, ses postures, ses attitudes et surtout les visages et leurs émotions. Je n’aurai alors de cesse de les reproduire, trouvant mes inspirations de l’époque dans les pages enfants des magazines de vente par correspondance. Constamment insatisfaite par ce que je produis, je travaillerai encore et encore ma technique au travers de recherches diverses pour tenter d’atteindre ce qui me tient le plus à cœur : l’hyperréalisme de mes créations. Un de mes dessins paraîtra dans un journal local nord-américain dans les années 80.

    Curieuse de nature et touche-à-tout, j'entreprends des études universitaires et obtiendrai successivement une Maîtrise d’Anglais, un Troisième Cycle en Linguistique et Fabrication de Voix de Synthèse ainsi qu’une Licence en Aéronautique, sans oublier deux ans d’études scientifiques au CNAM et une formation à distance d’assistant ingénieur du son. Je suis également multi-instrumentiste et chanteuse et ai fait 5 ans de théâtre.

    J'effectue ma carrière dans le milieu de l’aérien en tant que technicien trafic, un peu par hasard mais cela deviendra une véritable passion. Pour autant, je n’oublie pas le dessin et la peinture et prends des cours auprès de deux enseignantes diplômées de l’E.N.S.A.A.M.A. Olivier-de-Serres et de l’E.S.A.A. Duperré durant deux ans, auprès desquelles j'approfondis ma technique (mine graphite, huile, aquarelle, gouache, acrylique) au travers de sujets variés. Je m’initierai même à la sculpture.

    Autodidacte, je travaille aussi de moi-même le pastel sec, le crayon de couleur et le stylo à bille, toujours motivée par l’hyperréalisme de mes réalisations. Je parcours d’ailleurs inlassablement le net à la recherche d’artistes contemporains susceptibles de m’aider, au travers de leurs œuvres, à parfaire mes différentes techniques. Essentiellement passionnée par les portraits, je ne reste cependant pas cantonnée qu’à ce seul sujet et c’est avec joie et professionnalisme que je réalise les différentes commandes de mes clients.

    J'ai également réalisé la maquette et la mise en page d’un guide de voyage spécial motards vendu sur Amazon (tinyurl.com/daytona002) et dans la boutique en ligne du magazine Motomag (tinyurl.com/Daytona-motomag).

    Récemment passée à mon compte, je prépare activement mes premières expositions de l'année 2017 tout en travaillant également sur mes commandes en cours.

  • Mon projet, qui commence par cette grande exposition de Paris Porte de Versailles, vise à faire connaître mon travail et, je l'espère, me faire repérer par une galerie. Je compte  développer mes réalisations au travers de différents thèmes. Beaucoup d'idées sont déjà jetées sur le papier.

  • Exposer dans un salon tel que celui de Paris Porte de Versailles demande un réel investissement en temps et en argent. Je prépare cette exposition depuis le début de l'année 2016. Pour être sélectionnée, il m'a fallu envoyer un curriculum vitae, une biographie et plusieurs photos de mes réalisations. Ce salon accueille des visiteurs nationaux, mais aussi internationaux ainsi que des galeries d'art. Le tableau ci-dessous récapitule les coûts auxquels je suis confrontée. Nous serons trois personnes à nous relayer sur le stand durant ces trois jours d'exposition. Nous n'habitons pas la région, aussi avons-nous dû trouver un hébergement sur place.

Actuellement, je termine les dernières réalisations destinées à être exposées en janvier prochain. Chacune d'elle sera ensuite encadrée et accompagnée d'un certificat d'authenticité.

Vous ne pouvez pas contribuer ? Rien de grave ! Vous pouvez toujours m'aider autrement :

  •  Passez le mot et faites de la publicité autour de mon projet.
  •  N'oubliez pas pour cela d'utiliser les outils de partage Indiegogo.

Merci infiniment. Je vous retrouve au salon Art3f de Paris les 27, 28 et 29 janvier 2017.

story:
Hello,
My name is Ahmed Zeidan and I am the founder of Room Art Space in Cairo. "Room" is one of the leading independent culture venues in Cairo and it is in danger of shutting down. With your contribution we are not only surviving but also building an art school and co-working space that hosts thousands of art seekers in Cairo every year. 

The idea of "Room" emerged from the desperate need for more cultural spaces in the massive city of Cairo. in year 2014 Room Art Space launched as one of the first venues that offers a serious cultural programme without any governmental or private funding. The space sustains itself by generating income from food and beverage sales beside tickets income, Room was not only capable of covering its cost but was always evolving and expanding.

and the music never stopped.

The space sustains itself by generating income from food and beverage sales beside tickets income, Room was not only capable of covering its cost but was always evolving and expanding.

During the past few months and with crisis hitting Egyptian economy hard, Room is for the first time facing the danger of being forced to shut down. 

 

If we can reach $2000 Room will have a second chance

If we reach $4000 Room will have another chance and we will improve our vent and sound system. Beside basic sound treatment for the space.

f we reach $8000 we will do what is above beside putting together a small editing and recording unit that will reactivate our youtube and soundcloud channels. The recordings allow musicians to reach more audience without any cost from their side  

If we reach $13000 we will build a professional recording studio that emerging musicians can use for an affordable price  

If we reach a $20,000 we will rent a bigger space that will serve as an art school and a co-working space for artists such as musicians, painters, filmmaker and more offering an editing room, rehearsal space and a recording studio.

‏if we could really reach $20,000 with your contribution and build the school we will carve your name with all the names of contributors on the walls of the school.  

Support Room Art Space

And help keep the music playing

story:
The Farm

The Purney family, originally from Western Pennsylvania, came to Nova Scotia in 1783 and was granted a stretch of land on the western branch of the Jordan river near the small town of Port Roseway, now Shelburne, on the Southwest Shore of the peninsula. They homesteaded this land from that year and until the early 21st century, for over two hundred years. Several of them are buried on the property. The Pletner family, upon purchasing the 70-acre farm in a state of decline in 2010, vowed to restore it to its former glory while paying homage to its original owners, the Purney’s. It is in their honor that the new forge will be named and it will be their indomitable pioneer spirit that will guide us in everything we do.

The Vision

Many artisan blade smiths prefer to work using only traditional tools and methods. Japanese sword makers often start with iron ore mined in the same place in Japan where it had been mined for millennia. While we admire this approach, we also feel that it puts handmade blades out of reach for most folks in North America. We plan to utilize a blend of modern and traditional materials, tools, and techniques to produce the highest quality handmade edged tools at prices that most folks can afford.

While we believe in turning a healthy profit, we pledge to keep our eyes firmly fixed first on our quality, our community, and our customers, and only thereafter on our bottom line. Our financial goal for the business is to provide stable income for the Graham and Pletner families and a place of apprenticeship for the young people of Shelburne County. We hope to be able to support the blade smithing community both locally and across North America.

The Team

Master Smith Randal Graham has been tinkering with metal his entire life and has been making blades of all kinds full-time for over a quarter of a century. Growing up on a farm in Nova Scotia, he was always aware of his Scottish ancestors’ famous frugality, emphasizing in his designs utility & ruggedness over excessive artistic flourish.  

Dr. Baruch Pletner is a serial entrepreneur with advanced degrees in aerospace and business administration. He has been involved with edged weapons since he started fencing in Israel when he was only eleven years old. Since then Baruch kept up a keen interest in traditional edged weapons manufacturing, building relationships with Japanese traditional sword smiths among others. Baruch is a keen hunter, fisherman, and outdoorsman.

Community Engagement

Both Randal and Baruch are passionate about education and have engaged in mentoring and tutoring for most of their adult lives. We plan to partner with the community in Shelburne Municipality and Shelburne County to offer apprenticeships to students in the Shelburne and Lockeport regional high schools and in the Nova Scotia Community College, Shelburne Campus.

We firmly believe that we owe everything to the men and women of our military and law enforcement. As such, we plan to offer substantially reduced pricing on selected products for active duty and retired military and law enforcement members across North America. We will further have a slew of very special offerings for those members who have been wounded in the line of duty.

Where Are We Now

We are ready to get started. May of 2017 will be spent in setting up the forge and production will start in June.

Our Commitment to Quality & Functionality

We are passionate about our products serving their function for as long as they are appreciated by their owners. When you buy one of our knives, you are getting a tool that can be in your family for generations. To show that we mean business, we offer a lifetime warranty on all our products. If your knife gets damaged as part of normal use, please send it to us and we'll send you a new one. As simple as that. Since we want you to use our knives in your daily life, we also offer a free sharpening & reconditioning service. Send us your knife with a prepaid return label and we will recondition it to be like new. 

Our Initial Offerings

Read this to find out which three knives we will make first as we ramp up production and focus on excellence in everything we do. Customized versions of these knives will be available to the patrons of this campaign in limited quantities.

Classic Camp Knife

We take our big knives exceedingly seriously. 

We don't believe them to be replacements for axes - they are knives. Nor do we believe you can make a camp knife be like an ax without getting completely away from what a big knife should be or how it should be made.

Knives are cutting tools and our Classic Camp Knife follows this fundamental principle to the letter. Featuring a 10 inch (25 cm) blade with exhaustive attention given to balance and cross-section, coupled with heat treatment normally reserved for only the finest of custom knives, it is a tool that will help you create fire-lays, shelters, trails, and traps with ease and confidence.

And when it really counts...it'll see you through.

Like in all of our knives, the user interface, the handle, is as important as the blade...complete with a properly tapered and heat treated tang, the intelligently shaped handle features simple but strong and functional construction.  

So an ax replacement? No, we don't believe it should be thought of that way. But as an alternative; a lightweight, but capable tool for heavier tasks like firewood procurement or shelter building, or making your way through heavy brush on your big back-country hunt, we feel it's a sublime choice.

Some big game hunters have come to rely on these big campers for the initial prep required to pack out their large prize.

 

Scandinavian EDC (Every Day Carry)

Our take on the centuries-old Nordic traditions of the working knife, our Scandinavian EDC is a full tang hard-working tool ready to take on whatever task you need it to accomplish.

Classic Nordic design, modern materials, and heat treatment combine to create a workhorse of a knife that's ideal for bushcrafting and survival, but is equally at home as a daily carry tool. Carry it in the shop, on a hike, or wherever your travels take you.

Full tang construction, fully sealed scales, and a 4 inch (10 cm) blade with a true "scandi" grind, along with the classic handle profile and cross section make the Scandinavian EDC a far more capable knife than its compact appearance would indicate. It carries lightly and discreetly, yet when called on to work hard and long, it's ready and able.

This knife has a long history as a proven hunting knife; use it to effortlessly prep and dress small and medium game, where it's trim and compact stature will prove a real bonus.

The Scandinavian EDC won't tire you out or weigh you down...it's ready to go whenever you are and wherever your adventures may lead you.

Backwoods Utility

Featuring a 3.5 inch (9 cm) blade with full flat V grind and convex secondary edge bevel, the Backwood's blade is thin, flexible, and scandalously sharp, ready to take on any task with ease; preparing a fire, cleaning fish and game, or in-camp crafting. 

The Backwoods has a huge tang for it's class, embedded in an ergonomically shaped handle that provides sure and safe grip in many modes of utlization. You can tell the orientation of the blade by feel and the handle design allows using the knife in many different grips and positions for a wide range of tasks. 

The Backwood is lightweight. Very much into ultralight territory, this knife begs to go along on your next through-hike or expedition where every ounce counts, without giving up true heavyweight performance and toughness.

If you are a backwoods minimalist, this is your knife, it was made for you. 

 

Especially for You

In exchange for being early adopters of our products and true believers in our vision, we offer special editions of our three startup knives. These one of a kind offerings will be hand-signed by Randal and include features that will not be repeated on any other knife we make. These knives will be one of a kind items that will never again be made in that exact form by our forge. These designs are just now being finished and we do not yet have pictures, but please stay tuned. Quantities are extremely limited and will not be increased as we will have to focus on production ramp-up and will not be able to offer customized blades at deeply discounted prices once our early adopter perks sell out. Please see the "Initial Offerings" section above for full descriptions of these one of a kind  products.

Secret Perk

Yes, there is something we are holding back for the true enthusiasts. No clues, but if you email us and tell us what makes you interested in blade smithing excellence, we will send you a link.

Other Ways You Can Help

Have experience with the outdoors? Passionate about hunting or fishing? A current or past member of the military or law enforcement? A great chef? Love edged weapons? Consider joining our advisory board! Send us a note and we'll get back to you.
story_txt:
The Farm
The Purney family, originally from Western Pennsylvania, came to Nova Scotia in 1783 and was granted a stretch of land on the western branch of the Jordan river near the small town of Port Roseway, now Shelburne, on the Southwest Shore of the peninsula. They homesteaded this land from that year and until the early 21st century, for over two hundred years. Several of them are buried on the property. The Pletner family, upon purchasing the 70-acre farm in a state of decline in 2010, vowed to restore it to its former glory while paying homage to its original owners, the Purney’s. It is in their honor that the new forge will be named and it will be their indomitable pioneer spirit that will guide us in everything we do.
The Vision
Many artisan blade smiths prefer to work using only traditional tools and methods. Japanese sword makers often start with iron ore mined in the same place in Japan where it had been mined for millennia. While we admire this approach, we also feel that it puts handmade blades out of reach for most folks in North America. We plan to utilize a blend of modern and traditional materials, tools, and techniques to produce the highest quality handmade edged tools at prices that most folks can afford.
While we believe in turning a healthy profit, we pledge to keep our eyes firmly fixed first on our quality, our community, and our customers, and only thereafter on our bottom line. Our financial goal for the business is to provide stable income for the Graham and Pletner families and a place of apprenticeship for the young people of Shelburne County. We hope to be able to support the blade smithing community both locally and across North America.

The Team
Master Smith Randal Graham has been tinkering with metal his entire life and has been making blades of all kinds full-time for over a quarter of a century. Growing up on a farm in Nova Scotia, he was always aware of his Scottish ancestors’ famous frugality, emphasizing in his designs utility & ruggedness over excessive artistic flourish.  

Dr. Baruch Pletner is a serial entrepreneur with advanced degrees in aerospace and business administration. He has been involved with edged weapons since he started fencing in Israel when he was only eleven years old. Since then Baruch kept up a keen interest in traditional edged weapons manufacturing, building relationships with Japanese traditional sword smiths among others. Baruch is a keen hunter, fisherman, and outdoorsman.
Community Engagement
Both Randal and Baruch are passionate about education and have engaged in mentoring and tutoring for most of their adult lives. We plan to partner with the community in Shelburne Municipality and Shelburne County to offer apprenticeships to students in the Shelburne and Lockeport regional high schools and in the Nova Scotia Community College, Shelburne Campus.
We firmly believe that we owe everything to the men and women of our military and law enforcement. As such, we plan to offer substantially reduced pricing on selected products for active duty and retired military and law enforcement members across North America. We will further have a slew of very special offerings for those members who have been wounded in the line of duty.

Where Are We Now
We are ready to get started. May of 2017 will be spent in setting up the forge and production will start in June.
Our Commitment to Quality & Functionality
We are passionate about our products serving their function for as long as they are appreciated by their owners. When you buy one of our knives, you are getting a tool that can be in your family for generations. To show that we mean business, we offer a lifetime warranty on all our products. Send us your knife with a prepaid return label and we will recondition it to be like new.

story:
Hello!

My name is Christos and I'm a Graphic Designer.

I studied at the Technological Institute of Athens. And now for my graduation I have created the branding, products, website etc. for a company named 2918 that fabricates and sale climbing gear.

Now it's time for the presentation of my Bachelor Thesis. That means printing/buying the climbing gear, packaging of the products, posters, t shirts, website domain, magazine catalogues etc.

2918

We are the first company creating climbing gear, based in Greece. Brand new, modern, advanced company, we are proud to export mountaineering and outdoor equipment, all over the world.

The name of the company 2918, was inspired from the highest altitude in Greece, 2918 meters. Located at the mythical Olympus mountain, with the pick named Mytikas. Studying the local flora and fauna of the mountain, a very interesting tiny black and bright yellow creature popup. The fire salamander, became our mascot since then, and the inspiration for the whole branding of the company.


#christosellinas #brand #drawing #film #crafts #creative #art #direction #brading #adobe #artist​ #summer #photo #greece #colors #black #yellow #wealth #info #like #follow #love #sport #european #minimal #abstract #trip #nature #gym #sunshine #mountain #rockclimbing #retweet #bouldering

 

Perks

People inspire me and I want to inspire them too!

Thank you for Watching!

story:
Short Summary

Firmament is a large LED sculpture first created for Burning Man 2015. It’s 54’ in diameter, 42’ tall, with 21,600 LED modules, each controlled by a computer. It’s been exhibited several times since then, delighting hordes of Burning Man participants, Steampunk Masqueraders, and other connoisseurs of animated beauty.

In late 2016, it was installed in a public park in Houston. It was fantastic to have it appreciated by non-Burning Man folks of all stripes. And the urban setting provided some great sight lines! 

Unfortunately, That urban setting provided a lot of rain too. Water got into all of the LED modules (which we were assured were waterproof). Now they must all be replaced.

The good news is that this circumstance allows us to improve the LED canopy! The original had LED modules attached to bird netting with zip ties. Modules would often point to the side, and their spacing would vary more than a bit. The new canopy will be made of plastic sheets with precisely-sized holes that hold each module in place. Each module will be pointing exactly where it should, and the spacing will stay consistent. The quality of images displayed on Firmament will be markedly improved!

These improvements cost money of course. Please consider helping us bring back this community-building, awe-inspiring, safe-space-providing piece!

What We Need & What You Get

The new LED modules will cost $21,100. The new canopy panel sheets will cost $2,600 (Insurance, transport, and gasoline to run the generators have already been covered by a generous donation from a very kind fellow-artist.)

We have gifts to offer contributors at various levels.  Many are opportunities for sharing in the creation of Firmament’s show.  One is a stainless steel medallion suitable for use in all sorts of playa-wear:

There's also a nice hoodie:

The Impact

At Burning Man 2015 and 2016, Firmament was not only yet-another-LED-piece.  It was a place to be.  It was surprising to us just how attached visitors were to hanging out within it, and not just for a minute or two!  It had many nicknames including “The Mustache” and “The Tripper Trap”. Our favorite though was “Permanent”, as in no one wanted to leave!

It was also surprising how the thump-thump of the playa was effectively shut-out by having 6 speakers playing classical music at relatively low volume. This resulted in a space that felt safe, calm and peaceful - a rarity on the playa these days.

Mirth was another outcome of Firmament. The Hubble Space Telescope images, panning and zooming across the field of vision were an awe-inspiring sight. And the Tchaikovsky waltzes nearly always inspired at least one full-grown person to remember his/her ballet lessons. Our favorite moment was when the entire population of Firmament got up to waltz during the Finale of La Valse des Fleurs!

In 2016, live musicians were added to the mix! Three cellists, one violist, two opera singers, and one peruvian double-flute player performed pieces while we chose visual scenes to match. In 2017 we plan much more of this, perhaps a performance of the Playa Pops or other playa-based orchestras.

1000s of people enjoyed Firmament deeply. Please help us restore this piece, so that we can provide this experience in the desert once again.
