story:
Showcasing plant life from Botanical gardens, Chinese medicine, the Australian Outback, the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant Zone of Alienation and the graves of lost children, the art in this book represents the hardy connections between plant and human.

We have put together a book of art that we are proud of and are excited to get it out into the world.

We've been told that print is dead and have learned that printing costs are high, but we love beautiful objects, so we've done it any way.  We promised to print and ship a copy to each artist involved... back when there were only 6 of us so the book was that much thinner. So many Ayatana artists have made amazing things with plants that the project has grown into a big publication that will be shipped out to a lot more artists. We also look forward to giving copies to the amazing scientists and naturalists who have helped us on our way. We've promised to print and ship 40 copies but they cost $25 each.  Ayatana is artist-run on a shoe string so we'd love your help to cover the printing and shipping costs.

  If we make more than we spend on this project we will give a scholarship to an artist to do an Ayatana research residency in Canada next year.

If we go over our goal we will send all of our backers a secret postal poem that's not in the perks.

If we go way over we will send every one a couple postal poems and some stickers to celebrate.

If we do not make our printing cost we will still send you your books.

The Germinating Herbarium is the first issue of Ayatana's Annual Anthology.

Each year we will showcase art working within a theme. This year's theme is plants.

Ayatana is a research program that leads international artists on intensive expeditions to study nature with scientists and experts from outside the art world. 

The whole point is to learn and then to express our experiences. We want to share our ideas. When we come together we notice recurring themes and thoughts that flow through like-minded artists and scientists from all around the world. This is encouraging. This is invigorating. This is validating.

We are often asked "why would an artist want to study science?" This book answers that question.

 

 

What’s the book like?

It's 90 glossy pages of contemporary art, discussion about plants, a few poems and a story too. 

It’s full color glossy images of art and writing by 30 research artists. It’s mostly pictures but includes statements from each artist and dialogue about working with plants, how they are inspiring, and what using them in art means.

 

It's filled with art by these artists:

Amanda Besl, USA
Julya Hajnoczky, Canada
Alyssa Ellis, Canada
Brooke Sauer, USA
Tracie Stewart, Canada
Cassandra Robillard, Canada
Chantal Dupas, Canada
Cynthia Farnell, USA
Guylaine Couture, Canada
Helga Jakobson, Canada
Linelle Stepto, Australia
MJ Musiol, Canada
Mellissa Fisher, England
Shannon Amidon, USA
Shavon Madden, Scotland
Sonja Hebert, Canada
Stephanie Sherriff, USA
Agnes Marton, Luxembourg
Blake Evans, Canada
Chloe Rodham, England
Jody Brooks, USA
Hua Jin, Canada
Miriam Segan, USA
Meggan Trobaugh, USA
Michelle Stewart, Australia
Mika Aono Boyd, USA
Rachel Yurkovich, USA
Shelly Smith, USA
Yannick DeSerre, Canada
Katrina Vera Wong, Canada
Alexis Williams, Canada

 

All these artists participated in an Ayatana Artists' Research Program expedition. All have made art, poetry or flash fiction that expresses what they've learned from experiences with plants.

 

Get cool stuff:

You can have a copy of the book!
We also have other cool perks like one of a kind art, hand printed t shirts, 

 

If you don't want to spend $ but still want to help, please share this on your facebook. :)

story:
The Project

The project is a QPOC-led zodiac photography and horoscope series combining Filipinx mythology with astrology!

The series will feature 12 pre-colonial Filipina goddesses represented by a diverse range of Filipina womxn and will be shot on location in Manila, Philippines in early March 2019. It will be released monthly on Hella Pinay, a digital magazine centering Filipina womxn, starting with the first zodiac sign, Aries, accompanied by original horoscopes and ritual.

We'll be representing goddesses from Filipinx mythology - such as Magwayen, the Visayan goddess of the sea and underworld; Lakapati, the transgender Tagalog goddess of fertility; and Mayari, the Tagalog goddess of the moon.

This is a collaboration between Stephanie Gancayco, founder & EIC of Hella Pinay; art director & stylist Jodinand Aguillon; and astrologer Chase Chualong of Early Bird Astrology.

Who We Are

At Hella Pinay, we seek to create a space for positive representation of the diversity and complexity of Filipina womxn, and facilitate dialogue between Pinays in the Philippines and throughout the diaspora. Frustrated by the lack of representation of Filipinas in mainstream media, Hella Pinay was created as a platform for us to tell our own stories; a space for conversations on identity, decolonization, spirituality, creativity, and celebration of dope Pinay sh*t. Launched in December 2016, we've written dozens of articles, thrown WOC-centered events,  built a strong community of Filipinx followers around the globe, and have a stacked masthead of prominent writers, activists, artists, and healers in the Filipinx community from North America to the Philippines to Paris. Its founder, Stephanie Gancayco, is a creative director, designer, and medium based in Oakland, CA.

Jodinand Aguillon is a Manila-based art director, stylist, and overall creative visionary who's helped shaped the neo-Filipino aesthetic. The images used in this campaign are actually from his first collaboration with Hella Pinay from two years ago entitled "9 Muses" that were created as part of his arts residency at Pineapple Lab in Manila. Inspired by the "Siyam na Diwata ng Sining/Nine Muses of the Arts" sculpture by Napoleon Abueva at UP Diliman and Goddess/Oracle cards, the series re-envisioned modern Muses as "Diwata Cards" which can be pulled for words of advice for those seeking inspiration. We shot and interviewed nine different Filipina creatives from the Philippines and North America who are each challenging societal limitations in their respective fields. You can see the interviews and images here.

We will also be partnering with New York-based astrologer Chase Chualong of Early Bird Astrology to release monthly horoscopes and ritual to accompany the images. Chase believes that when used properly, astrology is a wonderful, practical tool that becomes a window into the soul and give us access to our deep potential. His work with astrology has created a container for the many subjects he's consistently studied for the past 8 years: traditional medicine, herbalism, spirituality, Buddhist thought, flower essences, energy work, massage, nutrition, health, beauty, food and magic. 

Why Do We Need Funding?

For the past two years, we've been doing it for the community and for the love and while that will always be at the heart of Hella Pinay's work, it's also been a major roadblock to putting out the kind of original content we want to (and also that we believe our audience deserves??).

The money we raise will allow us to compensate our talented team for their valuable labor and create beautiful representations of our precolonial goddesses (and the womxn depicting them). This is an ambitious project that requires research, props and costumes that represent the beauty of Philippine cultures and people, sourcing textiles which support Indigenous communities, location scouting and travel. We might even turn this into a print zine (or include it in our future planned print issues!), a gallery show, etc which requires more funding than we can provide out-of-pocket.

What You Get!

For those who've been asking us for the longest, we're finally going to be turning the 9 Muses series into a small oracle card deck that you can only get through donating to our Indiegogo campaign! You'll also be able to get prints from this zodiac series, Hella Pinay merch, and for the super super generous, a personalized chart reading from our astrologer Chase!

The Impact

We believe it's super important to disrupt the traditional media landscape and create the reflections of ourselves that we want to see out in the world. To see people who look like us represented in an empowering, beautiful way positively impacts not just ourselves, but also the younger generations. We also aspire to share our precolonial mythology with our community (and beyond) and hopefully create an entry point for digging deeper into Filipinx spirituality. Much of the information on Filipinx mythology that exists isn't very easily accessible - at Hella Pinay we get constantly asked to point readers to resources. We're hoping to help change that narrative by documenting some of our heritage while also connecting it to our lived diasporic experience.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, we hella appreciate the other ways you can help us out:

  • Spread the word about our Indiegogo campaign!
  • Follow us on social media!
  • Check out & share our articles on HellaPinay.com!
  • Pull up to one of our future events!

story:
We did it!!!! We've raised the funds needed to have "Where There's Smoke" at the Tribeca Film Festival via a mix of outside sources and crowdfunding.

BIG THANKS to everyone who contributed and/or helped to spread the word about the project. Starting April 24th through May 5th we'll be running the experience within the festival's Virtual Arcade and also at a special storefront installation on Canal Street a few blocks away.

The storefront comes via a collaboration with Wallplay's OnCanal arts initiative. For more details visit http://smokeproject.co

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

In 1983 our van burst into flames on a family vacation. Eleven months later our house would burn to the ground.

As I dig through my past I find mysterious connections to these blazes that force me to confront a closet full of skeletons. Inspired by true events in my life, Where There’s Smoke details these connections between two mysterious fires and my father’s battle with cancer.

This spring, Where There’s Smoke will premiere at the Tribeca Film Festival. The experience will consist of two distinct immersive installations: one in the festival’s main venue, and the other as a pop-up in a nearby storefront on Canal Street. Both installations will bring festival-goers into different sections of a house destroyed by fire.

After Tribeca, Where There’s Smoke will become a traveling installation designed to evoke empathy among healthcare practitioners in an effort to reduce intern burnout. Working in conjunction with the Columbia University Narrative Medicine program and the School of the Arts’ Digital Storytelling Lab, the project will act as a curative space that enables practitioners, patients and loved ones to craft and share stories of healing. The goal is to evolve the project into a multi-year design research initiative that harnesses storytelling, collaborative design and emergent technology in an effort to improve care.

We need your help to create an empathic healing/learning experience that can tour multiple cities — starting with a storefront pop-up installation on Canal Street during the Tribeca Film Festival. 

In Brief: Why should I support the project?

1. When my dad was diagnosed with stage 4 colon cancer, the lack of empathy he received was heartbreaking. The careless treatment he suffered has driven me to create this experience as part of a grieving process. This work holds space for others to process loss and explore their own memories through a series of emotional artifacts that are enchanted via emergent technology.

2. Where There's Smoke represents a new form and function of storytelling. It’s a doc meets immersive theatre meets escape room, as well as an empathic space for healing. We did a work-in-progress staging at the invitational Future of Storytelling Summit and the response was overwhelming.

3. The immersive story installation created for Tribeca will also be able to travel to other locations. We're in talks with hospitals, museums and other festivals to stage Where There's Smoke in 2019 and 2020.

4. Work like this is difficult to fund as it doesn't fit into traditional formats. While the work is exciting on its own, projects like this also help to forge new paths for the curation, funding and exhibition of immersive work.

5.  We need $65,000 to realize the Tribeca offsite and to create a traveling set that will hit the road in 2019 and 2020. The physical and technical build-out is extensive and we've made sure to place value on those who are making the project a reality with their talents and time.
 

6.  The tech behind this experience will be documented and shared openly for others who wish to build their own immersive story installations with emergent technology.

7.  We've assembled an amazing group of collaborators - the Tribeca Film Festival, Columbia University's Narrative Medicine program, the Columbia University School of the Arts' Digital Storytelling Lab and Wallplay/On Canal to name a few.

 

The following is based on true events

An Obsession with Fire

Since I was a child, my Dad had always been an enigma. For over 20 years he put his life on the line as a volunteer firefighter and amateur fire scene photographer shooting thousands of scenes and objects in various states of burning. He spent his nights off listening to fire scanners, chasing blazes from dusk to dawn.

I grew up in a culture of fire parades, pancake breakfasts, and beef and beers. My family had evacuation plans, my brothers and I knew how to check doors for backdrafts and we were all well versed in the art of stop, drop and roll. Yet fire would intersect with our lives in strange and devastating ways multiple times throughout my youth.

In the months leading up to my Dad’s death, we had a series of in-depth conversations, finding our way through memories of experiences we shared. From the start, we both knew we were moving into uncharted territory. Where There’s Smoke shares our story in order to hold space for participants’ own memories. Participants work together to uncover nine narrative fragments that comprise the core of the experience, and in the process have an opportunity to connect to their own stories and each others’.

What's the audience experience

Audience members take on the role of fire investigators as they move through the charred remains of a house while searching for a series of objects that survived a blaze. Once all the objects are found a 35mm slide projector and light table magically comes to life. By placing the objects in various combinations, audience members unlock a series of narrative fragments that reveal a mystery.

 

Where There’s Smoke crafts a unique experience that enables participants to explore their own memories through a series of emotional artifacts.

 

The following video is an example of a narrative fragment unlocked by mixing and matching objects on the light table within the Where There’s Smoke installation.

 

A Healing Space through Storytelling

Through a mixture of storytelling, emergent technology and a collaborative design framework developed at Columbia University, Where There’s Smoke crafts a unique experience that enables participants to explore their own memories through a series of emotional artifacts. The result is an empathic space not easily accessible on our own or through everyday experiences.

My Dad was terminal and given a year to live

Even the walls looked sick — drab, washed out and orange. My Dad sat silently as my wife and I tried to make sense of the medical forms spread out in front of us. The forms had been copied so many times they were almost illegible.

After about thirty minutes the doctor finally arrived. From the moment she entered the room, she was rushed. She started by explaining that the cancer had spread from his colon to his liver to his lungs. The prognosis wasn’t good. My Dad was terminal – given a year to live.

He struggled with the fact that there was no cure. The more questions we asked, the more it seemed like the doctor was speaking a foreign language. We were talking past each other. In a moment of frustration, the doctor uttered a mere eight words that cut deep. They sting to this day. “I guess I’ll have to work through lunch,” she said, without looking up from her laptop.

The visit continued for another few minutes until the doctor started packing up her things, said goodbye and awkwardly left the room. In her wake, we attempted to pick up the emotional debris.

My Dad was a fighter. He lived much longer than expected. Over the course of two and a half years, he went through forty-five cycles of chemo until it made him so sick that he decided to walk away from treatment. To regain a degree of control over his life, he decided to take one last cross-country road trip with my Mom. When he returned from his trip we started collaborating on what would become Where There’s Smoke.

The lack of empathy my Dad experienced during his cancer diagnosis became a source of inspiration. During the final months of his life, we captured hours and hours of audio, sifted through thousands of archival slides, discussed plans for a physical set and chose some of his possessions to become enchanted game pieces at the center of the Where There’s Smoke experience.

What people are saying about Where There's Smoke

The following is an audience members response after participating in a work-in-progress staging at the Future of Storytelling last fall.

“Not all transformations are visible, but 6 weeks since sitting down at a white table across from a complete stranger to start Lance Weiler’s immersive experience Where There’s Smoke I know this to be true: it is a truly transformative experience, in both visible and invisible ways… The experience encouraged immediate introspection and real empathy, both of which seem to be sorely lacking in our dialogue today. That introspection also prepared us to internalize an experience in which Lance and his family processed their complicated relationship with his dad, a firefighter, and the generational legacy of mysteries physical and spiritual left unsolved as cancer took his life. Where There’s Smoke is both deeply personal and universally true, as the best stories always are.“

 

The funds will help to create an installation that can travel to multiple locations

The money raised will be used to design and build a traveling version of the set, to create a robust Internet of Things hardware/software control system with documentation (which we intend to openly share), to rent the storefront and to staff the installation for a month-long run. The total budget for the traveling set as well as staging the experience at the Tribeca Film Festival is $65,000

 

What do I receive in return for my contribution?

First and foremost it is important to note that this project would not be possible without contributions from funders like you. Thank you so much for your time and consideration.

 

Please help us to spread the word

Sharing is a nice thing to do! If you find this project interesting please make sure to share it with others. For example...

"Where There's Smoke mixes documentary/immersive theatre/escape room to explore memory, loss and mortality by enabling participants to explore their own memories through a series of emotional artifacts. #smokeproject"

Thanks so much!

 

Additional details about the WTiS Art Book

My Dad shot thousands of photos of things in various states of burning. Those images are at the heart of the Where There's Smoke experience and will be featured in within the limited edition WTiS Art Book. The book features photos shot between 1968 and 1988 when my Dad was a volunteer firefighter and amateur fire scene photographer.

 

More about Lance and his previous work

An alumnus of the Sundance Screenwriting Lab, Lance Weiler is recognized as a pioneer in mixing storytelling and technology. Wired magazine named him “one of 25 people helping to reinvent entertainment and change the face of Hollywood.” He was nominated for an International Emmy in digital fiction for his work on Collapsus: The Energy Risk Conspiracy. His award-winning collaboration with David Cronenberg entitled, Body/Mind/Change premiered at the TIFF Lightbox and his most recent project Frankenstein AI: a monster made by many was an official selection of the Sundance Film Festival and IDFA doc lab. In addition, he is a founding member and director of the Columbia University School of the Arts’ Digital Storytelling Lab. He’s currently developing a new immersive work entitled, Where There’s Smoke which will start touring the world in 2019.

Selected Works

Lance is known for his immersive installations that mix storytelling, design, play, and emergent technology. His work has been staged around the world at festivals, museums and event spaces.

Pandemic 1.0 (2011) - Official Selection Sundance Film Festival

 

Body/Mind/Change (2013 -2017) - Premiered at the TIFF Lightbox

 

Frankenstein AI (2018 - present) Official Selection Sundance Film Festival and IDFA Doc Lab
story_txt:
We did it!!!! We've raised the funds needed to have "Where There's Smoke" at the Tribeca Film Festival via a mix of outside sources and crowdfunding.
BIG THANKS to everyone who contributed and/or helped to spread the word about the project. Starting April 24th through May 5th we'll be running the experience within the festival's Virtual Arcade and also at a special storefront installation on Canal Street a few blocks away.
The storefront comes via a collaboration with Wallplay's OnCanal arts initiative. For more details visit http://smokeproject.co
 

 
 
 
 
 
 
In 1983 our van burst into flames on a family vacation. Eleven months later our house would burn to the ground.
As I dig through my past I find mysterious connections to these blazes that force me to confront a closet full of skeletons. Inspired by true events in my life, Where There’s Smoke details these connections between two mysterious fires and my father’s battle with cancer.
This spring, Where There’s Smoke will premiere at the Tribeca Film Festival. The experience will consist of two distinct immersive installations: one in the festival’s main venue, and the other as a pop-up in a nearby storefront on Canal Street. Both installations will bring festival-goers into different sections of a house destroyed by fire.
After Tribeca, Where There’s Smoke will become a traveling installation designed to evoke empathy among healthcare practitioners in an effort to reduce intern burnout. Working in conjunction with the Columbia University Narrative Medicine program and the School of the Arts’ Digital Storytelling Lab, the project will act as a curative space that enables practitioners, patients and loved ones to craft and share stories of healing. The goal is to evolve the project into a multi-year design research initiative that harnesses storytelling, collaborative design and emergent technology in an effort to improve care.
We need your help to create an empathic healing/learning experience that can tour multiple cities — starting with a storefront pop-up installation on Canal Street during the Tribeca Film Festival. 

In Brief: Why should I support the project?
1. When my dad was diagnosed with stage 4 colon cancer, the lack of empathy he received was heartbreaking. The careless treatment he suffered has driven me to create this experience as part of a grieving process. This work holds space for others to process loss and explore their own memories through a series of emotional artifacts that are enchanted via emergent technology.
2. Where There's Smoke represents a new form and function of storytelling. It’s a doc meets immersive theatre meets escape room, as well as an empathic space for healing. We did a work-in-progress staging at the invitational Future of Storytelling Summit and the response was overwhelming.
3. The immersive story installation created for Tribeca will also be able to travel to other locations. We're in talks with hospitals, museums and other festivals to stage Where There's Smoke in 2019 and 2020.4. Work like this is difficult to fund as it doesn't fit into traditional formats. While the work is exciting on its own, projects like this also help to forge new paths for the curation, funding and exhibition of immersive work.5.  We need $65,000 to realize the Tribeca offsite and to create a traveling set that will hit the road in 2019 and 2020. The physical and technical build-out is extensive and we've made sure to place value on those who are making the project a reality with their talents and time. 6.  The tech behind this experience will be documented and shared openly for others who wish to build their own immersive story installations with emergent technology.
7.  We've assembled an amazing group of collaborators - the Tribeca Film Festival, Columbia University's Narrative Medicine program, the Columbia University School of the Arts' Digital Storytelling Lab and Wallplay/On Canal to name a few.
 

The following is based on true events

story:
"Joy is the highest energy of all. It is the magical sense that everything is possible. Joy springs from appreciating the gifts within each moment. Joy allows you to attract and create your present and future moments at their highest possible levels" - Doreen Virtue

Imagine seeing a giant kitten playing with a ball of yarn as you start pedaling out into the open playa. From afar you can see she's made of wood and has a most ecstatic expression on her face. As you pedal closer you can see her skin is made up of carefully cut mosaic pieces.  At night the light pours through the spaces on the mosaic, illuminating her from the inside out.  It is evident that an entire community created this larger than life sculpture. As you start to explore the ball of yarn you notice a panel of buttons which pique your curiosity. You examine a button and press it, to your delight a purring sound emanates from the sculpture. At night the buttons light up and you find that when you press another button it changes the color of the lighting in the yarn. You can't help but feel the joy, curiosity, and playful energy this feline exudes. 

The impact of this project is immeasurable because joy the driving force behind it's creation. Perhaps if we could put the feeling of joy in a pill, we would be able to cure the suffering of humanity. Instead, we’ll bring it in the form of a giant kitten playing with yarn.

This project is already bringing joy to everyone who supports it. I invite you to join the JoyCat 2019 community by sharing and contributing to this crowdfunding campaign. 

 

We need $90,000 to pay for materials, fabrication, transportation, engineering, lighting, etc.

You can help us however your budget affords. For $10 we will send you exclusive sneak peak videos and updates. $1750 will send you a 10 inch 3D printed replica from Gentle Giant Studios. Please see the perks page for more information.

All funds, in any amount, will go towards the creation of JoyCat 2019.

 

Here's the basic build plan:

 

Joycat 2019 was borne from a deep desire to transmute the whole-body emotion of joy to the infinite masses. Through the powerful alchemy of Prana Vinyasa Yoga, Meditation, Shamanic Practices, and art, artist Love/Hate Los Angeles (aka Rebecca Totman) has been working on transforming her own fear from personal trauma and societal constrictions into freedom and joy. And now, it is time to share! 

While watching the Burning Man webcam incessantly last year, Rebecca decided she had to go back home. And she must make a sculpture with her community. She had an idea in mind for the piece and thought that if she could make it small, she could make it big.

Rebecca loves sculpting, she earned her BFA from MSUD in 2005 and hasn't stopped creating art since, albeit slowly due to a busy work life as an Associate Producer of Animation on The Simpsons. While she had confidence in the “making it small/making it big” part of things, she had even bigger confidence in her ability to recruit and lead talented people. Rebecca believes anything is possible with teamwork (and it's WAY more fun!) She called  her friend Adriane Dos Sontos (she’s a super talented fine detail sculptor) and asked her if she’d like to help make a maquette.

Adriane Dos Sontos always had a love for art throughout her life but didn't discover her talent until 4 years ago when she decided to pursue what has now become her passion. Not having the privilege of attending an art school and only having a few technique classes under her belt, she was forced to learn on her own and become a self-taught sculptor. After the first time of running her fingers through the clay and letting the magic of formation take place is when she knew this was her calling and fell in love with sculpting. Adriane felt called to help on this project because of the overriding message of joy and the opportunity to explore new media and techniques. 

After about a month of hard work, the beautiful maquette was complete and Rebecca called Gentle Giant Studios to help with the 3D scan. Being Burners themselves, they were super excited to help on this project. Word spread in our community and all of a sudden, JoyCat 2019 had a couple of mentors. Things have been rolling along (with mighty persistence) ever since.

Currently the project is with Rbhu engineering making sure it won’t be knocked over in a wind storm or pulled down by a clueless climber. We're super happy to say we've got a build site here in Pasadena where we'll be hosting monthly live fundraisers. We’re projected to start building in of May.
 

 

 

Love/Hate Los Angeles- Lead Artist

Adriane Dos Sontos- Sculptor

Gentle Giant Studios- 3D Render, fabrication, printing

Jesus Guerrero- Architect

Rbhu- Engineering

Bill and Bob Real- lighting/power

Carlton Batten- Support Camp Lead

Sam Saldivar- Video and Still Documentation

Dustin Rolstad- Website Design

There are many challenges that come with building a 35 foot sculpture made of wood (and meant to burn.) However, we've got an AMAZING team of people on board who are very good at their specialties as well as passionate burners. 

The biggest risk is that we won't be able to raise the funds to cover materials.

You can help by contributing to this crowdfunding campaign (which will cover the essential materials and transportation costs), and/or lending a hand with construction both off or on the playa, or simply sharing this campaign with your friends. Please share!

See www.joycat2019.com for opportunities to help build and/or join our art support camp.

Follow us on facebook @joycat2019 and Instagram @rebecca.totman.

story:
Short Summary

I am a circus performer with over 25 years experience performing all over the world. The above image is but a snippet of the productions I have both been involved with and created. 

"The Drunken Sailors" is one of my latest projects which culminated from working with my brother who has over 20 years experience as a musician. It involves our roving bike/boat/stage on which we perform sea shanties and circus tricks.

This campaign will get us to Europe. We want to expose this work to a larger audience so it seems the best way to do that is to take it to where the people are. Not only that, much of the music we sing has its origins in and around The Mediterranean Sea. What more appropriate place is there for us to be performing. 

This adventure is the culmination of a lifetime of work, as well as the start of a new journey.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Funding for this trip will go towards these needs.

- International Travel

- In country Travel

- Accomodation

- Food

- General Costs (Communications, taxes, etc)

For three people and a 4 meter long craft this is no cheap exercise.

We are in this for the long haul. This is a project that I believe in so if we don't reach our target and can't get to Europe this year the funds will go directly into the vault and be ready for use next year when we hope to be touring through Europe. If contributions exceed our target the excess will go to like minded projects.

This project has a strong cultural message. It reminds people of the art that came out of the blood and sweat of men from thousands of years of travel and work on the seas. It also crosses cultural boundaries. Sailing nations around the world had their own versions of sea shanties and influences on songs from different groups would drift in and out as they joined the long journeys on the sea. An important oral history which this project is endeavouring to tell the story of and continue.

Risks & Challenges

Every time we have performed this act it has been met with great joy and excitement. Children who would follow us around an event and sit and watch every performance to sing along to all the songs while contributing to the interactive nature of what we do. This in itself is reward enough.

The biggest obstacle I perceive is reach. Once we have reached enough people this project will take on its own life. When we get to that point, I will happily never do another campaign again and actually put back into similar projects that need a lift up.

If you can't contribute financially, simply pass this campaign onto others. Eventually we will reach out goal.

Thank you.

An important oral history which this project is endeavouring to tell the story of and continue.
Risks & Challenges
Every time we have performed this act it has been met with great joy and excitement. Children who would follow us around an event and sit and watch every performance to sing along to all the songs while contributing to the interactive nature of what we do. This in itself is reward enough.
The biggest obstacle I perceive is reach. Once we have reached enough people this project will take on its own life. When we get to that point, I will happily never do another campaign again and actually put back into similar projects that need a lift up.
If you can't contribute financially, simply pass this campaign onto others. Eventually we will reach out goal.Thank you.

story:
Nowhere is a space for the citizens of Black Rock City to climb, sit, connect and be present with each other. 

Nowhere

We are a small crew of friends from LA and SF who share a passion for building things, making art, and getting lost in deep playa. We've decided to create a space for wandering souls to take refuge and know that they have finally arrived Nowhere. Or is it Now Here? 

At the edge of the trash fence, the neon glow is a call to all explorers, drifters, and lost sheep. Whether you feel like you have ended up in the middle of Nowhere or are grounded in the moment of Now Here, a welcome seat awaits. 

The letters are made of LED strips diffused by a silicone tube to give a neon glow, and programmed to flicker - as if they really were neon.

The structure is a 9ft tall platform, made to look like 3ft x 3ft x 3ft cubes were stacked together to create stadium style seating on one side of the installation. Facing out towards the sunrise, this space invites anyone nearby to stop for moment, climb to the top, take a seat, admire the view and be with the people surrounding you. 

 

The Nowhere Team is asking for your help!

Your donation goes 100% to procuring materials, transportation, and storage of the installation! The Nowhere team is volunteering their time, skills, and money with a commitment to enhancing your deep playa adventures. The crew is currently self-funding this project and could really use your financial support to ensure we have enough funds to store and transport the project to the playa! 

Expenses

Transportation - $2,000

Materials - $2,500

Storage - $500

You can also help us spread the campaign by sharing it on social media! And please, find your way out to Nowhere during Burning Man and hang out with us. Your participation is the greatest support you can offer.

story:
Short Summary

Join us in this project initiated by Živi Atelje DK (Living Atelier DK), where the past mingles with the future and transforms our present.

Our name, Living Atelier DK, tells it all — “Living,” ever adapting; “Atelier,” ever experimenting; and the initials “DK,” from the artist Vera Dajht-Kralj, the spirit that continues to inspire.

After Vera left us in 2014, we started the art cooperative to honor her legacy and build on what she had developed in nearly 60 years of work in her art studio.

The art studio, her atelier, was always an open and welcoming place of creativity where artists, architects, craftsmen and women, writers, journalists and people from all walks of life and meridians of the globe came for a coffee or a “rakia” drink and conversation. Ideas were exchanged, and joint projects were imagined and developed.

This project – the first exhibition from the heritage collection and a book, specifically an art monograph –  is one more tangible step in the preservation and promotion of her artistic heritage and spirit.

Through your support, you join hands with a diverse group of people already working on the digitalization, cataloguing and preservation of Vera’s collection. So far, thanks almost exclusively to voluntary efforts and individual funds, members of the cooperative managed to catalogue over 2,000 units from this valuable collection and establish an on-line public repository so that others can enjoy and benefit from Vera’s art.

Vera Dajht Kralj (1928 – 2014) is one of the most important sculptresses of the second half of the 20th century in Croatia and the region. In 2015, her art was officially declared as part of the protected cultural heritage of Croatia.

Our work is not just a re-evaluation of Croatian and regional cultural heritage in the global context but also a re-evaluation of women in art, especially sculpture, one of the art disciplines where male sculptors dominated the scene for so long.

On the 3rd of October 2018, we will open the first major exhibition from her collection since her passing, entitled “Beyond Visible - Sculpture, Space and Memory: Public art and commemorative sculpture of Vera Dajht Kralj,” at the Croatian Museum of Architecture of the Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts (HAZU). As part of the exhibition, we will promote the monograph by the same name whose author, Ana Kršinić Lozica, is the curator of the collection and an art historian. She worked on this project with two students of art history and museology, Ana Marija Petričević and Anyla Kabashi, who have integrated their work on the collection to be part of their university thesis and who continue to be an indispensable part of the project.

As an independent non-profit art cooperative, we struggle with funds to make this project come through with the quality it deserves.

Your contribution will enable us to realize this first major goal of an exhibition and monograph. Any donation we collect above the needed amount will solely go toward the protection and restoration of art pieces in danger of degradation. We will also be working on creating virtual exhibitions to expand on the reach of Vera's art.

We invite you to join us now, in the present, and blend the future with the past. When you share in our efforts, you are supporting more than than just the exhibition and book – you also become part of the vision and allow activities at Living Atelier Dajht Kralj to live on.

What We Need & What You Get

For this first step, to realize the exhibition, restore some of the art pieces included in the exhibition and prepare a 300-page bilingual (Croatian-English) comprehensive monograph, we need a total of 21,389  US dollars (136,080 kn). From the City of Zagreb, we secured 4 ,715 US dollars (30,000 kn) and another 1,572 US dollars (10,000 kn) from the Croatian Ministry of Culture.

The remaining 15,102 US dollars (96,080.80 kn) we are looking to collect from sponsors and donors.

Only now, after three years of continuous engagement, volunteering, enthusiasm and passion, we invite you to join in with your contributions. We are proud that we already have a lot to show from our efforts — the catalogued units from Vera's collection, a public repository, and numerous other activities that you can see on our web page and our Facebook page.

As an appreciation for your gesture of support, as you will see in the PERKS section, we offer an array of valuable gifts, each with their own tale for you to share with those around you.

* Preorder a monograph at a discount.

* You can come for an exclusive concert by our honorary members and world class musicians Miroslav Tadić and Yvette Holzwarth.

* We are also releasing a limited edition of screen prints, including some signed by Vera herself.

* SPECIAL ** Become the owner of an original piece of Vera's art by choosing from a selection of her sculptures to cast in bronze. One bronze original is for you and the other for the collection.

— For this last offer please contact us directly, zbirkadajhtkralj@ziviatelje.dk, so we can discuss which sculpture you would be interested in saving from degradation. —

As Living Atelier Dajht Kralj is a place of diversity, we are sure you will find something that suits you perfectly among the perks on offer :-)

The Future

The impact of your contribution does not stop with the closing of the exhibition, it will live on through our preservation work and promotion of Vera's art by finishing the public repository and enabling other students or curators to work on different themes inspired by the collection.

The monograph is just one step in a vision that enables people to engage with one of many aspects of Vera's unique art. The virtual exhibitions we plan to do will set new standards for such exhibitions, reach a wider and younger public, and disseminate the main message of Vera's art — universal love.

In three years of existence, we gained more than 1,800 regular followers over Facebook (a significant number for our age and for where we operate) and we keep growing. Events in our small gallery space attract an average of 100 people per opening whether hosting exhibitions at Gallery DK for young artists graduating from the art academy across the street or more established and international artists. Our "No Borders: Integration of Art-Art of Integration" project traveled to five cities in Croatia and our Women to Women project has changed many lives. We also host the "Wandering Art Tea Academy" and hold workshops in glass blowing and Chinese calligraphy.

We are the continuation of what Vera's atelier has been for 60 years during her lifetime — an open and living atelier. So your contribution and your support is more than just the production of art and protection of cultural heritage. With your support you become part of a vision and lifestyle platform of sharing and love.

Other Ways You Can Help

In the spirit of what we represent and talk about here, money is not the only, nor the most important, contribution.

The most important of all is for you to feel part of our initiative. Spread the word of this campaign in your circles. If you are in Zagreb, or if you visit Zagreb at any stage, give us a ring and come by for a chat or tea (maybe even a rakia).

If you are an expert in any field related to art protection, restoration, digital archives, art management or any other field you think relevant to what we do, please contact us. Your expertise and engagement is priceless. We are eager to hear from you and are most grateful for any support :-)

THANK YOU!

story:
FIRST TIME BURNING MAN ART HONORARIUM RECIPIENT 

Help artist, Kelly Smith Cassidy fund her project, Creu Hudol ("Magical Being" in Welsh). Kelly's "Burnbot" proposal was accepted by the Burning Man Art Committee in early July and will be given a small stipend to jumpstart her project, but she needs help with additional funding for materials and transportation. 

  • Kelly is a full-time professional sculptor living in South Lake Tahoe, CA
  • This is her first Burning Man Honorarium project and it's a BIG ONE! Her sculpture, Creu Hudol will be one of 12 sculptures featured at one of the hour points surrounding The Man in the Pavilion. 
  • Her sculpture has the potential of being seen by tens of thousands of people attending Burning Man and beyond!

WE NEED YOUR HELP TO BRING CREU HUDOL TO BURNING MAN!

What We Need & What You Get

Here's what we need and some cool perks for your contribution:

  • We need $900 to laser cut wood planks to create Creu Hudol's body.
  • $300 is needed to create her crystal headdress.
  • $400 is needed for transportation (including the trailer and gas)
  • $500 is needed to hire a glass blower to create her glass joints.
  • $200 is needed to create the platform that she stands on.
  • $50 is needed to purchase her glass head.

The PERKS!

  • You get your name listed on the official website for Creu Hudol.
  • SWAG! Because everyone loves BM swag, right? Stickers and cards!
  • a handmade welded bronze aspen leaf made by Kelly Cassidy in her welding studio
  • Shout-outs on Kelly's v-logs as she creates Creu Hudol.
  • You can say, "I helped fund that project!" when you come to the Pavilion or when you see the sculpture on videos. 

The Impact

This is a big project for a first-time BM Art Honorarium Recipient. To have a piece in the Pavilion is absolutely fantastic. 

  • Tens of thousands of people attend Burning Man every year and just about every one of them makes it out to the Burning Man Pavilion. So there is a very high visibility
  • Kelly Cassidy has been a full-time professional artist for 21 years. She has a 100% track record of completing projects to spec. 
  • The entire process will be video recorded so you can see how your contributions directly. 
  • Burning Man is a movement that is extraordinary. Those who participate are forever changed. The art seen and experienced on Playa stays within the psyche for eternity. 

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Because this is a very unique project, I expect that there will probably be unforeseen hurdles along the way. Because of this, a cushion fund of $500 will be apportioned 
  • Kelly has a HUGE backing of artist friends and family. As the President of the Tahoe Art League, Kelly has already received several volunteers for the project including world-famous artists and previous artists of large-scale Burning Man Projects. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Can't help? It's OK! Please send this page to others!!

Thank you and Happy Burning!

story:
Short Summary

You Might Die Tomorrow is an art project by Kate Manser to inspire the citizens of Black Rock City to live urgently, love openly, and enjoy your life. Remembering that we will die is the most powerful reminder to live while we're still alive.

The art installation is a 14' wide x 10' tall message in lights: YOU MIGHT DIE TOMORROW. The objective of this piece, tied to the 2018 theme, "I Robot," is to remind the citizens of Black Rock City (and the world) that despite the rush and frightening evolution of technology, we humans are still absolutely, positively, completely mortal -- and for all the unknowns in the world, we might as well enjoy our lives while we're still here.

So many Burners come to BRC each year in search of a new way of living and a radical shift in perspective. Remembering that we are going to die is a profound and universally-accessible key to appreciating the here and now.

Studies show that when people are exposed to concepts of their mortality, we perform tasks better, are more creative, and value collectivism and the present more highly.

Our mortality is, unexpectedly, a source of joy, of motivation to live, and an inspiration to play. We have only now.

You might die tomorrow. So live today.

 

Support this project to bring the inspiring message, YOU MIGHT DIE TOMORROW, to the citizens of Black Rock City. 

 

About Kate

I'm Kate Manser. Here's my story.

In 2013, my 27-year old Manager at Google and my 27-year old college friend died in unrelated, unexpected tragedies. It shocked and terrified me, and I developed a fear of death that began to take over my life: I would imagine getting hit as I crossed an intersection, envision how the phone call would go when I got the news that my mom died, and avoided taking any risks out of fear of the unknown. It completely clouded the beauty of life.

About a year later, my colleague and adventure idol and fellow Burner Dan Fredinburg was killed in the Nepal earthquake while climbing Mount Everest at 33 years old. As I struggled to make sense of the loss, I realized that he knew he might die climbing that mountain, but that he had to climb it to truly live.

In that moment, everything changed for me: I realized that I have absolutely no control over when or how I die -- but I have complete control over how I live until that mystery moment comes. All of the energy I spent on my fear of dying was instantly channeled instead into living every day like I might die tomorrow. 

Since then, I have made radical shifts in my life to better align with my soul -- including quitting my job at Google, traveling around the world for two years, and writing a book about how thinking about your death makes life better -- but no shift has been as radical as my shift in perspective. I live urgently, love wildly, and am so grateful to be alive. 

Life is beautiful.

With love,
-kate the great

 

What I need:

This project is being designed and will be created with an incredible amount of love and care. All funding will go directly to materials for this art installation. 

Materials:

  • Two 200w solar panels and shipping ($600)
  • 150' LED energy-efficient Rope lights and shipping ($400)
  • Guy lines, U-Poles, t-stakes, tools, etc ($150)
  • 200aH deep cycle battery ($100)
  • Stainless steel cable ($70)
  • Lightweight chicken wire ($50)

What your donation will NOT cover:

  • Time, blood, sweat, and tears to create this art: $0

Myself and my project partner are donating our resources, time, work, and creativity for the planning, creation, transportation of the art to and from Black Rock City, installation, on-Playa care, and break down of this art installation.

 

Supporter Perks:

 

Pledge $25 or more: "Congratulations, you're alive!"

One 'You Might Die Tomorrow' sticker sent to you with love.

ESTIMATED DELIVERY: Jul 2018

SHIPS TO: Ships anywhere in the world

 

Pledge $50 or more: "Live to the point of tears." -Camus

Pack of 'You Might Die Tomorrow' stickers in multiple sizes, sent with love.

ESTIMATED DELIVERY: Jul 2018

SHIPS TO: Ships anywhere in the world

 

Pledge $100 or more: Memento Mori

Guided Deathbed Meditation over live video chat with Kate + Pack of 'You Might Die Tomorrow' stickers in multiple sizes, sent with love

ESTIMATED DELIVERY: Jul 2018

SHIPS TO: Ships anywhere in the world

 

Pledge $500 or more: "Make your life spectacular."

Guided Deathbed Meditation in person with Kate at Burning Man or elsewhere to be determined + Pack of 'You Might Die Tomorrow' stickers in multiple sizes, sent with love.

 

Risks & Challenges

It is critical to construct this art piece from strong, stable materials to withstand the harsh conditions of the Black Rock Desert.

It will be a challenge to power bright lights by 100% solar power, but I am committed to using renewable energy. 

My art project partner is experienced in both construction and solar power. Yay for complementary skill sets!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Share this campaign wide and far -- word of mouth, social, your blog, email!
  • Email me a story of how an experience with death -- or simply being reminded of your own death -- radically shifted your perspective on life. 

 

THANK YOU. 

Lots of love,

kate the great

I live urgently, love wildly, and am so grateful to be alive. 
Life is beautiful.
With love,-kate the great
 
What I need:

This project is being designed and will be created with an incredible amount of love and care. All funding will go directly to materials for this art installation. 
Materials:

Two 200w solar panels and shipping ($600)
150' LED energy-efficient Rope lights and shipping ($400)
Guy lines, U-Poles, t-stakes, tools, etc ($150)
200aH deep cycle battery ($100)
Stainless steel cable ($70)
Lightweight chicken wire ($50)

What your donation will NOT cover:
Time, blood, sweat, and tears to create this art: $0
Myself and my project partner are donating our resources, time, work, and creativity for the planning, creation, transportation of the art to and from Black Rock City, installation, on-Playa care, and break down of this art installation.
 

Supporter Perks:
 
Pledge $25 or more: "Congratulations, you're alive!"
One 'You Might Die Tomorrow' sticker sent to you with love.
ESTIMATED DELIVERY: Jul 2018
SHIPS TO: Ships anywhere in the world
 
Pledge $50 or more: "Live to the point of tears." -Camus
Pack of 'You Might Die Tomorrow' stickers in multiple sizes, sent with love.
ESTIMATED DELIVERY: Jul 2018


SHIPS TO: Ships anywhere in the world
 
Pledge $100 or more: Memento Mori
Guided Deathbed Meditation over live video chat with Kate + Pack of 'You Might Die Tomorrow' stickers in multiple sizes, sent with love
ESTIMATED DELIVERY: Jul 2018
SHIPS TO: Ships anywhere in the world

 
Pledge $500 or more: "Make your life spectacular."
Guided Deathbed Meditation in person with Kate at Burning Man or elsewhere to be determined + Pack of 'You Might Die Tomorrow' stickers in multiple sizes, sent with love.

 
Risks & Challenges
It is critical to construct this art piece from strong, stable materials to withstand the harsh conditions of the Black Rock Desert.
It will be a challenge to power bright lights by 100% solar power, but I am committed to using renewable energy. 
My art project partner is experienced in both construction and solar power. Yay for complementary skill sets!
 

Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Share this campaign wide and far -- word of mouth, social, your blog, email!
Email me a story of how an experience with death -- or simply being reminded of your own death -- radically shifted your perspective on life. 

 THANK YOU. Lots of love,kate the great

story:
I'm Katlynn Marie, I live in Texas, I hope to become a professional makeup artist with doing special effects and other body art, I really like doing Horror effects more than most but I hope to do Aliens,Other Creatures,Demons,Fairies and everything else you can  possibly imagine.

I absolutely love doing makeup, I want to make other people happy with it as well, I only have 20 days left and I really hope to reach my goal even though it's a far out amount, Doing makeup is extremely important to me because I love doing it and I want to follow my dream and hell, don’t we all? 

Honestly even a dollar helps a whole lot and If you donate, You're quite lovely.






My obstacles are Earning Money for special effects makeup & props to go along with it, I started a few months ago and I'd like to learn how to do a lot more makeup effects other than just cuts and bruises, I plan on also doing body art and other things like that! I also plan on getting a photographer to do some professional photos of my work.

story:
Invest in Watershed Arts! Help us advance the cause of great visual art in Eugene!

We are a non-profit (501-c3) arts organization founded by volunteers and housed inside The Gallery at the Watershed in Eugene, Oregon. Starting in the spring of 2014, we gathered great teachers and began classes. We organized events and discussions about modern and contemporary visual art. 

We created Eugene’s first steamroller printmaking exhibition enjoyed by over 700 people of all ages.


We saw something missing in our community; a place where adults from all backgrounds could learn about art. Not just take an art class, but touch on the deeper stuff and leave with fresh perceptions. So we’ve been building that place, sending out ripples in the pond, gathering enthusiastic artists and art supporters.

Now we need your donation to keep this momentum going!

We think that the art of our time can lead us to important conversations. Great art is the great connector.

Watershed Arts is helping to make Eugene a thriving visual arts hub. Don’t you agree it’s time? Wouldn’t you like to be a part of that?

Please give. This is a chance to not just “say” you support the arts, but truly help move our city’s culture into the future.

And you’ll get a nifty gift too! Check out the gallery page above and see the amazing art we're giving to donors.

Your donation helps us to “keep the lights on” literally and figuratively, so we can continue stimulating talks and build art connections. We’d love to produce another summer outdoor art experience called Great Big Art.

We can’t run on volunteer hours and good will alone.

Every donation helps!

Together, let’s generate excitement around new art possibilities for Eugene.

Tell others about this campaign. Donate today!

story:
Amo mio padre, ha speso tutta la sua vita per il Museo delle Maioliche Medievali e Rinascimentali Orvietane.

Ho deciso di organizzare una raccolta fondi perché amo mio padre e ho profonda stima per ciò in cui lui ha fortemente creduto: ha speso la sua vita intera e tutte le sue risorse, soprattutto economiche, per rendere visibili al pubblico suggestivi locali ipogei scavati nel tufo e una collezione di ceramica quasi interamente rinvenuta all'interno degli stessi, prodotta da una fornace medievale - rimasta pressoché intatta - e unica del Quattrocento esistente al mondo. Tutto questo lo ha fatto senza usufruire di nessun contributo pubblico.

Il Ministero dei Beni e delle Attività Culturali e del Turismo, attraverso la Soprintendenza per i Beni Architettonici e Paesaggistici dell'Umbria ha riconosciuto l'importanza dei 3000 pezzi della collezione e dei locali del Museo e con un decreto di notifica li ha vincolati (legando luogo di produzione e manufatti) e sottoposti a disposizione di tutela. Un riconoscimento importante dunque, che però non prevede erogazione di fondi.

Il prezzo del biglietto non è sufficiente per coprire i costi di gestione e di manutenzione del Museo che è quindi attualmente chiuso. Per me questo è inaccettabile: voglio credere di vivere in una Nazione che ama il proprio patrimonio artistico e culturale, e uno stato è formato prima di tutto dai suoi Cittadini e dunque è a loro che mi rivolgo, a tutti quegli appassionati d'arte e di storia che non si arrendono al triste destino di un'Italia che non crede abbastanza nella sua inesauribile Bellezza.

Chiunque può dare un piccolo contributo, anche di un euro: verrà ricompensato con una visita gratuita al Museo. Chi non può contribuire economicamente può - se vuole - aiutarmi a sostenere la causa spargendo la voce.

Voglio credere ancora nei sogni. E anche se a volte la tentazione di mollare è forte, penso sempre a un famoso proverbio: "Non arrenderti: rischieresti di farlo un'ora prima del miracolo".

Dicono di noi:

"Un tesoro da salvare" - Vittorio Sgarbi - Critico e storico dell'arte

"Un patrimonio eccezionale, non solo per Orvieto, ma per tutta la storia della Ceramica italiana del Medioevo e del Rinascimento" - Timoty Wilson - Professore d'arte presso l'Università di Oxford

"Questo Museo straordinario, per il suo carattere unico, dovrebbe essere considerato essenziale non solo per la città di Orvieto, ma per tutta l'umanità, e dovrebbe essere salvaguardato, e quindi sottoposto a tutela, conservazione e valorizzazione, come previsto dal Codice dei Beni Culturali" -  Luciano Frazzoni - Direttore del Museo F. Rittatore Vonwiller, Farnese (VT)

"Un patrimonio da salvare" Antonella Frezzolini - Studiosa di ceramica antica


La nostra pagina Facebook: www.facebook.com/ceramicunderground.org

Il nostro sito internet: www.ceramicunderground.org

Ci trovate anche su Twitter: @ceramicundergr


I love my father, he has spent all his life for the Museum of Ceramics.

The Museum suffered a lack of government funding: over the years, the Museum has used its resources to make up the statal shortfall, and this has placed a tremendous strain on our budget.

The closure of the Museum means that it is wrong believing in art, history, culture,
dreams? No, I still want to believe in dreams!

Closing the Museum would be depriving people access to education facilites so vital to our understanding of ceramic history of the whole world. I ask you to help me keep alive the dream of my father. His amazing Museum can not close!

The museum carved out of tufa rock

The Museum premises are particularly inspiring and a remarkable attraction in themselves. Almost entirely carved out of tufa rock, the Museum unveils archaeological structures dating back to the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, such as a fifteenth-century kiln for firing majolicas, which is the only one existing in Italy and, possibly, in the whole world, and is almost intact.  Furthermore, the kiln dumps can be seen too, as well as the structure of a typical winekeeping cellar.

The majolicas are displayed in glass cases fitted to old niches carved out of tufa rock; in some cases the safety glasses have been directly fitted to the walls and wooden structures have been provided for support.  

Both private clients and public institutions have been borrowing the collection exhibits on occasions, whether to make commercial copies or have the town represented in local, national and international exhibitions respectively; furthermore, schools of all grades, including Italian and foreign universities, have benefited from the permanent exhibition for cultural visits and documentation, together with more or less occasional visitors.

It should not be overlooked that, in spite of Orvieto being one of the most famous towns in Italy in the tradition of ceramics, a local Museum specialized in this field had yet to be created therefore it was necessary for someone to fulfil such a need.

Your funding will go 100% towards helping to sustain the Museum.


About us

"A treasure to be saved" - Vittorio Sgarbi - The most important art critic in Italy

"This is an exceptional heritage, not only for Orvieto, but throughout the history of Italian ceramics of the Middle Ages and Renaissance" Timothy Wilson - Professor of the Arts of the Renaissance at Oxford University

"A heritage to be saved" Antonella Frazzolini - Ancient ceramics researcher

"This extraordinary museum, for its unique character, should be considered essential not only for the city of Orvieto, but for all mankind, and should be safeguarded and therefore submitted to protection, conservation and enhancement, as required by the Code of Cultural Heritage" Luciano Frazzoni - Director of the Museum “F.Rittatore Vonwiller” - Farnese (VT)



Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a contribution, I hope you will consider sharing my campaign with your friends, getting the word out and making some noise about my campaign.

Thanks to all!

story:
The aim of the International Urban Art Festival is to bring together street artists, volunteers and activists who will try to reinvent urban myths based on the local folklore and urban legends. Street artists will create their artworks according to dialogue with local residents, both in Minsk and Vilnius.

We are the group of passionate street art addicts who aims to transform the street art movement in post-soviet countries. We would like to bring it to the new level, to show it in the light of contemporary art and to make it useful for local communities.

We would love to see our artworks not just decorating the city, but inspiring its citizens!

Due to the limited funding, but with a great help of our activists and volunteers we were able to organize a mini street art festival in six cities of Belarus during last spring-summer season. That was the first when street artists were able to choose their own object in the city and transform it into a street art masterpiece.

Here are some examples of those magic transformations:

Urban Myths Festival is a new chance for all of us! It’s a chance to rise and shine in a different way, it’s a chance for collaboration between artists and it’s a chance to improve ourselves and our environment.

The unique part of the festival is in the idea of exploration of local mythology and urban legends by street artists. We hope that by doing this we can make artworks to be contextual and assist locals to develop their own urban identity.

We already have:

  • a group of inspired and passionate activists;

  • a support from State Museum (permissions for creating murals);

  • a support from local municipalities;

  • an interest in participation of well-known street artists (here are some examples of their works):

(...Brasil)

(...Ukraine)

(...Russia)

(...France)

(...Spain)

(...Poland)

...and we hope:

some artists from Norway and USA...

___

We recognize that this project requires some funding and this is where we need your help. We are currently expecting some investments from several sponsors, but their support won’t cover all our expenses.

The amount we want to collect is needed for the initial start of the project:

  • development of the website which is intended to promote the Festival, spread the word and attract sponsors;

  • cover visa and travel costs for prospect participants;

  • cover payments for full-time coordinator position (managing work with municipality, project logistics, etc.)

Your support can make a real difference, can inspire hundreds of people and organize a really great Festival!

Thank you!

story:
http://www.gondolas4all.com/sostienici/


click here  for Italian language

Accessing facilities means living life to the full, sharing spaces and opportunities for meeting other people.

This is everyone’s right, enshrined in the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which rules that States Parties should take appropriate measures to ensure that persons with disabilities have access to the physical environment and to transportation, among other things. 

Visiting a unique special city like Venice on board a GONDOLA, one of the symbols of Venice, is not possible for wheelchair users. This is NOT RIGHT.   

GONDOLAS4ALL ONLUS aims to  solve this problem:

  • gondolas must be accessible to everyone, including wheelchair users:
  • wheelchair users must be able to get into a gondola safely and independently
  • Venice must become an even more accessible city

The Gondolas4All project goes back to the beginning of 2012 and was developed from an idea of Alessandro Dalla Pieta’, aged 38 and a gondolier with twenty years of experience, and Enrico Greifenberg, his friend and colleague. The project has already obtained 50 thousand euros from the Veneto Regional Authorities, who are committed to supporting the development of accessible tourism in the lagoon city.

GONDOLAS4ALL has designed a completely new solution, never previously implemented: the construction of a special jetty combined with an automatic wheelchair lift, able to transfer wheelchair users onto the gondola in a safe controlled way. 

The special jetty: this is a floating jetty made entirely of recycled plastic obtained from tetrapak processing and produced by the company Rein. 

Access to the jetty is provided by a non-slip ramp.  

The automatic wheelchair lift: the jetty is provided with a special lift; the wheelchair is fixed to the lift which, by means of two motors, moves it and positions it directly in the gondola, a simple safe operation. The automatic wheelchair lift will be produced by Fadiel, a leading company in Europe specialising in equipment for the disabled.

  • The person can remain comfortably seated in his/her manual wheelchair
  • It adapts to different types of motor disability 
  • Boarding is performed in complete safety 

The Gondolas4All gondoliers are expert purposely trained operators: they have all followed a course provided by UILDM VENEZIA (Italian Association of Muscular Dystrophy) and have obtained certification in the following:

  • disability terminology;
  • knowledge of different disabilities and related mobility needs;
  • knowledge of relational/emotional aspects. 

The financing will be used to produce the first accessible jetty complete with automatic wheelchair lift which will be built by the company Rein. 

The jetty has been designed by the Venice firm of architects and engineers “Studio di Architetti e Ingegneri Moro Venezia” (and already submitted at the end of 2013 to the Venice town planning department). 

The automatic wheelchair lift will be produced by Fadiel, a leading company in Europe specialising in equipment for the disabled, which has already designed for Volvo a seat which can lift a person into a lorry cab.  

The first special jetty complete with automatic wheelchair lift will be installed in Venice in Piazzale Roma, the point of arrival for cars and buses with the railway station nearby.  

View Google Maps 

Regione del Veneto
 Village for all - V4A® 

Village for all supports the Gondolas4All project because travel is a way of discovering the world and Venice can only be truly discovered by gondola. Our brand V4A® will provide international recognition, based on the unique quality of this project.

Fadiel   

     Architetti e Ingegneri Moro  Venezia

   Rein 

Cooperativa Gondolieri – Traghetto Ferrovia

  LogoPro


  ITALIAN   LANGUAGE

Accedere alle strutture significa partecipare alla realtà, condividere gli spazi e le occasioni di incontro.

Accedere all’esperienza vuole dire vivere.
Questo è un diritto per tutti, sancito dalla carta dei diritti dell’ONU per le persone disabili.

Visitare una città unica e speciale come Venezia, a bordo di un’imbarcazione nata nella storia di quella città, la GONDOLA, oggi non è possibile per chi utilizza una carrozzina. Noi pensiamo che NON sia giusto!!

GONDOLAS4ALL Onlus è nata per questo:

  • salire sulla gondola deve essere possibile per tutti, anche per chi usa la carrozzina;
  • bisogna poterlo fare con sicurezza e autonomia;
  • Venezia deve diventare una città ancora più accessibile. 

GONDOLAS4ALL ha progettato una soluzione del tutto nuova, mai realizzata prima: la costruzione di un pontile speciale associato ad una pedana automatica, in grado di portare la persona in carrozzina a bordo della gondola in modo sicuro e controllato 

Il pontile speciale: è un pontile galleggiante costruito completamente con plastiche riciclabili ottenuto dalla lavorazione del tetrapak e realizzato dalla ditta Rein. L'accesso alla banchina avviene percorrendo una rampa antiscivolo.

La pedana automatica: sul pontile si trova una pedana speciale; la carrozzina viene fissata alla pedana che, grazie a due motori, la sposta e la colloca direttamente nella gondola con una manovra semplice e sicura. La pedana automatica sarà prodotta dalla società Fadiel, azienda leader in Europa e specializzata in ausili per disabili. 

  • la persona può rimanere comodamente seduta nella propria carrozzina manuale a spinta;
  • si adatta a diversi tipi di disabilità motoria;
  • la manovra di imbarco avviene in modo sicuro.

I gondolieri di Gondolas4All sono esperti e specializzati: con un corso di formazione della UILDM (Unione Italiana Lotta alla Distrofia Muscolare) hanno ottenuto un attestato e delle competenze su:

  • terminologia relativa alla disabilità; 
  • competenze rispetto alle diverse disabilità e relative esigenze di mobilità;
  • competenze in ambito relazionale/emotivo.

Il finanziamento serve a realizzare il primo pontile accessibile completo di pedana automatica che sarà costruito dalla ditta Rein.
Il pontile è stato progettato dallo Studio di Architetti e Ingegneri Moro di Venezia (e già presentato alla fine del 2013 agli uffici di Edilizia Privata del Comune di Venezia).
La pedana automatica sarà prodotta dalla società Fadiel, azienda leader in Europa e specializzata in ausili per disabili, che ha già progettato per Volvo un sedile in grado di far salire una persona fino alla cabina del camion. 

Il primo pontile speciale completo di pedana automatica sarà costruito a Venezia in Piazzale Roma, punto di arrivo con le auto, gli autobus e i treni. 

Vedi sulla mappa

Regione del Veneto

Village for all - V4A®

Village for all supports the Gondolas4All project because travel is a way of discovering the world and Venice can only be truly discovered by gondola. Our brand V4A® will provide international recognition, based on the unique quality of this project.

Fadiel   

Architetti e Ingegneri Moro Venezia

story_txt:
http://www.gondolas4all.com/sostienici/


click here  for Italian language




Accessing facilities means living life to the full, sharing spaces and opportunities for meeting other people.
This is everyone’s right, enshrined in the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which rules that States Parties should take appropriate measures to ensure that persons with disabilities have access to the physical environment and to transportation, among other things. 


Visiting a unique special city like Venice on board a GONDOLA, one of the symbols of Venice, is not possible for wheelchair users. This is NOT RIGHT.   
GONDOLAS4ALL ONLUS aims to  solve this problem:





gondolas must be accessible to everyone, including wheelchair users:


wheelchair users must be able to get into a gondola safely and independently


Venice must become an even more accessible city


The Gondolas4All project goes back to the beginning of 2012 and was developed from an idea of Alessandro Dalla Pieta’, aged 38 and a gondolier with twenty years of experience, and Enrico Greifenberg, his friend and colleague. The project has already obtained 50 thousand euros from the Veneto Regional Authorities, who are committed to supporting the development of accessible tourism in the lagoon city.

GONDOLAS4ALL has designed a completely new solution, never previously implemented: the construction of a special jetty combined with an automatic wheelchair lift, able to transfer wheelchair users onto the gondola in a safe controlled way. 





The special jetty: this is a floating jetty made entirely of recycled plastic obtained from tetrapak processing and produced by the company Rein. 
Access to the jetty is provided by a non-slip ramp.  
The automatic wheelchair lift: the jetty is provided with a special lift; the wheelchair is fixed to the lift which, by means of two motors, moves it and positions it directly in the gondola, a simple safe operation. The automatic wheelchair lift will be produced by Fadiel, a leading company in Europe specialising in equipment for the disabled.






The person can remain comfortably seated in his/her manual wheelchair


It adapts to different types of motor disability 


Boarding is performed in complete safety 




The Gondolas4All gondoliers are expert purposely trained operators: they have all followed a course provided by UILDM VENEZIA (Italian Association of Muscular Dystrophy) and have obtained certification in the following:



disability terminology;


knowledge of different disabilities and related mobility needs;

knowledge of relational/emotional aspects. 







The financing will be used to produce the first accessible jetty complete with automatic wheelchair lift which will be built by the company Rein. 
The jetty has been designed by the Venice firm of architects and engineers “Studio di Architetti e Ingegneri Moro Venezia” (and already submitted at the end of 2013 to the Venice town planning department). 
The automatic wheelchair lift will be produced by Fadiel, a leading company in Europe specialising in equipment for the disabled, which has already designed for Volvo a seat which can lift a person into a lorry cab.  



The first special jetty complete with automatic wheelchair lift will be installed in Venice in Piazzale Roma, the point of arrival for cars and buses with the railway station nearby.  





View Google Maps 


Regione del Veneto

Fadiel

ITALIAN   LANGUAGE








Accedere alle strutture significa partecipare alla realtà, condividere gli
spazi e le occasioni di incontro.
Accedere all’esperienza vuole dire vivere.
Questo è un diritto per tutti, sancito dalla carta dei diritti dell’ONU
per le persone disabili.
Visitare una città unica e speciale come Venezia, a bordo di
un’imbarcazione nata nella storia di quella città, la GONDOLA, oggi
non è possibile per chi utilizza una carrozzina. Noi pensiamo che
NON sia giusto!!
GONDOLAS4ALL Onlus è nata per questo:



salire sulla gondola deve essere possibile per tutti, anche per chi usa la carrozzina;


bisogna poterlo fare con sicurezza e autonomia;


Venezia deve diventare una città ancora più accessibile. 














GONDOLAS4ALL ha progettato una soluzione del tutto nuova, mai
realizzata prima: la costruzione di un pontile speciale associato ad
una pedana automatica, in grado di portare la persona in carrozzina a
bordo della gondola in modo sicuro e controllato 














Il pontile speciale: è un pontile
galleggiante costruito
completamente con plastiche
riciclabili ottenuto dalla lavorazione
del tetrapak e realizzato dalla ditta Rein. L'accesso alla banchina avviene percorrendo una rampa antiscivolo.












La pedana automatica: sul pontile si
trova una pedana speciale; la
carrozzina viene fissata alla pedana
che, grazie a due motori, la sposta e
la colloca direttamente nella
gondola con una manovra semplice
e sicura. La pedana automatica sarà
prodotta dalla società Fadiel,
azienda leader in Europa e
specializzata in ausili per disabili. 



















la persona può rimanere comodamente seduta nella propria carrozzina manuale a spinta;


si adatta a diversi tipi di disabilità motoria;


la manovra di imbarco avviene in modo sicuro.





I gondolieri di Gondolas4All sono esperti e specializzati: con un corso di formazione della UILDM (Unione Italiana Lotta alla Distrofia Muscolare) hanno ottenuto un attestato e delle competenze su:



terminologia relativa alla disabilità; 


competenze rispetto alle diverse disabilità e relative esigenze di mobilità;

competenze in ambito relazionale/emotivo.
















Il finanziamento serve a realizzare il primo pontile accessibile
completo di pedana automatica che sarà costruito dalla ditta Rein.
Il pontile è stato progettato dallo Studio di Architetti e Ingegneri Moro
di Venezia (e già presentato alla fine del 2013 agli uffici di Edilizia
Privata del Comune di Venezia).
La pedana automatica sarà prodotta dalla società Fadiel, azienda
leader in Europa e specializzata in ausili per disabili, che ha già
progettato per Volvo un sedile in grado di far salire una persona fino
alla cabina del camion. 















Il primo pontile speciale completo di pedana automatica sarà
costruito a Venezia in Piazzale Roma, punto di arrivo con le auto, gli
autobus e i treni.
