Use the Indiegogo share tools! ASK OTHERS TO CONTRIBUTE.   .

story:
My name is Kathy and my life changed 36 years ago when I started working for Wisconsin Disability Coalition, a cross disability advocacy organization. Starting out I knew nothing about disability, but I met so many interesting talented people with all sorts of disabilities. I also met an amazing man, who happened to have a C-4 Spinal Cord injury; it was love at first sight. We married in 1983. We became foster parents, using our experience with disabilities to specialize in kids with disabilities which led us to realize that these kids were not getting the services they needed. As our kids aged they had trouble transitioning into adulthood. I had this idea . . . what if we could have a place where they could work on their creative talents and sell the creations in a Gallery? The idea for Indigo Wings began to form more fully year after year.

Six of those foster kids became our family, but all the love and support was not enough, they still struggled. Now that they are all in their 20’s, struggling to find jobs and support themselves, we realized it was time to make Indigo Wings a reality. In the process of researching the area we found other adults with similar stories who wanted to join us. That is when the dream really took wings. We could help more people if we could offer classes and studio space.

The perfect rental space at the perfect price became available. We became a 501(c)(3), all the paper work was done and filed. The purpose of Indigo Wings is to help people with disabilities become more financially and vocationally independent through the expression of their creativity. We use the broad definition of disability established in the American’s with Disabilities Act which turns 25 this year. So many people with disabilities exist at the poverty level; more than 80% are unemployed. We can now help some of them earn a supplemental income and the hope of a career.

We need help to get the Studio and Gallery up and running.

I mentioned the perfect rental space at the perfect price, well that’s because all of the demolition and remodeling is our responsibility. We need to buy paint, drywall screws, a new sink, bathroom mirror, faucet and door hardware, a computer/inventory/register device, picture rails to display art, other display pieces to showcase our jewelry, cards, soaps and many other items. We also need to patch drywall, replace some flooring, replace light fixtures, purchase painting easels, paint, brushes and much more.  We need $5,000.00 dollars to purchase all of the items we need to open our doors. The volunteers have already begun the demolition and cleaning and we have more standing by as soon as we can get the supplies.  

What’s in it for you? I thought about why I contribute to campaigns and my main reason is because I think that my contribution, combined with others can make a difference. One of our artists is in her 50’s, has had MS for two decades, and now has retinitis pigmentosa, she is divorced and lives on her SSDI, she also works part time helping others with disabilities, to make ends meet. Money she earns selling her beautiful art work will help her stay in the home she has lived in for more than 20 years and knows very well. We want to make her life better, multiply that by 10 or 20 or 100. This will not cure cancer, but it will help make people’s lives better.

We are committed to a 12 month lease so we do not have the option to fail. Any and all funds will be used for this campaign.  Everything earned above the $5,000 will be put towards keeping our doors open and funding for educational programs.

The Impact

Indigo Wings can help this community by providing mentoring and training to people with disabilities in need of support to make money from their artistic endeavors. We have sold jewelry and photography at conferences in the past, but it really limited the number of people we could help and there was no space other than my dining room to create. With a Gallery and Studio there will be plenty of space to create and we can be open 7 days a week. When you create something and another person values it enough to purchase it, there is a sense of pride and accomplishment. We want to help people feel that pride and know that they have value. Our Sellers Permit is valid as of July 1, 2015. The faster we can get this Gallery finished the sooner we open to the public.

Risks & Challenges

Does this scare me? Very much! I started to put things together, file incorporation papers, 1023EZ (it actually was), do the Webinars offered by the SBA, listen to all the statistics, write a Business Plan, find Board Members, talk to everyone, and get opinions and advice. We are ready to do this; we have committed artists who have a lot to offer.

 I just failed to account for the expense of making the space ready, it was so big and priced well below market. This is where you come in; your contribution will directly help us help others. With the materials, we will fix the holes, paint, make it pretty and open a Gallery to showcase exceptional art from creative talented people, check a few of them out at www.indigowingsinc.com 

Other Ways You Can Help

Perhaps you can’t contribute money right now, I understand that, every spare dime I had has gone into getting us this far. We need your help to make this happen; you can help get the word out to people in your network. Don’t forget to use the Indiegogo sharing tools!

story:
The SoulBloom Project

SoulBloom is a growing community and online platform for emerging artists and creatives. The SoulBloom project aims to inspire and ignite the creative spark within each of us, and empower artists to become change agents within their local communities. We are building community centered around creativity, cooperation, and collaborative inspiration. The SoulBloom project also represents a reconnection to the sacred feminine energy of the Earth, Shakti or simply - creation. We invite you to connect with your creative energy within. 

Who we are: Michelle & Kelly (co-founders) and a growing artist collective. Find us on FB at www.facebook.com/soulbloomart and on the web at www.soul-bloom.co

It is time for us to expand our efforts and impact both online & locally. This campaign will help us raise money to:

  • Launch our merchandise line in collaboration with SoulBloom artist collective
  • Rebuild and reformat our website: expenses incurred, website redevelopment
  • Funding for SoulBloom events: Next SoulBloom creative gathering is Aug  16, 2015 in Washington D.C.
  • Build fund for artist bookings at events
  • Purchase materials for mobile art gallery
  • Podcast development & beginning stages of app development

The Breakdown:

$5,555:

  • $1,255- Merchandise line & Website development
  • $2,000- Event funding
  • $1,500- Mobile Art gallery
  • $800- Podcast development, beginning stages of app development
A HUGE THANK YOU to the following artists that have pledged their support for this campaign by sending in an art donation which will be used as incentive for campaign donations: Sam Farrand, Emily Kell, Annie Bennett, Jim Figora, Randal Roberts, Drake Arnold, Tyler Epe, John Gay 
SoulBloom in the Community
We exist humbly to inspire all forms of creativity in the community. 

"Roaming Gypsy Tea & Art Tent" SoulBloom & Antler Alchemy collaboration at Forward Fest DC 2015

Autumn Skye supporting the SoulBloom Project at Unifier Festival 2014 

DanceSafe Fundraiser at U Street Music Hall 2014

The Art of Nicholas Daily - DanceSafe Fundraiser at U Street Music Hall 2014

SoulBloom artist collective at the Vine party Washington D.C, 2015

Michelle & Kelly, Founders

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word about this campaign!!
  • Like us on FB, Follow us on Twitter & Instagram, FB: facebook.com/soulbloomart, Twitter: @Soul_Bloom, Instagram: _soulbloom_

story:
Carla Brown, the owner of the Hive, and Michelle Armstrong, local artist and art teacher at Cardinal Valley Elementary in Lexington, KY are working to raise funds to paint a mural of a beehive and native KY flowers on the side of the Hive Salon at 156 Deweese Street in downtown Lexington along with the help of some students from the area. The goals of this project are to 1) revitalize Deweese Street and downtown Lex with public art 2) engage community and students in creating art 3) raise awareness of the declination of the honey bee population.

 The Hive is an important gathering place for the downtown community and we would like to bring public art to this area of Lexington and also raise awareness about the declination of the honeybee population. We have invited several student groups to assist us in painting this mural such as art club students from the  Sisophromateum Art Foundation, students in the High Street YMCA summer camp, the LexArts Youth Council, art club students from William Wells Brown and art club students from Cardinal Valley Elementary school.

The design will consist of a dynamic color range and will have bees coming from the “hive” and pollinating various native Kentucky flowers. There will also be some native Kentucky birds integrated in the mural design. The largest part of the mural will be on the wall that is facing the parking lot (the South facing wall). The mural will also be painted on the top part of the back wall and the top part of the North facing wall with extending flowers so that the mural will create an effect that extends beyond the one wall and effectively “wraps” the building in color (only the top part of the wall can be seen from Elm Tree Lane).  The front entrance will also be painted with another extension of bees/ flowers to tie the whole piece together.

The community needs more beautification and recently lost a mural that was located on a building on the corner of Short St and Elm Tree Lane. This mural would bring new public art to Elm Tree Lane and the area.  The community would be enhanced with a new mural in the area and students from William Wells Brown, Cardinal Valley elementary school, Sisophromateum Art Foundation ART club, The High St YMCA summer camp program and the LexArts Youth council would be engaged in assisting with creating the mural as well. We also plan to host an event when the mural is completed to teach the community about the things that we can all do to improve conditions for the honey bees.

story:
Short Summary

“I wasn't really naked. I simply didn't have any clothes on.” 
― Josephine Baker

*art has the power to showcase the shadows that linger over our bones, through the resuscitated stories of our ancestors and the dreamings of our sunflower seeds/i believe art is the artifact earthlings remember far after bodies have transcended/so here i go, along with a few members of the MBCollective, MBC, {MargaretBurroughs-MaryMcCleodBethune-MoBettaBlues} to visit the spaces that enlightened a generation of artist retelling their african herhisstories. This piece, In Search of my Unfamiliar, a three year installation/iteration/exploration/activation, is about our, members of MBC, journeys back into a far far away time. we are actively searching the remnants of our peoples people peoples and continuing the next sixteen bars on their jazzy track~ 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Miles/Airfare D.C. to Paris and train cash to Berlin then back to D.C. 
  • All funds collected will be used for the trip! help me reach this goal!! 

The Impact

eARTh without ART is eh! it is VITAL that we study, labor and exchange our stories! 

  • I want to be the master of my experience and share my craft to facilitate the same vibrant joy I feel with others. Your liberation is tied to mine. 
  • Facilitating art as a healing practice has enabled many young people and adults to center them first in their lives and create the culture of community and clear and effective communication within their spaces.
  • I believe our journeys are linked so join with me in reaching forward while holding your hand. 

Risks & Challenges

Not getting fully funded! 

  • My main goal is to get the airline ticket for under $1000 while the rate is that low. I need your help in keeping my budget, in budget! 
  • I totally have faith in the UNIverse to send the things needed my way. For Real! 

Other Ways You Can Help

ENERGY

  • Spread the word through emails, conversations, postings, etc etc etc 
  • Send your positive vibrations my way so that I am fully covered spiritually, physically and financially!!! 

THANK YOU~ Blessings!

story:
Welcome to the Yokna Sculpture Trail


A rotating public art project featuring 18 large scale sculptures by locally, regionally, and nationally renowned artists. A collaboration between the City of Oxford, The University of Mississippi and the Yoknapatawpha Arts Council this free public sculpture trail is the first of its kind in North Mississippi.

The sculpture trail links different parts of the community by placing public works of art on the campus of the University of Mississippi, in the Downtown Historic District and in a public park in a residential neighborhood. The trail connects the community through art providing a source of enjoyment that connects the green spaces with our arts and culture.

The trail connects the community through art providing a source of enjoyment that connects the green spaces with our arts and culture.

story:
We have just $1,500 to go! Please click here to help our Kickstarter.           

   

Update - June 22, 2015: We've added some new IndieGogo Perks - Your Own Glorious Infinity Mirror ($45 to $750 options)


‘Wonder of wonders! HOLD ONTO YOUR Knickers!


Prepare to be h​ypnotized,​ mesmerized,​and e​lectrified! ​

This attraction promises to bend reality to new levels as yet unseen by the masses. Be among the first to reemerge reawakened and revitalized from a reflective walk through The Gallery of Infinity! 

  

What is The Gallery of Infinity?

It’s a sideshow attraction displaying an array of various infinity mirrors to create wild effects and optical illusions within sprawling corridors. The installation involves walls built with layers of plexiglass sheets. Within the sheets, are LED bands that are hooked to proximity sensors to change colors schemes based on the movement of passing visitors. This structure creates a mind-boggling effect of colorful, dazzling lights that reflect into apparent infinity. Multiple walls will create an infinity mirror system to offer an incredible visual experience and disorienting sense of reality different from the one which many of us are accustomed to. These visuals will push visitors to be more critical of the paths they navigate and compel them to question the accuracy of their perceptions.


Perk: Personal Desktop Infinity Mirror

               A talker will attempt to lure passersby off the Midway, the spiel will tempt and entice them to dare to enter this mind altering reality and emerge differently from whence they came in. Many of us autopilot through physical spaces, and have learned to not be especially critical of our own biases and heuristics. These biases leave us vulnerable to spatial illusions, and that’s what we intend to exploit. 


               This infinity gallery illusion will provide a unique opportunity to inspect physical spaces with a more discerning eye, as visitors enjoy the ability to peer off into seemingly endless tunnels of light. This project promises to be a bizarre, eye opening experience, mildly disorienting and visually thrilling, while altering the visitors’ natural sensibilities to navigate through space.

Features & Goals

The base structure alone (including travel) is expected to cost at least $8,000. Additional features are included based on funding. Below is a diagram of our layout (black walls are infinity mirror panels) and some examples of what we plan to include:

A Body Sensing Camera and Reactive LED Wall

Using the Microsoft Kinect, one hallway of the installation will detect the shape of a person's body and project this onto a wall of LED strands. The colors will change for each person (e.g., body 1 = red, body 2 = green, etc.) and you can transfer color by touching one another. Below is an example of the camera in action!

MOVING Infinity Mirrors Powered by Motors

Motor Powered Infinity Panels? WHAT!? Yes. We will move the damn mirrors within the infinity panels using corkscrew motors to create an INSANE moving tunnel effect. We are working with a PhD student of computer engineering (robotics emphasis) to design movement within the infinity mirrors. This will be nuts.

Proximity & Motion Sensitive Hallways 

The infinity mirror walls will change based on the movement of people passing through and depending upon how close one is to approaching the wall. This will allow us to change hallways and light patterns depending on visitor location. For example, walls of light that seem to follow the visitor and then change color schemes and flash depending on location.

An infinite Playa Horizon  

Upon exiting, the last wall will have a long (width-­wise) infinity mirror that has lights only on the top and bottom of the mirror. This will create an infinite horizon effect as visitors exit the installation. The horizon will have black­light paint and EL wire to create landmark structures such as The Man and Temple of Promise. 

Hallway of Masks  

At eye level, one of the corridors will include multiple frames of infinity mirrors with holographic head­-sized stickers of various masks. As visitors pass through, they will be able to view their own reflections superimposed with the masks displayed in the mirror. 


Touch Interactive 3D Infinity Cubes & Pyramids

A 3-sided pyramid and 4-sided cube of connected infinity mirrors. The sides will have touch capacitive sensors so that the sculpture’s color changes based on the number of visitors touching it simultaneously. (For example, an entire pyramid is green with 1 touch, sides pulsate green & blue with 2 touches.)

Showcasing Local Artists

We're experimenting with different methods of using blacklight paint, EL wire and reflective objects to create infinity panels with -insane- effects for paintings. Local artists are invited to paint panels to showcase their works. Message us at Facebook.com/GalleryOfInfinity if you're interested!

And more...

Yes, more! Depending on funding, we can fill the space with different infinity sculptures and installations. The possibilities are essentially boundless, (or you could say infinite...) on what we can incorporate into this awesome attraction. 

If we reach...

$7,000 - It happens! We can include the hallway of masks, some reactive panels, but no sculptures. 

$8,000 - 724 sq feet of infinity panels with several surprise interactive ones.

$9,000 - We can make most infinity panels interactive &  include 2 touch-reactive sculptures.

How you can be part of something big:

There are many ways you can contribute:
  • Donate! Donations are the bread and butter of what makes this possible. Click Here to Support the Cause!
  • Like us on Facebook and share our posts. Click here to see our FB page!
  • Spread the word. Use the IndieGogo share tool to show this campaign to your friends and family.
  • If you're in the Bay Area, visit us at our weekly Monday builds! Just message us.
  • Join Us! - Can you write? Create? Perform? Build? Enjoy onsite promotions? Contact us to get involved! Click Here!

Meet the Team

Max Ziegler/Ziggy (Lead) - Construction Captain | Installation Design 
Over 8 years of experience in construction and building hobbyist. This will be Ziggy's 3rd burn.

Victoria Hollis (Lead) - Fundraising | Installation Design | Production
Human-Computer Interaction researcher & designer. This will be Victoria's 3rd burn. 

Dillon Temple - Promotion | Build Team

Pooz Creek - Fundraising | Promotion | Morale

Keleos N. - Fundraising | Promotion | Build Team

Jo Plante - Fundraising | Build Team

Mary O. - Fundraising | Volunteer Coordination

Will S. - Promotion | Event Production

Bronwyn M. - Promotion | Fundraising

Kyle G. - Graphic Design | Promotion

Andrew L. - Graphic Design

Gary & Iain ('The Irish') - Build Team | Promotion 

Jon W. - Fundraising | Promotion | Build Team

story_txt:
We have just $1,500 to go! Please click here to help our Kickstarter.              


Update - June 22, 2015: We've added some new IndieGogo Perks - Your Own Glorious Infinity Mirror ($45 to $750 options)








‘Wonder of wonders! HOLD ONTO YOUR Knickers!


Prepare to be h​ypnotized,​
mesmerized,​and e​lectrified! ​


This attraction promises to bend reality to new levels as
yet unseen by the masses. Be among the first to reemerge reawakened and
revitalized from a reflective walk through The Gallery of Infinity! 

  



What is The Gallery of Infinity?
It’s a sideshow attraction displaying an array of various infinity mirrors to create wild effects and optical illusions within sprawling corridors. The installation involves walls built with layers of plexiglass sheets. Within the sheets, are LED bands that are hooked to proximity sensors to change colors schemes based on the movement of passing visitors. This structure creates a mind-boggling effect of colorful, dazzling lights that reflect into apparent infinity. Multiple walls will create an infinity mirror
system to offer an incredible visual experience and disorienting sense of reality
different from the one which many of us are accustomed to. These visuals will
push visitors to be more critical of the paths they navigate and compel them to
question the accuracy of their perceptions.

Perk: Personal Desktop Infinity Mirror













               A talker will attempt to lure passersby off the Midway, the spiel will tempt and entice them to dare to enter this mind altering reality and emerge differently from whence they came in. Many of us
autopilot through physical spaces, and have learned to not be especially critical of our own biases and heuristics. These biases leave us vulnerable to spatial illusions, and that’s what we intend to exploit. 

               This infinity gallery illusion will provide a unique opportunity to inspect physical spaces with a more discerning eye, as visitors enjoy the ability to peer off into seemingly endless tunnels of light. This project promises to be a bizarre, eye opening experience, mildly disorienting and visually thrilling, while altering the visitors’ natural sensibilities to navigate through space.









  


Features & Goals

The base structure alone (including travel) is expected to cost at least $8,000. Additional features are included based on funding. Below is a diagram of our layout (black walls are infinity mirror panels) and some examples of what we plan to include:


A Body Sensing Camera and Reactive LED Wall
Using the Microsoft Kinect, one hallway of the installation will detect the shape of a person's body and project this onto a wall of LED strands. The colors will change for each person (e.g., body 1 = red, body 2 = green, etc.) and you can transfer color by touching one another. Below is an example of the camera in action!


MOVING Infinity Mirrors Powered by Motors

Motor Powered Infinity Panels? WHAT!? Yes. We will move the damn mirrors within the infinity panels using corkscrew motors to create an INSANE moving tunnel effect. We are working with a PhD student of computer engineering (robotics emphasis) to design movement within the infinity mirrors. This will be nuts.

Proximity & Motion Sensitive Hallways 


The infinity mirror walls will change based on the movement of people passing through and depending upon how close one is to approaching the wall. This will allow us to change hallways and light patterns depending on visitor location. For example, walls of light that seem to follow the visitor and then change color schemes and flash depending on location.

An infinite Playa Horizon  

Upon exiting, the last wall will have a long (width-­wise) infinity mirror that has lights only on the top and bottom of the mirror. This will create an infinite horizon effect as visitors exit the installation. The horizon will have black­light paint and EL wire to create landmark structures such as The Man and Temple of Promise. 

Hallway of Masks  

At eye level, one of the corridors will include multiple frames of infinity mirrors with holographic head­-sized stickers of various masks. As visitors pass through, they will be able to view their own reflections superimposed with the masks displayed in the mirror. 






Touch Interactive 3D Infinity Cubes & Pyramids
A 3-sided pyramid and 4-sided cube of connected infinity mirrors. The sides will have touch capacitive sensors so that the sculpture’s color changes based on the number of visitors touching it simultaneously. (For example, an entire pyramid is green with 1 touch, sides pulsate green & blue with 2 touches.)
Showcasing Local Artists
We're experimenting with different methods of using blacklight paint, EL wire and reflective objects to create infinity panels with -insane- effects for paintings. Local artists are invited to paint panels to showcase their works. Message us at Facebook.com/GalleryOfInfinity if you're interested!


And more...

Yes, more! Depending on funding, we can fill the space with different infinity sculptures and installations. The possibilities are essentially boundless, (or you could say infinite...) on what we can incorporate into this awesome attraction. 


If we reach...
$7,000 - It happens! We can include the hallway of masks, some reactive panels, but no sculptures. 
$8,000 - 724 sq feet of infinity panels with several surprise interactive ones.
$9,000 - We can make most infinity panels interactive &  include 2 touch-reactive sculptures.
How you can be part of something big:
There are many ways you can contribute:


Donate! Donations are the bread and butter of what makes this possible. Click Here to Support the Cause!

Like us on Facebook and share our posts. Click here to see our FB page!
Spread the word. Use the IndieGogo share tool to show this campaign to your friends and family.
If you're in the Bay Area, visit us at our weekly Monday builds! Just message us.

Join Us! - Can you write? Create? Perform? Build? Enjoy onsite promotions? Contact us to get involved! Click Here!

story:
TriPod is a massive landmark that is a stage, a homing laser platform, an aerial swing, and just a massive structure that will be a visible landmark for all of us. It was created by artist Rob Bucholz for the Circus Maximus Arena of 2010....but has been in storage since.

WE NEED YOUR HELP.......this is a huge object......the artist has graciously donated this to the community.......but there are FIXED COSTS !!!

Private donors have already arranged for its storage in Gerlach, but we require funds to repair, transport, erect, and take down this huge piece of steel and concrete.

PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE........give what you can.......the cost of your Martini at your favorite hipster bar in Brooklyn, SF, or London.....the pleasure you get back will be tenfold multiple........ )'(  

PS - FireEaters, Trapeze Artists, Performers of all sorts WANTED !! Msg us !! 


Total weight: 18,440 lbs

Foundation block: 3,300 lbs

Elevated slab: 5,700 lbs

​10" structured steel: 1,220 lbs

12" structured steel: 1,080 lbs

Rigging attachments: 540 lbs

story:
The Hung Tao Choy Mei leadership Institute a Washington, DC based non-profit youth development organization is seeking to raise $35,000 during its 20th anniversary year to refit its existing 800 square feet of open training space into a performing arts studio for weekend use primarily by the areas youth and young adults. We seek to provide a professional live performance venue named “The Artists’ Workshop” for aspiring artists to polish their craft in a safe and secure environment under the guidance and supervision of seasoned professionals. There will not be any food or beverages served and any revenue generated will be through donations offered to our non-profit organization. We will also invite leading professional artists in all genres to conduct Master Workshops on “Creative Sundays” which is every Sunday between 1:00pm and 6:00pm. Friday and Saturday evenings between 7:00pm and 9:00pm (youth) and 10:00pm to 1:00pm (young adults) will be reserved for live performances on an open mic format. We estimate that our costs will be as follows: renovation to men’s and women’s bathrooms and changing areas = $14:000; electrical upgrades and lighting = $5,000; installation of improved heating and air-conditioning = $7,000; improvements to entrance, hallways and staircases =$7,000; signage inside and outside $3,000; total cost estimated $35,000. Any funds received towards this goal will be used in part or total for its intended purpose. We will continue to raise funds until the work is completed.

The Artists’ Workshop will provide a venue and means for youth to have greater voice in expressing what is and is not meaningful to them while providing adults an opportunity to hear from them directly on how to assist and provide them with what they need to thrive. 

MISSION:The Hung Tao Choy Mei Leadership Institutes “We use our intense African and Chinese Traditional Cultural Arts of kung fu, lion and dragon dance, and drumming training to instill in our participants the character traits of self-reliance, personal responsibility, to strive for excellence, and to become successful adults and leaders in their chosen fields and prepare them to live a meaningful life. VISION: Through the power of our values and commitment to excellence in the traditional African and Chinese cultural arts, the HTCMLI will become the region’s leading center of excellence for youth development

History:  The Hung Tao Choy Mei Leadership Institute was founded in 1995 by Abdur-Rahim Muhammad a native Washingtonian.  President Muhammad opened the Institute at 1351 U at a time when many home owners and businesses were hesitant to invest in the area and began teaching children few thought worthy of their attention. He trained these children and sponsored their trips (over 50 local children and youth) to competitions in Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong and Mainland China and they returned home as kung fu champions holding numerous gold, silver, and bronze medals for their efforts and huge boosts to their pride and self-esteem. The Institute is recognized worldwide as one of the leading traditional martial arts organizations in the United States. “The Council of the District of Columbia recognizes and supports the Hung Tao Choy Mei Leadership Institute and in celebration of this milestone declares November 3, 2009, as the “Hung Tao Choy Mei Leadership Institute's Lion Dance and Kung Fu Champions Recognition Day” in the District  of Columbia.”
The Leadership Institute produces the annual Paul Robeson "Here I Stand" Award Gala at the 

Lincoln Theater featuring world class entertainers and scholars such as Harry Belafonte, Danny Glover, Paul Robeson Jr., Dick Gregory, Dr. John Hope Franklin, Judith Jamison, Rita Moreno, Spike Lee, and hip hop legends “Common” and Chuck D of Public Enemy the hip hop group recently inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame.  The Institute has been providing Out of School time programs for DC Children since 1995 and free full day summer camps since 2007.     

In the past eight years the Institute has provided children and older youth with an after- school program 5 days per week, Saturday morning and afternoon classes, full day summer camps for 50 children, performance opportunities at the Verizon Center during half time for Washington Mystics, Kennedy Center, Lincoln Theatre, Black Cat Nightclub, H Street Festival, Fiesta Asia, Funk Parade, and nearly 100 additional events around the Washington, DC metropolitan area. 

  The Leadership Institute has implemented a strategic framework which revolves around our integrated core values of Diversity, Creativity, Unity, Activism, Trust, Tolerance, Authenticity and Accountability. We utilize an asset based approach and shun the punitive. We focus on strengths and positive outcomes; youth voice and engagement; strategies that include all youth including those with physical and emotional challenges; community involvement and collaboration; strive to build long term commitments.  Training at Hung Tao Choy Mei is “Preparation for Living a Meaningful Life.”

story:
Who We Are

The Sable Project is a different kind of artist residency. For emerging artists of different backgrounds, it is off-grid (no electricity, internet, or cell service), environmentally engaged, grounded by physical work, and inspired by collaboration. We work hard to grow wholesome, delicious food and create inquisitive, elegant, and potent art.

Last year we started with a dream, a lot of energy, and a beautiful piece of land. By the end of the summer we had hosted 13 incredible artists, built a studio, a stage, a really cool dragon oven, a treehouse, and completed many more construction projects, grown a bountiful garden, and produced two public showcases full of inspiring art. In short, our first year was a resounding success, and now we want to do it all again! 

What's New?

Last summer was an amazing learning process, and this year we know we can make  The Sable Project even better. There have already been a bunch of changes, and many more in the works. Here's what's new!

  • We are a registered 501(c)(3) non-profit organization now. That means that we are now able to apply for grants and all of your donations are TAX DEDUCTIBLE!
  • We are growing a huge garden and running a Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) program. This includes our new "Food and Art Series," where, with the creative and physical input of both our residents and a group of talented guest artists, we will host a weekly community gathering on Friday afternoons to share and educate about the joys of fresh organic produce, sustainable living, and thoughtful, inspiring art.

Why Indiegogo Again? 

This summer we are once again hosting young, emerging artists. However, that means that our residents are often not financially able to pay for expensive programs. Because of this, we have decided that it is important and necessary to offer the residency at zero cost to our artists. 

We only just recently received our new non-profit status, and as such were not able to apply to as many grants or alternative funding sources as we needed to make this second year a possibility. That's where you come in!  With your help, you will be supporting a group of young artists who will work in innovative ways and engage deeply with their surroundings, as well as include and inspire the local Vermont community.

What We Need

We are looking to raise $10,000 again this year, mainly to cover the cost of:
  • $3000 -Food not grown in our garden
  • $3000 -Art supplies
  • $750    -Advertising/communication/marketing expenses
  • $250    -General expenses (kitchen supplies, fuel, ice, etc)
  • $750    -Transportation
  • $1250  - Legal/accounting fees for being a 501(c)(3) non-profit
  • $1000  -Insurance
In reality, these estimates are low and less than half of our organizational budget this year ta' boot! But every bit counts and we are incredibly thankful for every donation. To show our love for you, we have awesome perks this year - check them out, make sure to look at the pictures, and enjoy!

The Why

We are working on something we feel is extremely important. By exemplifying a community that cares deeply about how art can be made, food can be grown, and communities can interact with their surroundings, we hope to create a shift in the way that our artists and visitors think and act in regards to these subjects as well. In short, our goal is to inspire creative minds and healthy bodies for the greater community.

Wish List!

Can't contribute monetarily? That is fine! We have a long wish list of tons of different things which are just as helpful as donations of cash. Here it is:

  • Art supplies
  • Dry food (rice, beans, oats, etc)
  • Lumber, fasteners, and other construction supplies
  • Construction tools 
  • Gardening supplies (tools, compost, produce baskets and boxes, etc)
  • A tall ladder (or two!)
  • Coolers (these are our refrigerators!)
  • Another picnic table and more chairs
  • And more! We are open to suggestions :)
If you want to donate anything on this list, get in contact with us at thesableprojectvt@gmail.com with the subject "Wish List." Thank you!

story:
Join us for a preliminary reading of The Forgotten House/ La Maison Oubliee!

Free and open for all
Email joyarab@gmail.com to reserve your seat as places are limited.

Show times are as follows:
Saturday 5/23 at 2:00 pm and 7:00 pm
Sunday 5/24 at 1:00 pm

Short Summary

About the book and installation:

The starting point of the narrative is a childhood’s memory: "when I was a child, I thought that at least one forgotten house existed somewhere, preferably in the woods, where I could discretely settle. If I scroll through my memory, I have a very precise image of that house, I even feel that it truly exists. What would happen if one day this imaginary house ended up in the real world?"

As the book unfolds, the darkening pages make the text illegible. With LA MAISON OUBLIEE/THE FORGOTTEN HOUSE, the book as object is part of the narrative, and the slow movement of the 105 pages towards complete darkness is right away perceived as a key narrative element by the reader.

About the performance:

The actress Emilie Gruat and the musician Denis Schuler genuinely crafted this art installation into a theater and musical experience. At the end of their performance, the theater becomes a gallery and the performance a vernissage. Denis Schuler’s instruments (glasses filled with water, as ephemeral organs) also become elements of the exhibition.

Who is Who

Author/Artist: Dominique Robin

Dominique belongs to the generation of multimedia artists: text (A Clinic In Guinea, édition La Martinière, foword Mickael Lonsdale), photography (Students in Conakry), video (Les petites statues), sound (Fontaine, Murmures, ...) etc. His art installations are generally narrative, demanding the genuine participation and focused attention of viewers who are thus able to give full rein to their imagination. "My installations try to create intervals; between two drawings, two videos, two photos, there is a white space which is very liberating, from the spectator’s point of view. I like to think of my installations as marker buoys." www.dorobin.com

Actor/Translator: Emilie Gruat

Emilie has worked with prominent directors including Pierre Debauche, artistic collaborator of Antoine Vitez; Pierre Vial, a member of La Comédie Française; Ariane Mnouchkine, founder and director of the Théâtre du Soleil; Paata Tsintsdze, Georgian director and filmmaker and collaborator of Emir Kusturica and Otar Iosseliani; and Anne Bogart, founder of the SITI Company.

Actor: Hugh Buller

Hugh is a graduate of the American Academy of Graduate Arts.  In the past he has been featured in such plays as 'Good People;' ‘Dinner With Friends,’ 'The Veil,' and collaborating with Neil LaBute for the world premiere reading of his masterfully touching play 'One Day Like This.' Currently he is working for RavenFolk Productions as a main content contributor and performer. RavenFolk, a new media company, is planning the debut of its new pieces this autumn. Stay tuned!

Musician: Denis Schuler

Born in Geneva, Denis Schuler is a Swiss composer, musician, and curator. He studied composition with Michael Jarrell and Emanuel Nunes, among others. He writes and proposes programs for diverse structures at the Fondation Suisse in Paris, the Eternal Tour Festival and the Ensemble Vide. This work leads him to think about the contents of concerts, the venues, and the way the audience perceives the whole project. He favors programs that include unusual places for contemporary music and proposes original stage dispositions. These "sound-perception objects" allow the musicians to create a new relationship with the auditors, offering them new listening possibilities. www.schulerdenis.name

Director: Michael Scholar Jr.

Michael is the Founding Artistic Producer of Canada’s award winning November Theatre, producers of the world English premiere of Tom Waits, William S Burroughs and Robert Wilson’s The Black Rider, which toured internationally for a decade. With November Theatre he wrote and starred in the cult punk show Hard Core Logo: Live; and wrote and directed Ana for the 2010 Cultural Olympiad. Most recently November Theatre has been producing his directorial work at Medicine Show Theatre Uncle Vanya and Ilsa, Queen of the Nazi Love Camp. Michael has been nominated for a Jessie Award (Vancouver) for “Best Direction”, received the Canadian AEA Emerging Artist Award, and several grants from The Canada Council for the Arts including the JBC Watkins Award to pursue his MFA in Directing at Columbia University, where he is currently the Faculty Assistant to Anne Bogart. www.novembertheatre.com/bio/michael-scholar-jr

Producer: Joy Arab

Joy is currently the Assistant to Executive Director at The Martin E. Segal Theatre Center, at the Graduate Center CUNY. She is Lebanese American with a BA in Studio Arts and a minor in Theatre from the American University of Beirut. She was producer of both Rituals of Signs and Transformations (The premiere of the English translation of renowned Syrian playwright, Saadallah Wannous' major work) and the first ever site-specific play in Beirut, that were both directed by Sahar Assaf and translated/written by Dr. Robert Myers. She will be attending The School of The Arts at Columbia to continue her training in Theatre Management and Producing in the Fall of 2015. 

Why We Need Your Help

This first reading that is taking place in 10 days will be the launch of the work on the performance that we plan to make into a full blown production in the Fall. We invite you to help us raise some money in order to put on this reading and eventually the show. We will be needing your help for equipment, space rental, and other needs.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

Join us for a preliminary reading of The Forgotten House/ La Maison Oubliee!
Free and open for allEmail joyarab@gmail.com to reserve your seat as places are limited.
Show times are as follows:Saturday 5/23 at 2:00 pm and 7:00 pmSunday 5/24 at 1:00 pm
Short Summary 
About the book and installation:
The starting point of the narrative is a childhood’s memory: "when I was a child, I thought that at least one forgotten house existed somewhere, preferably in the woods, where I could discretely settle. If I scroll through my memory, I have a very precise image of that house, I even feel that it truly exists. What would happen if one day this imaginary house ended up in the real world?"
As the book unfolds, the darkening pages make the text illegible. With LA MAISON OUBLIEE/THE FORGOTTEN HOUSE, the book as object is part of the narrative, and the slow movement of the 105 pages towards complete darkness is right away perceived as a key narrative element by the reader.
About the performance:
The actress Emilie Gruat and the musician Denis Schuler genuinely crafted this art installation into a theater and musical experience. At the end of their performance, the theater becomes a gallery and the performance a vernissage. Denis Schuler’s instruments (glasses filled with water, as ephemeral organs) also become elements of the exhibition.

Who is Who
Author/Artist: Dominique Robin
Dominique belongs to the generation of multimedia artists: text (A Clinic In Guinea, édition La Martinière, foword Mickael Lonsdale), photography (Students in Conakry), video (Les petites statues), sound (Fontaine, Murmures, ...) etc. His art installations are generally narrative, demanding the genuine participation and focused attention of viewers who are thus able to give full rein to their imagination. "My installations try to create intervals; between two drawings, two videos, two photos, there is a white space which is very liberating, from the spectator’s point of view. I like to think of my installations as marker buoys." www.dorobin.com
Actor/Translator: Emilie Gruat
Emilie has worked with prominent directors including Pierre Debauche, artistic collaborator of Antoine Vitez; Pierre Vial, a member of La Comédie Française; Ariane Mnouchkine, founder and director of the Théâtre du Soleil; Paata Tsintsdze, Georgian director and filmmaker and collaborator of Emir Kusturica and Otar Iosseliani; and Anne Bogart, founder of the SITI Company.

Actor: Hugh Buller
Hugh is a graduate of the American Academy of Graduate Arts.  In the past he has been featured in such plays as 'Good People;' ‘Dinner With Friends,’ 'The Veil,' and collaborating with Neil LaBute for the world premiere reading of his masterfully touching play 'One Day Like This.' Currently he is working for RavenFolk Productions as a main content contributor and performer. RavenFolk, a new media company, is planning the debut of its new pieces this autumn. Stay tuned!
Musician: Denis Schuler
Born in Geneva, Denis Schuler is a Swiss composer, musician, and curator. He studied composition with Michael Jarrell and Emanuel Nunes, among others. He writes and proposes programs for diverse structures at the Fondation Suisse in Paris, the Eternal Tour Festival and the Ensemble Vide. This work leads him to think about the contents of concerts, the venues, and the way the audience perceives the whole project. He favors programs that include unusual places for contemporary music and proposes original stage dispositions. These "sound-perception objects" allow the musicians to create a new relationship with the auditors, offering them new listening possibilities. www.schulerdenis.name
Director: Michael Scholar Jr.
Michael is the Founding Artistic Producer of Canada’s award winning November Theatre, producers of the world English premiere of Tom Waits, William S Burroughs and Robert Wilson’s The Black Rider, which toured internationally for a decade. With November Theatre he wrote and starred in the cult punk show Hard Core Logo: Live; and wrote and directed Ana for the 2010 Cultural Olympiad. Most recently November Theatre has been producing his directorial work at Medicine Show Theatre Uncle Vanya and Ilsa, Queen of the Nazi Love Camp. Michael has been nominated for a Jessie Award (Vancouver) for “Best Direction”, received the Canadian AEA Emerging Artist Award, and several grants from The Canada Council for the Arts including the JBC Watkins Award to pursue his MFA in Directing at Columbia University, where he is currently the Faculty Assistant to Anne Bogart. www.novembertheatre.com/bio/michael-scholar-jr
Producer: Joy Arab
Joy is currently the Assistant to Executive Director at The Martin E. Segal Theatre Center, at the Graduate Center CUNY. She is Lebanese American with a BA in Studio Arts and a minor in Theatre from the American University of Beirut. She was producer of both Rituals of Signs and Transformations (The premiere of the English translation of renowned Syrian playwright, Saadallah Wannous' major work) and the first ever site-specific play in Beirut, that were both directed by Sahar Assaf and translated/written by Dr. Robert Myers. She will be attending The School of The Arts at Columbia to continue her training in Theatre Management and Producing in the Fall of 2015. 

    Why We Need Your Help
This first reading that is taking place in 10 days will be the launch of the work on the performance that we plan to make into a full blown production in the Fall. We invite you to help us raise some money in order to put on this reading and eventually the show. We will be needing your help for equipment, space rental, and other needs.

Other Ways You Can Help We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:
Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

story:
VERY IMPORTANT: MESSAGE ME YOUR EMAIL ADDRESS IF YOU CLAIM ANY OF THE PERKS LISTED, SO WE CAN DISCUSS THEM (IF THE PERK YOU HAVE CLAIMED IS THE TUMBLR PROMO, PLEASE MESSAGE ME YOUR TUMBLR URL. IF THE PERK YOU CLAIMED IS THE THANK YOU VIDEO, MESSAGE ME YOUR NAME)

Introduction

Hello, my name is Jamie Woodward and I am a 21 year old student studying Animation at the Art Institute of Pittsburgh (online). I currently live with my aunt and two pets (a chinchilla named Sherlock and a Leopard Gecko named Gryphon). I am currently unemployed and am getting money from my grandmother every month, but it really is only enough to care for my pets. I cannot get a job right now for various personal and family matters, so I am kind of in a bind.

what you will be funding

if you fund me, your money will go towards buying a cintiq graphics tablet. With this tablet, I can work in Photoshop and begin to learn animation better and start me off on the road to my dream job of being a free-lance animator.

The particular one I am looking at is around 800 dollars. The reason I ask for 1000, though, is so I can pay my grandmother back for all the support she has been giving me. Even though she is going through a lot, she still helps me out financially and I don’t know where I’d be without her. Any amount of money over 1000 will be going to the American Humane Association.

Perks!

There are perks to choose from, such as free commissions, videos dedicated to you and more! (note that "+ previous perks" do not include the previous perks with limited avalibility)

what if i don't make it?

If it turns out I don’t reach my entire goal, depending on how much I make, I will put it back to fund for the tablet in the future. Note that, no matter what, you will be getting your perks.

can't donate? no problem!

If you find you can’t contribute, please share this to signal boost it! (Note that even a dollar donation helps greatly, but you can still help by sharing!!)

story: /

A few copies of the first edition of The San Francisco Oracle Deck remain! Supply is very limited. The link to purchase will remain live here on indiegogo until we run out.  

 

The San Francisco Oracle is an original oracle deck using relatable, modern symbolism with distinctive Bay Area flavor. Developed by two Bay Area transmedia storytellers with a combined 20 years of divination research and storytelling practice between them, this original system of hand-illustrated oracle cards - which are not available in stores - offers lovers of oracle and tarot decks an opportunity to reflect on their own story through the lens of life in the city of art and innovation. 

 

Calling this a “San francisco tarot deck” doesn’t even scratch the surface! These cards have entirely original meanings and work within their own story universe. The deck includes an eight page booklet which explains the meanings and context for each card, and how to use them for readings alone or with friends. 

 

We believe our cards will dynamically engage your dreams and visions, offering you new insights and a fresh perspective through this new expression of the visionary spirit of the city by the bay!

 

 

ORIGIN STORY

 

The origin story of the San Francisco Oracle is a little weird, but what else would you expect? Last September, it seemed that the stars aligned and the sky cracked open and started revealing a deck of oracle cards based on the history of bohemian life in San Francisco. 

We drew the first raw symbols from the stars onto blank bridge cards and then met in the shadow of the Golden Gate Bridge to give each other the first readings from an oracle that would go on to *build itself* as it grew through our test-readings of San Franciscans from all walks of life. After the original reading under the bridge, we sketched more cards and fine tuned the divination system by giving a series of test readings for individuals in our community here in the Bay. These early playtesters had experience with oracle cards, and told us how relatable they found the symbols we chose, educating us on some of the nuances, and sending us back to the drawing board for refinements. As we worked, we found the inspiring stories and dreams of our early playtesters worked their way into the final product, giving it texture and life. If you live here, you know how easy it is for San Francisco to get down on itself, and while we had our cranky days, we were repeatedly buoyed by the vision of creating a tool that reflected not so much how we see the city, but by how our playtester’s reactions to the prototype illuminated the attitude and approach that defines the revolutionary creativity of San Francisco culture.

 

We then polished our new oracle to a shine by exposing it to every kind of San Franciscan we could; librarians, trapeze artists, rideshare drivers, hackers, the brunch crowd, psychedelic gurus, florists, Lowell High School teachers, landscape architects, hapless entrepreneurs caught in the swirling vortex of OracleCon at Moscone center, newspaper journalists, nurses, SEO quants, conspiracy bloggers, grass-roots historians, cable car operators, pianists, recruiters, Northbeach barflies, our innocent families, and one lucky cryptocurrency millionaire who just quit his job in pursuit of the questing beast. Nearly all gave inspiring insights in response to their test readings, and many of those insights found their way into the final design. 

 

In this way, The San Francisco Oracle is in large part a community effort, and we are deeply grateful for the opportunity we’ve had to share the creation story of the deck with so many friends both new and old.

 

Along with 53 original cards, the deck includes four card “spreads” designed to help active, creative folks - who may or may not believe in magic - make tough decisions, look at their lives from useful oblique perspectives, and reflect on parts of themselves they love or might like to change. 


Your contribution not only lands you your very own limited first edition of the San Francisco Oracle Deck, but also stands to amplify the ongoing adventure of our city’s creative spirit with every reading you give. We named this deck The San Francisco Oracle for a reason. The name is a nod to the independent newspaper that the Haight Ashbury community created during the Summer of Love.  By naming our deck after The San Francisco Oracle, we mean to honor and participate in our city’s legacy of folk esoterica. 

 

While our deck is not meant to be in any way a copy or reboot of Allen Cohen et al’s Oracle of the City of San Francisco, it is inspired by that paper’s spirit as a gift of a visionary community in authentic counsel with itself. We are huge fans of Laurence Ferlenghetti, Gary Snyder, Alan Watts, and many other luminary writers and thinkers who graced The Oracle’s pages, but the main way we hope to emulate its spirit by making a sincere and hopeful expression of our own cultural moment in San Francisco history. Because even when some folks worry that the legacy of the city’s imagination is in decline, the truth is we are still here. In 2020, as in 1967, the world needs the city that starts revolutions to get on with it’s traditional work of dreaming up a better world. 

 

What You Get  

You are paying for the printing & hand-prepared blessing & shipping of every deck you order.

Every deck in the first edition will be ritually blessed and hand-stamped with the San Francisco Oracle sigil that intends the deck be used to create beautiful new experiences to sustain the spirit of the Bay Area. Prices reflect time and expense of research, development, illustration, and large burritos split across two meals. When you contribute at higher levels you are helping the San Francisco Oracle - and art created by local artists - reach a larger audience.  

What makes this oracle’s capabilities unique is its synthesis of traditional cartomantic systems with new language & storytelling techniques. 

By helping us reach our goal, you help us bring this labor of love to a larger audience and fund the artists development of additional SFO content. Because we have chosen a flex goal, if you choose to support our campaign, your oracle - and your future - will arrive regardless of whether we reach our financing goal. 

 

WHO WE ARE

 

Eugene Ashton-Gonzalez is a transmedia poet, artist, and 7th-generation native San Franciscan. He is the creator of The Signal Room, a rogue museum featured in a documentary film published by the San Francisco Chronicle. He is also the creator & host of Eat My Heart Out, a live storytelling dinner party whose performances inspire edible metaphor. An avid student of cultural and art history in the Bay Area, he holds a B.A. in English Literature from Yale University and has studied divination and mystery traditions for many years. 

 

Robin Lehto is a visionary artist, intuitive systems developer and lifelong student of western esoterica. She holds a degree in drawing, painting and printmaking from Portland State University, with a concentration in urban folklore and transcendental philosophy. She has developed creative projects for underground urban cultures on both coasts for twenty years, the last seven of them in San Francisco. She consults with institutions, businesses, and communities to help them develop dynamic models for defining their common interests and collective wisdom.

 

As creative collaborators we have spent four years researching the historical and cultural leitmotifs of multiple cultural generations in the Bay Area. We've turned that investment into a fun & approachable storytelling tool that sparks personal connection when used with friends and gently coaches our inner wisdom to the fore. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Send this to any of your friends who like making magic local and personal. We hope it will inspire the creation of more oracles that are in deep conversation with the places they are made! If you or your friends have also made oracles or divination systems based on the SF Bay Area, we'd love to hear about it!

story:
Campaign update 2

Campaign update 1

Stretch Goal 1 of CAD$18,000 reached! 

We will send a one-page Looking-Glass Calendar 2021 to everyone who has made a deposit CAD$20 and above, along with the rewards that are listed in your pledges.

Stretch Goal 2 of CAD$24,000.

Dear friends, if we reach it, there will be an extra gift for every backer who has pledged CAD$50 and above. The gift will be your choice of: 

The print of the first page of the chosen chapter illustration - 8.5"W x 11.5"H on archival acid-free paper, signed. 

Poster with my pen/ink drawings to Alice (my first series). Vertical composition. 

Poster with my pen/ink drawings to Alice (my first series). Horizontal composition. 

What makes this limited edition of 'Through the Looking Glass and What Alice Found There' a must-have? This book is going to live up to the legacy of the original 'Alice in Wonderland' that we illustrated and published back in 2008 (more details below). That project was a great success, having been meticulously illustrated and prepared, while sparing no expense on printing and binding - a true collector's item. After many years of hard work, putting great care into illustrations, we are ready to complete the sequel. What we need now is your help to fund the printing and binding process.

We are proud to dedicate this edition to the 150th Anniversary of publishing the 'Through the Looking Glass and What Alice Found There' which we will celebrate next year (1871—2021).

 

 Lewis Carroll's masterpiece 'Through the Looking Glass and What Alice Found There' is the sequel to his 'Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'. So, all this is not about the first book? Well, that's because it, 'Alice's Adventures in Wonderland' was already published in 2008, then in 2009. This work received a lot of favorable reviews and I was awarded by IBBY for illustrations. 

Of course, I wasn’t going to stop there, and continued to work on the second story about Alice — ‘Looking Glass’. There was a lot of sketching, composing, character development, etc. Time after time the 'Looking-Glass' was put aside for other projects, one of which was the illustrating and publishing of 'The Hunting of the Snark' by Lewis Carroll. Nevertheless, despite several breaks and intermissions, the work continued up to this day, and now we are very close to the end. We would much appreciate your support in bringing this book to life.

 

A long-long time ago when I read Alice first time I was charmed by Carroll's world. Naturally, I began drawing, sketching, doodling - visualizing Alice my own way, "cause I'm a damn artist". 

 In the beginning, there were no plans to publish my drawings. My obsession with Alice's visualization had a form of an endless and unpredictable game with characters, situations, adventures, and nonsense. Each time I reread the book I found new details, new aspects of the conversations or circumstances, which I had missed before. It doesn't matter whether you are an observant, meticulous reader or not — Carroll is a magician, his literary techniques are often similar to an illusionist's craft. A single passage can be read seven times, but suddenly, on the eighth time, you notice an obvious detail and think to yourself: "how in the world could I have missed this before?" 

 

  I drew characters, composed scenes, invented costumes and surroundings, everything was getting “curiouser and curiouser”. I just could not stop, it became an obsessive occupation, a kind of hobby, a favorite pastime. And at some point, I realized that all this madness must be turned into something, into a book. So, I collected all the graphic works and began to collate them into a series of illustrations with a coherent style for a book.

 

 

While reading "Alice", sometimes it is hard to understand what unites some parts of the book. Each chapter looks like an isolated event that isn't related to any other; different characters, locations, and events can be easily changed, can be rearranged, without losing the coherence of the story.

English is my second language, so some of the finer words and nuances elude me to this day, but at some point, I stumbled upon the word "scene" and thought it a perfect fit to describe each chapter. Yes, these chapters really look like theatrical acts.

 

Carroll starts the chapter like this:

     “There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house, and the March Hare and the Hatter were having tea at it: a Dormouse was sitting between them…”

Doesn't this remind you of the mise-en-scene (arrangement of the stage) in a play? Lewis Carroll (Charles Lutwidge Dodgson) was very fond of theater, theatricality, and stage performance, and this love helped him to write and construct the story about Alice. Based on this idea, I built myself a peculiar image of the curtain, so the illustration as a whole consists of:

     1) The main part of the drawing executed in brown color.

     2) Frame or a kind of curtain, drawn in black and white with graphite pencil.

This curtain not only frames the illustration, but also tells “its own” story, explains to us some details of conversations, verses, thoughts, and/or various literary, cultural and historical reminiscences. 

 

 
 
 

4 Unbirthday Cards
 
 

Playing Cards

 
 

12 postcards

  


Prints of Chapters First Pages

 


'Queen Alice Feast' — Print

 


'Looking-Glass' — Print

 

 

The Book — Limited edition of 'Looking-Glass'

The Book — Limited edition of 'Looking-Glass' copies #11-#99.
The Book 'Special' — Limited edition of 'Looking-Glass' with the unique hand-drawn character of your choice on the dedication page. Copies #2-#10 and #100
 


'Looking-Glass' — original illustration


Original illustration to 'Looking-Glass'. Observe the entire collection here: http://www.fieric.com/lipchenko/wordpress/illustrations/looking-glass-original-drawinds/
 

'Looking-Glass' & 'Wonderland'


You get a set of two books: 'Looking Glass' Limited Edition — featured project, and 'Alice in Wonderland' Limited Edition, published in 2008. The quantity of remaining copies of "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" is very limited (a couple of dozens is still available). Both books numbered and signed by the artist.

 

 

Risks & Challenges

We have met certain difficulty with printing — the printer which had completed our request with 'Alice in Wonderland' Limited Edition, published in 2008, doesn't produce books anymore, so we had to search for another one with equal capabilities and ability to match the quality of the first book. We are lucky to have found one.
The possibility of delays during the pre-press and printing process has been considered, so our deadlines are set with a fair margin.

We are proud to dedicate this edition to the 150th Anniversary of publishing the 'Through the Looking Glass and What Alice Found There' which we will celebrate next year (1871—2021).
 

 Lewis Carroll's masterpiece 'Through the Looking Glass and What Alice Found There' is the sequel to his 'Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'. So, all this is not about the first book? Well, that's because it, 'Alice's Adventures in Wonderland' was already published in 2008, then in 2009. This work received a lot of favorable reviews and I was awarded by IBBY for illustrations. 
Of course, I wasn’t going to stop there, and continued to work on the second story about Alice — ‘Looking Glass’. There was a lot of sketching, composing, character development, etc. Time after time the 'Looking-Glass' was put aside for other projects, one of which was the illustrating and publishing of 'The Hunting of the Snark' by Lewis Carroll. Nevertheless, despite several breaks and intermissions, the work continued up to this day, and now we are very close to the end. We would much appreciate your support in bringing this book to life.
 

A long-long time ago when I read Alice first time I was charmed by Carroll's world. Naturally, I began drawing, sketching, doodling - visualizing Alice my own way, "cause I'm a damn artist". 
 In the beginning, there were no plans to publish my drawings. My obsession with Alice's visualization had a form of an endless and unpredictable game with characters, situations, adventures, and nonsense. Each time I reread the book I found new details, new aspects of the conversations or circumstances, which I had missed before. It doesn't matter whether you are an observant, meticulous reader or not — Carroll is a magician, his literary techniques are often similar to an illusionist's craft. A single passage can be read seven times, but suddenly, on the eighth time, you notice an obvious detail and think to yourself: "how in the world could I have missed this before?" 
 

  I drew characters, composed scenes, invented costumes and surroundings, everything was getting “curiouser and curiouser”. I just could not stop, it became an obsessive occupation, a kind of hobby, a favorite pastime. And at some point, I realized that all this madness must be turned into something, into a book. So, I collected all the graphic works and began to collate them into a series of illustrations with a coherent style for a book.
 


 

While reading "Alice", sometimes it is hard to understand what unites some parts of the book. Each chapter looks like an isolated event that isn't related to any other; different characters, locations, and events can be easily changed, can be rearranged, without losing the coherence of the story.
English is my second language, so some of the finer words and nuances elude me to this day, but at some point, I stumbled upon the word "scene" and thought it a perfect fit to describe each chapter. Yes, these chapters really look like theatrical acts.
 

Carroll starts the chapter like this:
     “There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house, and the March Hare and the Hatter were having tea at it: a Dormouse was sitting between them…”
Doesn't this remind you of the mise-en-scene (arrangement of the stage) in a play? Lewis Carroll (Charles Lutwidge Dodgson) was very fond of theater, theatricality, and stage performance, and this love helped him to write and construct the story about Alice. Based on this idea, I built myself a peculiar image of the curtain, so the illustration as a whole consists of:
     1) The main part of the drawing executed in brown color.
     2) Frame or a kind of curtain, drawn in black and white with graphite pencil.
This curtain not only frames the illustration, but also tells “its own” story, explains to us some details of conversations, verses, thoughts, and/or various literary, cultural and historical reminiscences. 
 

 
 

 

4 Unbirthday Cards  
Playing Cards  
12 postcards  
Prints of Chapters First Pages 
'Queen Alice Feast' — Print 
'Looking-Glass' — Print 
 
The Book — Limited edition of 'Looking-Glass'

The Book — Limited edition of 'Looking-Glass' copies #11-#99.The Book 'Special' — Limited edition of 'Looking-Glass' with the unique hand-drawn character of your choice on the dedication page. Copies #2-#10 and #100 
'Looking-Glass' — original illustration
Original illustration to 'Looking-Glass'. Observe the entire collection here: http://www.fieric.com/lipchenko/wordpress/illustrations/looking-glass-original-drawinds/ 
'Looking-Glass' & 'Wonderland'
You get a set of two books: 'Looking Glass' Limited Edition — featured project, and 'Alice in Wonderland' Limited Edition, published in 2008. The quantity of remaining copies of "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" is very limited (a couple of dozens is still available). Both books numbered and signed by the artist.

 
 

Risks & Challenges
We have met certain difficulty with printing — the printer which had completed our request with 'Alice in Wonderland' Limited Edition, published in 2008, doesn't produce books anymore, so we had to search for another one with equal capabilities and ability to match the quality of the first book. We are lucky to have found one.The possibility of delays during the pre-press and printing process has been considered, so our deadlines are set with a fair margin.

story:
The Art Book

I have been a horror fan all my life and I’ve always wanted to create a terrifying horror world of my own. Being an artist working in the game industry, it was natural for me to approach the project with a sketchbook first. A simple sketch became a painting, a page of story became six months worth of writing...the moment I thought I was done with everything, a new idea had me opening my sketchbook again. After so many sketchbooks and bottles of Bushmills, in late 2017 I finally put my foot down and told myself that I’m going to have my closure on the project by making an art book out of it. The art of Year Of The Ladybug omits a few things  but it holds large amount of visions I had for this world I created. With your love and support, it is my sincere belief that we can finish this book so that we are one step closer to the game. I had so much fun working on it, and I hope that you will love it as much as I do. 

 

The Impact

  • This book is for both horror fans and art lovers. 
  • There are many types of fear yet the game industry relies so heavily on jump scares and darkness. This is my way of exploring the other side of horror.
  • I will use this book as the official pitch to contact developers. 

 

Risks & Challenges

The tricky thing about making an art book for a game that doesn’t exist is deciding on what to share and what not to. Since most art books are read and appreciated after finishing the game, not spoiling the story was an obvious choice but how much of the visuals do you share when you are both trying to get people interested and hoping to see the game in future? I did what I can do to balance it and I hope that you will find this book amusing enough until we have the game. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You certainly don't have to buy the book to support the project. If you believe in this project, please share it with someone who may want to be involved. Let's get the word out and make some noise about this campaign!

 

A Special Thanks

The project was first announced in 2016 (link) and I've been blessed with tremendous amount of love and support from horror fans around the world, especially from Japan and Korea. I cannot thank you guys enough. 

私は昔からホラーファンで、いつか身の毛がよだつような自分のホラーゲームを作りたいと思っています。ゲーム業界でアーティストとして働いているので、私にとってスケッチブックからこのプロジェクトに取り組むことは自然なことでした。シンプルなスケッチが絵になり、1ページのストーリが、6か月分の膨大なストーリーになり．．.すべて終わったと思った瞬間に新しいアイデアが浮かび、またスケッチブックを開いていました。沢山のアイデアが詰まったスケッチブックが積み重なり、空のBushmills（ウイスキーの種類）のボトㇽも増えてきた2017年の下旬に、私はついに区切りをつけ、このYOTLゲーム化のプロジェクトを終わらせ、アートブックを作ろうと決意しました。YOTLのアートはゲームの全てではありませんが、自分が作り上げたホラーの世界の構想の大きな部分です。ゲーム化へまた一歩近づけるように、 あなたの愛とサポートのおかげでこのアートブックを完成させることができたと心から信じています。このアートブックを作るのは本当に楽しい作業でした。そして私と同じように、あなたがこの本をとても気に入ってくれると嬉しいです。

안녕하세요. 이어오브더레이디버그 작가 데이브캥입니다. 먼저 게임 소식이 아니라는 점, 기대 하셨던 분들께 죄송합니다. 2015년 프로잭트를 시작했을때 2가지 목표가 있었습니다. 어설픈 스토리와 갑툭튀에 반항하는 게임 아이디어를 만들자, 그리고 그것을 아트북으로 만들어서 세상에 공개하자. 그렇게 신나서 열심히 아트북을 작업하던 중 제가 활동했던 커뮤니티에 몇장의 그림을 올려보았고 그것을 본 어느 일본인의 트위터 글로 갑작스래 이어오브더레이디버그가 게임으로 만들어 진다는 기사가 뜨게 되었죠. 기사는 북미와 한국에도 퍼지기 시작했고 저는 고민 하였습니다.  비지니스는 책이 완성이 되면 생각해 보려 했는데 게임을 기다리는 팬분들이 늘어나면서 기회 놓치지 말고 게임으로 바로 발전 시켜보자 라는 생각으로 1년동안 머리를 싸매었죠. 지금 생각해 보면 참 불필요한 고민으로 시간을 낭비 했습니다. 직장생활 하면서, 남편으로 아빠로 살면서, 시간 쪼개어 취미생활로 시작했던 그 즐거웠던 프로잭트로 스트레스를 받는다는거 바람직 하지 못했기 때문이죠. 작년 말 에서야 정신 차리고 원래 계획이였던 아트북 작업을 다시 시작하였고 이제 거의 다 완성 하였습니다. 완성된 책으로 개발자를 찾아볼까 합니다. 제가 직접 개발 하기에는 회사에서 아트디렉터로서, 집에서는 가장으로서 해야할 일이 참 많습니다. 이 크라우드펀딩 캠페인은 아트북을 원하시는 분 들을 위해서 시작합니다. 늘 응원해 주셔서 감사합니다.

story:
This is fundraising for an art project for Burning man 2022.  I can't cancel or edit the campaign goal, so this fundraiser will stay up as is.  But I don't need near the money this year - no trucking fees, or transport expenses.  Burning Man has partially funded the project, as part of their Honoraria program, and I'll have enough for materials and a few months shop rent.  Of course, it'll probably take longer than that.  

The money goes to materials, transportation costs, and shop expenses.  It is an ambitious project - a lot of materials, logistics, and, of course, fabrication.  I will put in thousands of unpaid hours manifesting the animals, using every skill & every tool I have, and I couldn't do it without your help.   And I'm so grateful.  My shop is fitted out with all the equipment I need to build these animals - in short, I have the facilities,  the experience, and the motivation, I just need help with overhead & expenses.  

I think the piece is important, that it means something, and I look forward very much to many discussions around the council.  Thank you for your consideration.

The money goes to materials, transportation costs, and shop expenses.  It is an ambitious project - a lot of materials, logistics, and, of course, fabrication.  I will put in thousands of unpaid hours manifesting the animals, using every skill & every tool I have, and I couldn't do it without your help.   And I'm so grateful.  My shop is fitted out with all the equipment I need to build these animals - in short, I have the facilities,  the experience, and the motivation, I just need help with overhead & expenses.  
I think the piece is important, that it means something, and I look forward very much to many discussions around the council.  Thank you for your consideration.

story:
Queer artists deserve to be paid. Help us participate in the NFT movement!

My name is Ruby Powers and I’m an artist and do-gooder in New York City. In my years of doing drag, I’ve seen it all. And sometimes the audience has, too! 

But one thing I’ve noticed is that the economics of being a queer artist are not easy. When I heard about cryptocurrency and NFTs, I realized that this was a financial movement I couldn’t let pass me by. I wanted to learn the game and bring my friends along with me.

That is why I am launching The Queenly NFT, a cryptogallery for queer artists.
 

Let me start by explaining NFTs.

NFT stands for non-fungible token. Any piece of content, like art, photography, or music can become a NFT. Think of it like an official digital record of a work--stored in blockchain. And NFTs are being bought and sold as digital collectibles sometimes for hundreds, thousands, or millions of dollars.
 

Here's how my gallery will work.

Dozens of amazing artists from iconic photographers, to viral musicians, to the most legendary drag queens will exhibit their work via The Queenly NFT. And investors will buy or bid on their work!

From there, creators get fair compensation, plus a donation to their charity of choice! Then, if their NFTs sell again, they even get a cut of those future sales! 

Selling an important work in this way could have huge impact on the financial health and livelihood of the artists involved.
 

Here's what we need.

I’ve been bootstrapping this project so far and my budget is stretched tighter than my corset. My original plan was to hunker down and make this work with credit cards–but that financial advice is not Ruby-approved for my friends or for myself!

I need to raise about $10,000 to kickstart my idea. This will help me:

  • Bring on the staff I need to do contract review
  • Cover start up costs like LLC registration, website, bookkeeping, business checking, etc. 
  • Pay for ads and publicity to spread the message about queer inclusion!
  • Throw the best fancy launch event that this project deserves
     

The LGBT+ community needs help when it comes to fair finance.

Queer people, especially queer people of color and queer women, are often behind in financial literacy–and we often get taken advantage of. Queer people already have NFTs of their work being sold and they are not always consenting or getting compensated! This gallery will be a place that investors can trust will do right by the creators.

On a wider level, this gallery will prove that queer people are capable and ready to participate in the future of finance. Did you know that queer people with mortgages pay an average of 2% more than straight people? There are so many ways that queer people lag when it comes to equal opportunity and this gallery wants to help change that.

 

Help me make 'herstory' by launching the first ever cryptogallery for queer creators. ❤️
